editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: THE CANTING Academy, OR, THE Devils Cabinet Opened: WHEREIN IS SHEWN
div.p: The Myterious and Villanous Practices of that wicked Crew, commonly known by the Names of Hectors, Trapanners, Gilts, &c.
TO WHICH IS ADDED A Compleat Canting-Dictionary, both of old Words, and uch as are now mot in ue.
With everal New Catches AND SONGS, Compos'd by the choiet Wits of the Age.
A Book very ueful and neceary to be read by all orts of People.
London, Printed by F. Leach for Mat. Drew, and are to be old by the Bookellers. 1673.

div.head: To all orts of Perons, But more epecially, Inn-keepers, Victuallers, and TRAVELLERS.
div.p:
YOu are not ignorant how little there is extant in Print of a way of peaking, commonly known by the name of Canting, a Speech as confued, as the Profeors thereof are diorderly dipos'd; and yet you know how much it is in ue among ome Perons, I mean, the more debauched and looer ort of people. I would
not advie any honet minded man, or one that valu â€¢
<> R â€¢ putation to run <â€¦> into a Rogues Company; but yet I know he cannot avoid falling into their Company ome times; if it hould be your mihap, it will be a great convenience to you to have ome knowledge of what is contained in this inuing Treatie: In the firt part you will know how to ditinguih a Rogue from an honet Man, and what the Properties of a Villain are; in the later part you may acquaint your <> , with o much Canting,
â€¢ s will give you to undertand what they ay, and what damn'd deigns they are about.

The Canting-Dictionary Englih before Canting, and Canting before Englih is more compleat than any hath been publiht <> and I can aure <> the helps extant being o inconidenable â€¢ the pains I took in the Collection of <> Words is unima ginable; however I hall not <> my pains, if it may profit my Countrey-men, whoe welfare I have herein tudied, and if this prove acceptable, I hall <â€¦> in deavon â€¢ by labouring to erve you in omething ele of this nature. Fare well.

item.hi: Examples of Covetounes, Idlenes, Gluttony, and Lechery.

div.head: Villanies Dicovered: OR THE DEVILS CABINET Broken Open, &c.
div.p: THe task I have undertaken is o difficult, and the Perons I am about to deoribe o many, and their Vices and Practices o Villainouly various, (though they all concenter in one Hellih deign) that I know not how to begin, nor how to end when I have begun, for their Rogueries are infinite, and would everlatingly practice them, did not Hemp of their own beating, and a Rope of their own making, put an end to the further progres of their matchles Villainies.

However, I hall endeavour to give you an exact account of thee Caterpillars, with their hidden and myterious way of peaking, which they make ue of to blind the eyes of thoe they have cheated or robb'd, and inform one another with what they have done, or deigne to do. There is no profet Rogue whatever, (if he be qualified for his thieving faculty) but mut be well vers'd in Canting: and to the intent that they may not fall hort of being excellent proficients in all manner of Roguery, they lay the ground work thereof in Canting, for by this they are able to convere with, and undertand thoe of the upper Form of Villany, and by contant frequenting their company, become acquainted with Canting words which are mot new, and what are thrown aide as too commonly known, the ue whereof if not timely left off, may be the Intruments which may unhappily betray them to their condign punihments.

The principal Profeors of this Gibberih or Canting, I find, are a ort of People which are vulgarly called Gypies; and they do endeavour to perwade the ignorant, that they were extracted from the Egyptians, a people heretofore very famous for Atronomy, Natural Magick, the Art of Divination, with many other occult Arts and Sciences; and thee Strolers (that they may eem to have their derivation from thee ancient black Magi) are great pretenders to Fortune-telling, and to colour their impotures, they artificially dicolour their faces, and with this tawny hew and tatterdemallion habit, they rove up and down the Country, and with the pretenion of wonderful prediction, delude a many of the younger and les intelligent people.

And that they may not prejudice their Society
any ways by foolih babling, betraying the hellih ecrets of the fraternity, they wear all that are admitted into their Fellowhip: for did they not take that coure, they could not be afe among themelves from homebred treachery. For as they live together, o they lie promicuouly one with another; o that as they know not how to claim a propriety in the children begotten, the Mothers â€¢ nely being enible whoe they are by conception, o all things ele are in common among them. This general interet tyes them more firmly together, than if all their rags were twited into ropes to bind them indiolvably from a Separation.

However they have a Form of an Oath, with Articles annexed thereunto, which though it binds but lightly, yet they keep it for the mot part inviolably, which every one mut take before he is admitted into this ragged ociety, adminitred by the principal Maunder, or Roguing Stroler.

div.head: The Form of the Oath, with the Articles thereunto annexed, which thee Gypies and other Stroling Canters take, when they are firt admitted into this Society.
div.p: HIs name is firt demanded, and after ome little paue, a Nick-name given him, by which he is ever after called, and in time his other name is quite forgotten. Then up he tands in the middle, and directing his face to the Principal, he wears in this manner; as it is dictated to him by one of the mot experienced:

I Crank Cuffin do wear to be a true Brother, and will in all things obey the commands of the great tawny Prince, and keep his counel, nor
divulge the Secrets of my Brethren.

I will take my Princes part againt all hall oppoe him, or any of us, according to the utmot of my ability: nor will I uffer him, or any thereunto belonging, to be abued by any trange Abrams, Rufflers, Hookers, Palliards, Swadlers, Irih Toyls, Swig-men, Whip-jacks, Jark-men, Bawdy-baskets, Dommerars, Clapperdogeons, Patric â€¢ es, or Curtalls, but will defend him or them as much as I can againt th â€¢ e or any other Outlyers whatever.
I will not conceal ought I win out of Libkens, or from the Rufmans, but will preerve it for the ue of the Company.
I will never leave nor forake this Company but oberve and keep all the times of appointment either by day or by night, in any place whatoever.
I will not teach any one to Cant, nor will I dicloe ought of our myteries to them, although they flaug me to the death.
Latly, I will cleave to my Doxy Wap tiffly, and will bring her Cloaths, Hens, Turkies, Piggs, Geee, or any thing ele I can come at, as winnings for her wapping.

Having adopted a new Brother, a general tock is raied for Booz; as for Peck, that they can procure without money; the Booz being fetcht, ome are ent to break the Rufmans, for firing, others to filch Tybs of the Buttery, Cackling cheats, Margery Praters, Red-hanks, and Grunting cheats; their Morts are their Butchers, who preently make bloody work with what living things are brought them. The fire kindled under ome remore hedg or obcure place, the food is diverly dreed; you mut not imagine that they had a
Jack, or Dripping-pan, to roat their meat with; or when it was dret, they were overcurious of auce, napkins, or trenchers; but to work they go when all is ready, Tooth and Nail; and having eaten more like Beats than Men, they drink more like Swine than humane Creatures.

div.head: The Reaons, or Caues, of their following this coure of Life.
div.p: THey are a lazy and idle fort of people which cannot indure to take pains for an honet livelihood, but rather then labour, trole up and down all the Summer time in Droves or Companies, and by telling fortunes (that is, by deluding young Country wenches, and other foolih and credulous people) they pick up a great deal of Money, not onely what is freely given, but they will dextrouly pick pocket whilt they are telling thee imple people what hall hereafter befall them. For whilt one of thee cunning Gypies holds the hand, pretending to read therin trange things which hall come to pas, another ecretly and nimbly dives into their pocket; what money is taken from thence, is intantly conveyed to another, and o to a third, and by a fourth o cunningly hid, that the trictet earch hall never find it out. If you tax them therewith, they will make a thouand imprecations, oaths and protetations that they have none of it, wihing the ground may open and wallow them up if they meddled therewith, yet if ome perty reward be offered to the dicoverer, or the evere lah produced, or oundly threatned, whatever was lot hall be intantly retored.

I have heard when ilver hatbands were in fahion, â€¢ h â€¢ everal of them were toln off the hats of uch who were o indicreet as to inquire of thee roguih Impotors what hall befall them, and by uch means, that one would admire how it could be done, for whilt the Mother did earnetly look in the hand, the child at the back pin'd up with a skewer (after the Irih fahion) reaching over the Mothers head takes off the hatband; I am credibly informed that thee childeren were taught to do it â€¢ t two year old. Beides picking of pockets, they are very dextrous in tealing any thing that comes near their hands, either within doors or without, which they intantly convert into Money, and that into drink, of which they all hare alike, all things being in common amongt them; this is it which makes them take uch delight in this villainous way of living; in this following tory you hall more fully undertand their way.

In the Year one thouand ix hundred eventy and one, I rode from London to viit ome friends at Rocheter, by the way I met with a crew of tr â€¢
ling canting Gypies, whilt I was buying my eyes about them with more curioity than dicretion, I was urrounded by them and o beet with them or every ide, that I knew not what to think, having before moo many palpable ymptomes of approaching danger; however, I thought it prudence not to expres any fear, and therefore undauntedly I demanded their buines, and the reaon of their thus thronging about me? Sir, aid one, which eem'd to be the lutiet and mot confident fellow of the whole Company, we come from a far courtry (peaking in a trange tone, and tranger Englih) and are the true children of the Wie men of the Eat, we are skil'd in the dark and ecret myteries
of Nature, and uck'd from our Mothers breats the knowledge of the tars, and can tell what hath or will befall mortals, by the lines in their hands; hereupon he deired me to let him look into my hand, and he would tell me things I hould be glad and willing to undertand. Whilt he was buying himelf in telling me my fortunes, I with much earnetnes oberved his countenance, which methoughts I knew, notwithtanding its tawny dye; I view'd it again and again, and by often comparing the preent lineaments of his face, with thoe my memory had formerly retained of him, I grew confident this man mut be one of my former acquaintance. Having throughly view'd my hand, and eemingly taking ome information from my face, he began to tell me ome truths that I knew to be o, (for like a cunning Rogue he had not forgot me) though he would not take the leat notice of me; and that I might not upect him, he preently roved from the dicoure of what he experimentally knew of me, and talk'd at random of I know not what; Having finihed his predictions, intead of giving him a reward, I deired that I might ee his hand, and in requital of the pains he had taken to tell me my fortune, I told him, I would tell him his; With ome unwillingnes he gave me his hand, and looking into it, after ome paue, I pake after this manner: Sir, I can but reverence and admire you for your great skill, and mut repect your peron, in pight of the meanes of your apparel. What you have informed me with, for the mot part is o true, that had you been my boome and mot familiar Friend, you could not have told me more; and that I may make proof of my knowledge in your myterious art of divination, give me leave to tell you ome things, the truth whereof your elf hall be Judge of.

Firt, You are an Englih man, and have not one drop of Egyptian <> in you; the place of your nativity was Exceter, where you made ome proficency in the learning at the Grammar School; but o notorious arch and Roguih you grew, that before you arrived to ixteen years of age you had like to have been hanged twice. From this famous Wetern City, you were tranmitted to London, where you had not erved above half the time of your Apprenticehip, before you had committed o many villanies, that London was reolved to pew you out of your Native Country; for one fact (you wot of well) more notorious than the rest, tranported you to Virginia.

p.hi: My skill in Palmetry, Phyiognomy, and Atrology, will not inform me more than what I have related: You know how you have behaved your elf there, and ince your return, and You and I both know what will become of you at lat, if you do not hun this wicked and lazy coure of life, and endeavour to live other wie.

div.p: Hereupon I clapt purrs to my Hore, but could not tir one foot, for this turdy Rogue had fat hold of my bridle Reins. Now did I think he would have hinder'd me from ever telling Fortunes more, but I was oon convinced to the contrary, when I aw in what humble manner he beeeched me to tay, that he might have a little time to dicoure with me: I granted his requet, and did o far prevail with me, as to lie that night at an houe of his appointment.

Without much ceremony in taking leave of one the other, on I rid to the place appointed for our meeting, it being not many miles ditant from the place where I met with this ragged crue of Tatterdemallions, I got in four hours before Sunet: I might have been there ooner had it not been for
the obcurity of the place on which this tately Maunding Manion, this Begging Dormitory tood, which I found out more by the decription my Captain Gypie gave me of it, than any other information I met with by the way.

Arriving at the houe, with what tokens I brought with me, my reception was as kind as they could make it; and preparations were intantly made, not onely for my ake, but for the welcome of the Strolers they expected.

The houe was not very plendid you may imagine, yet large enough to contain three times tha Company. Whilt I was penively itting, thinking on what I had een, and tudying how I might divert my elf till their coming, my Hots daughter brought me ome Ale, of which I had no ooner tated, but I was forced to commend the goodnes of it.

She was homely, yet cleanly clad, and very tall. The Father and Mother, what with age and artificial means they heretofore ued to dicolour their faces, look'd like the twins of a lecherous He-Devil, begotten on an overgrown age-ridden Lapland Witch; for it eems this pair of Houe-keepers had formerly ued the trade of troling and telling fortunes, but growing old and unable to travel, had by the aitance of the Brotherhood, erected this Fabrick for their reception.

The goodnes of the Ale made me drink freely of it, and the liberty I took to indulge my appetite, made me as freely talk. This perwaded my Hot and Hotes that they might take ome freedom to, nor was the daughter therein a jot behind us; I might now properly ay, we were as merry as o many Beggars: and that I might not want Muick to increae my mirth, the Father, Mother, and
Daughter did interchangably ing, but in uch a language that I hould never have undertood what they ung, had they not been o kind to be their own interpreters. The ongs which they ung in Canting I have added to this treatie.

I drank to o high a pitch, that I was forced to forake my Company and betake my elf to leep, truting them to do with me as they pleaed, but awaking after two hours, and conidering how foolihly I had done, I examined my pockets but found nothing miing, then turning my elf about, there lay my untouch'd Bed-fellow, the Hots daughter by my ide, who tired with expectation was fallen aleep, it was unkindly done of me to light the preent my loving Landlady had ent me, and I could not but be troubled at the diatifaction I read in the eyes and face of the poor fool'd and cheated Girl.

By that time, I got up, in came the Egyptian Prince, according to his hour, with his Concubines children and the ret of his retinue, who were intantly conducted into the larget room in the houe, commonly called the Hall, where every one being eated, and tore of booz and fogus, (Drink and Tobacco) brought them, I was acquainted with their arrival, and of his Hignes deire to have ome conference with me.

I obey'd the Summons who upon my approach ar â€¢
â€¢ and welcom'd me into their Society: there were few complements pat between us, intead thereof the brown bowl pat often, none refuing their liquor, nay, thee of four years old were taught <â€¦> the bottom of the cup; in an hours time the room and all in i â€¢ became inviible, for nothing was to be een, but the moak that proceeded from their Pipes of an inch long.

The fury of this moaking rage being omewhat abated, and having pretty well drench'd their Veuvian throats, they began to ing their wild tunes: endeavouring to make harmony out of the greatet dicord imaginable.

I would fain have had ome dicoure with my old acquaintance, but he deired me to defer it a little longer and hereupon he calls a luty rogue to him, and comands him to ing a Canting ong, which was made upon the Budge, that is, uch who teal into houes in the night carrying off what next comes to their hands; of which tribe, as he told me, he was formerly one, which he deerted for the continual hazard attending the Profeers thereof, and betook himelf to this, in which there is no great danger of life, only a fleaing of the skin now and then or o; and thus he ang.

div.head: 1. Canting Song.
Of the Budge.

lg.l: THe Budge is one that lips into an houe in the dark, and taketh what next comes to his hands and marche â€¢ h off with it. Budge it is a delicate trade,
And a delicate trade of fame,
For when that we have Bit the blow, that is, done â€¢ he fear, or committed the theft or roguery of what nature oever. bit the blow
We carry away the Cully game.
But if the naps Cully us; that is, the Peron robbed apprehends them. naps us,
And the Lurries, Mony, Watch, Ring, or any other moveable. Lurries from us take,

O then he Rubs <>
â€¢ o the rubs us to the Whi â€¢ , ends them to Newgate. Whit,

Though w'are hardly worth a Make, ha â€¢
â€¢ eny. Make.
And when that we come to the Whit,
Our Darbies, irons, or Shackles or fetters for Fellons. Darbyes to behold,
And for to do our pennance there
We booz the Water cold;
But when that we come out again,
And the merry Hick, any peron whatever of whom they can make a prey. Hick we meet,
Weel File, to rob or cheat. file him of his Cole Money of any â€¢ rt. cole,
As he As he pikes, as he walks o â€¢ goes. pikes along the treet.
And when that we have filed him,
Perhaps of half a Half a job, ten hillings, or half a piece. Job
Then every man to the Boozing Ken, an Ale-houe or houe of entertaintment. Boozing Ken
And there to fence his hog, pend his hilling fence his hog.
But if the Cully napps us,
As a thing it is unfit
To take away the cole from us
And rub us to the Whit.
And when we come unto the Whit
For garnih they do cry,
Marry fogh, Pox on you, you on of a bi â€¢ ch,
You hall have it by and by.
Then every man with his <note n="" place="bottom">Mob, a Wench or Whore. Mob in his hand,
And o we kis and part,
From hence we are divorced
To the Nubbing cheat, the Gallows. Nubbing-cheat in a Cart.
And when we come to the Nubbing-cheat
For running on the Budge,
There tands Jack Kitch, the proper name of the Common Hangman that is now in being. Jack Kitch, that on of a bitch,
Who owes us all a grudge;
For when that he hath nubbed us,
And our friends Tips him no Cole, gives him no Money. tips him no cole,
He takes his Chive, a Knife. Chive and cuts us down
And tips us into the hole.
But if we have a friend tands by
Six and eight pence the uual fee which is given to carry back the body of the executed Malefactor to give it Chritian burial. Six and eight pence for to pay,
Then they may have <â€¦> back,
And carry us quite <â€¦>
For at St Giles, or St. Martins
A burying place is till;
And there's an end of a running Budge,
And the Son of a whore hath his will.

div.p:
This ong being ended, I was askt how I liked it, I told him the tune might be paable, but in the compoition there was much more impudence than ene or reaon; he preently replyed, how groly Sir you are mitaken, to expect from uch either ene or reaon; for had they either, they could not be o impudent as to continue in uch coures which bring ome or other of that Gang to
the Gallows every Seions. I was omewhat urprized at this udden reply from a peron o inconiderable to outward appearance, but the remembrance of his former good education and natural arts, leen'd my admiration. Whilt I was thus nuing with my elf, another of this Hellih conregation put me out of my dumps, by voluntary inging after this manner.

div.head: 2. Canting Song.
The Beggars Cure.

lg.l: THe Ruffin cly the nab of the Harmanbeck
If we maund Pannam, lap, or ruff peck
Or poplars of Yarum; he cuts bing to the Ruffmans,
Or ele he boldly wears by the Lightmans,
To put our tamps fat in the Harmans,
The Ruffin cly the Ghot of the Harmanbeck.
If we heave a booth we cly the Jerk,
If we niggle or Mill a Boozing Ken
Or nip a bung that hath but a win,
Or dup the Giger of a Gentry Coves Ken,
Straight to the Cuffin quire we bing,
And then to the Whit, to cour the cramprings,
From thence at the Nubbing-cheat we trine in the Lightmans
The Bube and the Ruffin cly the Harmanbeck and Harmans.

lg.head: Thus rendred in Englih, word for word.
lg.l: THe Devil take the Contables head
If we beg milk, bacon, butter or bread,
Milk, Pottage to the hedge bids us hie,
Or wears by this light i'th tocks we hall lie.
The Devil haunt the Contables Ghot,
If we rob but a Cabbin w'are whipt at a pot;
If a pittiful Ale-houe we rob or break open,
Or cut a pure hath but one ingle token,
Or come tealing in at a Gentlemans door,
To the Jutice w'are hurried though never o poor
Then next to the Goal to be ha â€¢ kled with irons
And then to the Gallows which many invirons,
Where up we are trus'd i'th' day time; the Pox
Take the Contable and the Devil take the tocks.

div.p:
Now it was thought high time to interline their inging with drinking, which they did with a wit
â€¢ s. The trangenes of their adventure, as it â€¢ oet my brains with admiration, o it eized my fancy with ome kind of delectation, and to expr â€¢
â€¢ me ene of atisfaction, I eem'd in ome meaure as merry as they; my complacency to their humours o obliged them, that triving to outdo each other in inging, I thought with the Nightingal, they would have dyed in the attempt; had not upper come in in the mean time to top their Mouths. I li â€¢ ed the chear well enough, being good proviion, and well dres'd, but the ight of the oppoite Guets had o turn'd my tomack, that not one bit would go down with me.

I could not forbear laughing out-right, when I conider'd my itting at the table. I was eated at the upper end, as deerving the place by the merit of my garme â€¢ s, the two poles admitting of no greater difference than between their cloaths and mine. Any one of indifferent judgment eeing me o inthron'd, would have worn I had been King of the Beggars, or that I had been ome Low-Country
Factor ent over to traffick with thee Rag-merchants.

Our tomacks were o harp, that we tock not the tythe of the time a Dutchman doth in the filling his belly; to be hort, we fell again to drinking; and now to gratifie me for my company, the fair Barbarian Princes would needs take upon her to ing alo; this Princes you mut know was the principal and mot beloved Concubine of this Gypie King, and had been o to three before him, one whereof was o everely (flaugg'd at the Tumbler) whipt at the Carts-are for everal mi-demeaners, â€¢ hat he dyed thereof, the other was (nub'd) hang'd, and the lat (marrinated) tranported.

She was not o old but that her Prince acknowledg'd her the mot buckom thing he ever aw, and â€¢ ndeed by her countenance I could gues no les; but o foul and â€¢ athome by reaon of her Raggs and Hellih paint, that he mut have a tronger tomack than I, that hath a mind to wop his Jockum with her: the ong he ung was this.

div.head: 3. Canting Song.
Being a Wenches complaint for, and praie of her lusty Rogue, who rambled the Country with her.

lg.l: NOw my Kinchin Cove is gone,
By the Rum pad maunded none,
In quarrons both for tamps and bone
Like my Clapperdogeon.
Dimber damber fare thee well
Palliards all thou didt excel,
And thy Jocky bore the bell,
Glymmer on it never fell.
Thou the Cramprings ne're didt cowre
Harmans had on thee no power,
Harmanbecks did never toure
For thee, though Drawers till had loure.
Duds and cheats thou oft hat won
Yet the Cuffin-quire couldt hun
And thy Deuavile didt run,
Ele the chates had thee undone.
Cank and Dommerar thou couldt play
Or Rum-Maunder in one day,
And like an Abram-Cove couldt pray
Yet pas with Jybes well jerk'd away.
When the Darkmans have been wet
Thou the Crackmans down didt beat
For Glymmar whilt a quacking cheat,
Or Tib o'th' Buttery was our meat.
Red hanks then I could not lack,
Ruff-peck till hung at my back,
Grannam ever fill'd my ack,
With lap and poplars held I tack.
To thy Bughar and thy skew,
Filch and Jybes I bid adieu,
Though thy Togeman was not new,
Yet the Ruffler in't was true.
NOw my little Rogue is gone,
By the High-way begs there none,
In body both for length and bone,
Like my Clapperdogeon.
Pretty Racal fare thee well,
Born beggars all thou do't excel,
Thy Sweep-takes till hall bare the Bell,
No Fire-hip yet aboard it fell.
Bolts my Bully ne'r â€¢ did wear
Never thou the tocks didt fear,
For thee no Contable did wear,
For thou hadt Mony and to pare.
Cloaths by tealth thou oft hat got,
Yet the Jutice took thee not,
But through the Country thou didt trot,
The Gallows ele had been thy lot.
Dumb and Madman thou couldt play,
Or a drivling Fool all day,
And like a poor man thou couldt pray.
Yet tap'd with Paes eal'd away.
When the Evening hath been wet,
For Fire the Hedges down didt bear.
Me then with toln Duck didt treat,
Or ele a fat Gooe was our meat
Mallards then I could not lack,
Bacon hung always at my back,
Nor Corn wanted in my ack,
With good Milk pottage I held tack.
To thy Dog and Dih adieu
Thy Staff and pas I ne're mut view,
Though thy Cloak was far from new,
In it my Rogue to me was true.

div.p: And now Prince Prig could forbear no longer, but that he mut put in for a Continuer of this harmony; when he began to ing, he fix'd his eyes tedfatly on this fair, foul, buckome, loathome, courtly ragged Mitres of his, by which I guet the lines might concern her; and o they proved by the equel.

div.head: 4. Canting Song.
The Rogues delight in praie of his Stroling Mort.

lg.l: DOxy oh! Thy Glaziers hine
As Glymmar by the Salomon,
No Gentry Mort hath prats like thine
No Cove e're wap'd with uch a one.
White thy fambles, red thy gan,
And thy quartons dainty is,
Couch a hoghead with me than,
In the Darkmans clip and kis.
What though I no Togeman wear,
Nor Commiion, Mih, or late,
Store of trummel wee'l have here.
And i'th' Skipper lib in tate.
Wapping thou I know dot love,
Ele the Ruffin cly thee Mort,
From thy tampers then remove
Thy Drawers and let's prig in port.
When the Lightmans up do's call
Margery Prater from her net,
And her Cackling cheats with all
In a Boozing-Ken wee'l feat.
There if Lour we want I'l mill
A Gage or nip for thee a bung,
Rum booz thou halt booz thy fill
And crah a Grunting cheat that's young.
Bing awat to Rome-vile then
O my dimber wapping Dell,
Wee'l heave a booth and dock agen
Then trining cape and all is well.
MY honey Chuck, byth' Mas I wear,
Thine eyes do hine than fire more clear,
No ilken Girl hath thighs like thine,
No Doe was ever buck'd like mine.
Thy hand is white and red thy lip,
Thy dainty body I will clip,
Let's down to leep our elves then lay,
Hug in the dark and kis and play.
What though I no cloak do wear
And neither Shirt or Sheet do bear,
Yet traw wee'l have enough that's weet
And tumble when i'th' Barn we meet.
What thy Grandam lov'd do't thou,
The Devil take thee ele I vow.
Off then with thy tockings and hooes
And let us do what others ue.
When the morning up hall call
From her net the Hen and all
Her tender Broodlings thou and I,
Will to the Ale-Houe wiftly fly.
If we can't our reck'ning pay
Somthing I'l filch and teal away,
Drink off thy liquor then thy fill,
Some uckling Pig for thee I'l kill.
7. Therefore to London let us hie
O thou my weet bewitching eye,
There wee'l rob and kis pell-mell,
Ecaping Tyburn all is well.

div.p: Latly, The mot ill-hapen ill-look'd Rogue in the whole Company, ung as followeth.

div.head: 5. Canting Song.
Sung commonly at their general Randezvous, or the night before they divided themelves into Tribes or Parties, to trol the Country.

lg.l: BIng out been Morts and tour and tour,
Bing out been Morts and tour,
For all your duds are bing'd awat
The been Cove hath the lour.
I met a Dell, I view'd her well,
She was benhip to my watch,
So he and I did tall and cloy
Whatever we could catch.
This Doxy Dell can cut been whids,
And wap well for a win,
And prig and cloy o benhiply
All the Deueavile within.
The boyl was up we had good luck
As well in frot as now,
When they did eek then did we creep
And plant in Ruffmans low.
To troling Ken the Mort bings then
To fetch lour for her cheats,
Duds and Ruffpeck romboil'd by Harmanbeck
And won by Maunders feats.
You Maunders all tow what you tall
To Rum-coves what o quire,
And wapping Dell that niggles well
And takes lour for her hire.
And Jybe well jerk'd tick rome confeck
For back by Glimmar to maund
To mill each Ken let Cove bing then
Through Ruffmans Jauge or laund.
Till Cramprings quire-tip Cove his hire
And Quire Ken do them Catch
A Canniken will quire Cuffin,
So quire to been Coves watch.
Been Darkmans then booz Mort and Ken,
The been Coves bing awat
On Chats to trine by Rum-Coves dine,
For his long lib at lat.
Bing out been Morts and tour
Bing out of the Rome vile fine,
And tour the Cove that cloyd your duds
Upon the Chats to trine.
GO forth brave Girls look out, look out,
Look out I ay good Maids,
For all your cloaths are toln I doubt,
And har'd among the Blades.
I met a Drab I lik'd her well,
With whom I us'd to dally,
What goods we tole we traight did ell,
And then abroad did ally.
This bouncing Trull can finely talk,
She will do for a penny,
Through every Town which he doth walk
Fails not to filch from any.
The houe being rais'd aide we tep
And through the mire did wade
The Hue and Cry to hun we crept
In Hedges where we laid.
To the Brokers then my Hedg-bird flies,
For goods he brings good coin,
Which though the Contable after hies
Our tricks away purloin.
You Maunding Rogues beware how you
Do teal, for earch is made,
And have a care you damned whore,
Who will not do till paid.
A Licence got with forged eal
To beg (as if undone
By fire) to break each houe and teal
Ore hedg and ditch then run,
Till hackles oundly pay us home,
And to the Gaol compell us,
Hells plague the Jutice heart conume,
So cruel to good fellows.
Sweet Wench, Ale-houe and Beer good night,
The honet Rogues departed,
To hanging by the Jutice pight
To his long home he's carted.
Away weet Ducks with greedy eyes
From London walk up Holborn
Purue him tole your Cloaths; he flyes
With hempen wings to Tyburn.

div.p: It now grew very late, which with the great quantity of drink made mot of the company betake themelves to leep, dropping one after another, leaving none at lat but my former acquaintance and my elf together, a thing I all along deired.

Being alone, prythee, aid I, give me a reaon why thou dot o degenerate from thy Birth and Education as to follow o lazy and o damn'd a coure of life, than which their is nothing wore under the Cope of Heaven: have patience, aid he, and I will endeavour your atisfaction in every thing that concerned me ince my leaving the place of my nativity to this time, and that in this hort relation.

div.head: An account of the notable and notorious life of a late and eminent King of the Gypies, yet living, taken verbatim as he himelf related it.
div.p: I Need not acquaint you, aid he, with the paages of my life while I was a School-boy at Exceter, ince I know they are not unknown to you; I hall therefore inform you when I came to London to be an Apprentice, I preently imagined I hould not erve my time, that trict coure of life being o diagreable to my looe inclinations, and therefore from the firt week I never intended to mind my trade, although you know it was as credible and reputable as mot in the whole City.

I was naturally very lazy and lothful, and ever hated any thing that was Gentile, I have often roe from dinner to make an end thereof with thoe who beg'd at the door, and took as much delight therein as others itting at Noble-mens Tables; o lovenly, that though my Mater bruh'd my coat for <> every day, yet he could not beat the loving â€¢â€¢â€¢ on't, nor that roguery, which being bred in the <> will never out of the fleh; when he aw nothing would reduce me to oberve the rules of de
â€¢ ency and civility, he took an occaion knocking late at his door to hut me out, and from thence I reolv'd never to return to him again.

All the day time I rambled up and down the out parts of the City, and being almot famih'd I ro â€¢ olv'd rather to beg than tarve, which I did o artificially, that I got victuals enough every where; at night I found convenient bulks to lie on, it being then Mid-ummer, I lay not in that manner in fear â€¢ at thing cold.

I liv'd after this manner for a Month, and began to be much in love with my begging Profeion, and had continued it had I not accidentally fallen into the acquaintance of a notable lazy companion like my elf, whom I found unning himelf in Lincolnin-fields. With little difficulty and les time we became intimately acquainted, and thereupon worn brothers. We beg'd together, lay together and louz'd together, and were ineparable; it was he that taught me firt to teal, and by his means firt oundly whipt. For it was our cutome in the cloe of the Evening, to beg at doors, which if we found open, we boldly enter'd, and if we epied none in the way, what was next at hand we rub'd off with; if we aw any, we traightwaies applyed our elves to our whining notes and pitiful looks, begging for Gods ake to betow their charity on two Orphan Twins, who were both troubled with the Falling-icknes: ome were o pittiful and credulous as to give their Alms, but the mot (eeing us turdy and luty young Lads) fright'ned us away with the threats of the whiping Pot, but thee menaces did not care us from our continual filching notwithtanding. But the Pitcher goes not o often to the Well but that it comes home broken at lat. For one night watching at a door for an opportunity, eeing the coat clear I whipt up tairs, and happily the firt thing my hands fatned on, was a Hair-Chamlet Cloak; overjoy'd with the goodnes of the prize and minding not the ditance of the tairs from me, I came ooner to the Stair head than I was aware of, and fell to the bottom of the tairs, making a noie like a Devil in a Drum: this unexpected misfortune did put my experienc'd Tutor and Comrade to the run, and with all o alarm'd the houe, that there was no hole left for me to creep out at.

Search being made, I was found with my Cloak lying at the tair foot, not able to tir; but my merciles foes did oon put life in me by by boxing and kicking me one to another; they had done me a kindnes had they kick'd me out into the treet; but hold there, after all this mi-uage I was carried before a Jutice, who preently ent me to Newgate.

Seions, as good luck would have it, was at hand, otherwie, I know not how I hould have lived a fortnight with a penny a day in Bread and Water: Being brought to the old Baily, I had my Tryal, and received entence of evere whipping, which was accordingly performed, and return'd to Newgate to lie there till I had paid my fees; which was o long (having no friend to help me) that I there became intimately acquainted with the whole Gang of ROGUES, ditinguihed by Files, Lifts, Gilts, Budges, Runners, Heavers, &c. Who eeing how forward I was to be one of them, promied me, if ever we met abroad, they would intruct me in a trade hould bring me in a livelyhood, which I found would have put me out of one, had I longer followed their intructions.

I now depair'd of coming out, and whilt I thought o, my little Tutor ent a youngter to me (for he durt not come himelf, being too well known by the Keepers) who brought me more Money than would dicharge my Fees, with directions where I hould find him.

I intantly addret my elf to the Mater-Keeper, telling him that I had a friend had ent me ome money and therefore I deired to know what I was indebted and I would pay it, provided I might be dicharged; he readily told me, and now we were poet with one and the ame joy, that he
was freed from me, and I from him.

I was no ooner out, but I fell a running, as if I intended to run out of my wits, and never topt till I came to my Comrade: you may imagine there was no mall joy at meeting, and to wah down orrow, we concluded to booz it rumly.

Over our Ale he recounted me all his adventures ince my urprizal, and how uccesful he was in them all; then taking me by the hand, aid, come boy ne'r be diheartned for one ill bargain I'l put thee in a way which hall recompence thy whipping.

Night approaching we did everal exploits and came off well, the next day and night we continued them with the like ucces, and now we had got Money enough to new cloath our elves, which we did, having firt unhusk'd.

What I had promied me in New-gate, I had perform'd abroad, for meeting with one of my fellow Collegiats, he was over-joy'd to ee me, and epecially at uch a time when he could erve me; for, aid he, I am now going to meet with ome according to appointment, who will make s All, he might have added, Be Hanged.

Taking my Comrade I went with him, where we found a jolly company drinking after a trange rate to their good ucces that night; in a little time I undertood their meaning; for, aid one, let us ceae from this exceive drinking, you know what a weighty buines we are to go about, no les than fifteen hundred pound in ready Mony, beides Plate and Jewells: hereupon they were advied, and fell immediately to plotting and rightly contriving the buines.

It was agreed upon, that I and my Comrade hould be the Forelorne-hope, or more properly the
Perdues; for our charge was to get into this houe deigned to be rob'd, and abcond our elves in ome obcure place and o at uch an hour let in our Maters.

At firt I knew not what to make of it, judging it o hazardous, that I trembled when I did but think thereon; my Comrade perceiving how timorous I was, hook me by the hand, bidding me be of good courage, he would warrant all well. Hereupon I reolv'd on the exploit and away we went together.

A little before night my Comrade had lodg'd himelf, but I knew not where, and being loath to be behind hand with him, I got underneath the tairs in a hole decending into the Collar, o convenient, as if it had been made for my purpoe. There was a Clock in the houe, which I watchfully told and oberved, and when it truck twelve (which was the fatal hour appointed) out I got and met full-but with my Comrade, who was as diligent as my elf to let them in, they being ready without, enter'd and leaving us two Sentinels at Door, they mounted the Stairs, and in a trice had ecured all that were in the houe by Gagging and binding them; jut as they were within ken of their booty; the Gentleman of the houe (who had been at play and had quarrell'd with ome Gentlemen,) came home attended by everal Gentlemen, and guarded with a Contable and trong watch, but wondred to ee two young Sentinels at his door; as oon as we aw him we betook our elves to our heels, having no time left to acquaint the ret with the preent danger; the Contable eeing us run, let looe a couple of his Nighthounds, and tay'd our farther progres; in the mean time the Gentleman enter'd his houe; they
within finding themelves dicovered, drew, and attempted to cut their paage through; but the Contable hearing a great noie with clahing of words, ecuring me and my comrade, preently ran to their aitance; and to be hort ecured them all, with whom we were ent to bear them Company in the Counter that night: in the morning being carried before the Jutice, there was matter of fact, and proof enough to end us to Newgate; being tryed at Seions, we were all found guilty of Burglary and accordingly received entence of Death, which was executed accordingly, onely I and my Comrade being very young, had the benefit of Tranportation.

Seven years in our exile, we did what our Maters commanded us and our time being expired, we reolv'd to return for England, but death put an end to my Comrades Voyage, however I alter'd not my reolution, but ail'd for England, where in everal places I made trials to live honetly, but could not, For what is bred in the bone will never out of the fleh.

Now knowing that if ever I was taken again on any Fellonious account, I hould auredly be hang'd; and being o lazy that I hated the thought of working, I reolved to follow the life of a troling Gypie, into which Society I was joyfully received: I grew o good a proficient in the myteries of this trade, that with a joint conent I was choen at a olemn meeting, their Prince or King; and for thee reaons; Firt, becaue I was young and well proportion'd; Secondly, becaue I was lutier and tronger than the ret; And Latly, becaue I had more than common learning, and more wit than they had, put them altogether.

Now the reaons inducing me to follow this life,
were thee; Firt, a lazy dipoition; Secondly, a lecherous inclination; And Latly, profit. As to the firt, we do nothing for a livelyhood but walk up and down in Summer time, which is rather a patime than pain; and in Winter, retire to uch quarters as are uitable to the eaon, not tirring thence till pring. As to the econd, our females are all in common among us, and though their skins be dicolour'd, they have as good fleh as can be coveted by an youthful appetite. And latly, as to profit; It is incredible to think how much we get by Fortune-telling, among the ignorant, the poor wenches being ready to pawn their Petticoats to procure us money, to tell them how fruitful they hall be, when Married; or whether William or Thomas loveth them or not: But the greatet profit we reap is from our By-blows, thee Children our Morts carry at their backs are all of them Batards, and mot of them none of their own begetting; for when young Gentlewomen have trod awry, and the Fathers are not to be digraced, the Bantlings for a good round um are ent to us to be nured, where they are never like to come to the knowledge of their true Parents. Here he made an end, if you hall approve of what is already written, I wil hortly inlarge my elf on this ubject.

lg.head: Beggars Holiday.
lg.l: CAt our Nabs and Cares away,
This is beggars Holiday,
In the world look out and ee,
Where's o happy a King as he?
At the Crowning of our King,
Thus we ever dance and ing.
Where's the Nation lives o free,
And o merry as do we?
Be it peace, or be it War,
Here at liberty we are;
Hang all Harmanbecks, we cry,
And the Cuffinquiers too by.
We enjoy our eae and ret,
To the fields we are not pret.
When the Subidy's increat,
We are not a penny ceat;
Nor are we call'd into the Town,
To be troubled with a Gown;
Nor will any go to Law
With a Beggar for a traw.
All which happines he brags,
He doth owe unto his rags.

div.head: AN ALPHABETICAL Canting Vocabulary. Canting before the Englih.

row.cell: The Mort hath tipt the Bube to the Cully.

cell.hi: The wench hath clapt the Fellow.
An Instrument to open a door.

row.cell: As bite the Cully, that is, pu â€¢ the Cheat on uch a Fellow. Or the Cove was bit, The Man was cheated.

cell.hi: One that teals Cloaks or ought ele, lipping into an houe in the dark

row.cell: As the Cully is bruh'd or rub'd, that is, He is march'd off, or broke.

cell.hi: The one jotles you up whilt the other picks your pocket.
O. Q. P. on the Floar or Stairs

row.cell: Blot the Skrip and jark it.

cell.hi: To be engaged or bound for any body.
To enter or go into an houe,

row.cell: As Dup the Ken, Enter the Houe, Dup the Boozing-Ken, and booz a gage; go into the Ale-houe and drink a pot.
As for example, Tip me my Earnet, Give me my Share or Divident.
As Flick me ome Pannam and Cah; Cut me ome Bread and Cheee

cell.hi: A Staff with an hole in the end thereof, in which upon occaion, your Rogues will faten an hook, to pull things cunningly from an Hedge, or through a Caement.

row.cell: As the Prancer drew the Quire Cove at the Cropping of the Rotan through the Rum pads of the Rum vile, and was flog'd by the Nubbing-Cove. That is, The Rogue was drag'd at <> Carts-are, through the chief treets of London, and was oundly whipt by the Hangman.
As tip me a gage of Fogus, Give me a pipe of Tobacco.
As Fib the Coves quarrons in the rum â€¢ ad for the lour in his burg. Beat the Man on the high-way for the money in his pure.
As Fence your Flag, Spend your Groat,
The whipper of Bridewell, or any other that whips people commonly called at Dublin in Ireland Bellores.

cell.hi: One that creeps in at caements, or unrips glas windows to filch and teal.

Where note that ome of them are o excellent at it, that they are furnihed with all orts of Gilts or Keys, f â€¢ o â€¢ n a Church door to the mallet Cabinet, and almot at firt ight will dexterouly open any door, t â€¢ unk, chet, or any lock whatever.

row.cell: As give him a rum nitch, or â€¢â€¢â€¢ ichel the Gigg, that is, Fillip him on the Noe.
As Heave a Booth, To rob an houe
You Darkman-budge, will you fence your hog with me, at the next Boozing Ken. That is, d'ye hear you Houe-creeper, will you pend your hilling with me, at the next Alehoue.

cell.hi: A fellow that walketh the treets, and takes all advantages to pick up the younger ort of people, whom with lies and many fair promies he inticeth on board a hip and tranports them into forreign plantations.
Gentile Beggars, Such as will not accept of Victuals, but money or cloaths, and thee beg under the pretence of being decay'd Gentlemen, Trademen, or uch who have been burn'd out or hipwrack'd
To take, or cheat with the Dice, that is, by certainly ecuring one chance.
One whoe Father is a born Beggar
Are all or â€¢ t of Thieves

row.cell: As Pi â€¢ e on the been,

cell.hi: Run for it as fat as you can.

row.cell: Plant your whids, and tow them,

cell.hi: Be careful what you ay or peak

row.cell: As track the Dancers and pikes with the Peeper, Go up the tairs and trip off with the Looking-glas.
As Rum hopper, tip us preently a Bouning cheat of Rum gutlers; Drawer fill us preently a bottle of the best Canary.

As the Ruffin nap the Cuffin-quier, and let the Harmanbeck trine with his Kinchins about his Colquarron; That is, Let the Devil take the Justice, and let the Contable hang with his children about his neck.

cell.hi: The better ort of Highway men.
Such who onely beg at Coaches.
One that lies underneath a bed, to watch an opportunity to rob the houe.
One that filcheth Commodities out of a Shop, under the pretence of cheapning or buying them of the Shop-keeper.

row.cell: As the Cully Stams fleh rumly; He Cants very well

cell.hi: A Brokers hop, or an houe that will recive toln goods.

row.cell: Stow your Whids and plant 'em, for the Cove of the Ken can cant 'em,

cell.hi: Have a care what you ay, the Man of the Houe understands you.

row.cell: As the Cully did freely blot the Skrip, and o tipt me forty Hogs; that is, One enter'd into bond with me for forty hillings.
Tip the cole to Adam Tiler

cell.hi: Give your pick-pocket money preently to your running Comrade.

row.cell: As five Rum padders are rub'd in the darkmans out of the Whit, and are pik'd into the Deueavile: Five Highway men in the night broke Newgate, and are gone into the Country.
As for example, The Cull is pik'd with the Witcher bubber; The Rogue is March'd off with the Silver Bowl.

As tout through the Wicket, and ee where a Cully pikes with his Gentry Mort, whoe Muns are the rummet I ever touted before: Look through the Caement, and ee where the man walks with a Gentlewoman, whoe face is the fairet I have ever een.

div.head: AN ALPHABETICAL Canting Dictionary. Englih before the Canting.

row.cell: An Intrument to break a door
Be careful of what you ay
Bar of an Alehoue or Tavern.
Enter or go into an houe
Fellows that pick up people for tranportation commonly called Spirits
Fop, or one that may eaily be wrought upon
One that lips into an houe in the dark and teals what he can lay hands on
One that creeps in at Caements and lets in others to rob the houe
One that filcheth commodities out of a hop under the pretence of Cheapning or Buying
One that lieth underneath a bed, or in ome other covert place to watch an opportunity to rob the houe
One whoe father is born a Begger
O Q P on the tairs

cell.hi: Blow off on the Ground â€¢ ll

div.p: Our Canting Alphabet will not extend a Letter farther then T, as far as I can find out; not knowing any Canting word beginning with , X, Y, Z, although I have made a trict inquiry from ome of the mot notorious Profeors hereof: I have conulted likewie what is printed on this ubject, and have lighted no help I could gather from thence, which indeed is very little; the greatet aitance I had in this dicovery, was from Newgate; which with much difficulty I crew'd out of the ullen Rogues, who would not peak a word till I had uppled their tongues with the oil of Barley, or rather thaw'd their obtinate ilence with the heat of trong Liquors.

From thee I undertood, that the Mode of Canting alter'd very often, and that they were forced to change frequently thoe material words which chiefly dicovered their myterious practices and
Villanies, leat growing too common their own words hould betray them.

Here in this Vocabulary or little Canting Dictionary, You have all or mot of the old words which are till in ue, and a many new never pubblihed in print, and but very lately minted, uch too which have paed the approbation of the Critical Canter. If I eem deficient in the quantity of words, let ome ele upply my defects, having collected words ufficiently enough for one, if you will have more, take the pains which I have done to be upplyed, and in the mean time be content with what is gathered to your hands.

div.head: A Character or Decription of the Roguih Profeors of that myterious and Diabolical Gibberih called Canting.
div.p: UNdoubtedly there were Rogues and Villains before ever this peech was invented, for whilt the world was in wadling cloaths, we read of men that acted very horrid and vile pranks, uch as for their infamy are o regitred, as never to be forgotten whilt the world indures; and ince evil example is more prevalent then good Precept, who knows but the wicked eeds of their lewd actions have been tranimitted to poterity, by which means we have uch an infinite increae of all manner of Villany, the Actors whereof I verily believe are much more notorious then heretofore, howing much more ingenuity in their Roguery than in â€¢ imes pat.
I hall begin to peak of the firt I have read of, which were the Founders or firt publick Profeors of Canting, and I find their names male, thus recorded.
Of all which according to the bet light I have received, I hall endeavour to give you an account; the firt that falls in my way, is

div.head: The pright Man.
div.p:
THis was a name antiently ued for the Principal of this Stroling, Maunding and Prigging Crew, and he was elective; when this Upright man dyed (which was eldome otherwie then on the Gallows,) then all of this cured Fraternity meant an appointed place, and their choe the lutiet toutet Rogue in the whole pack, to be their chief Leader, whom they called Upright man; and as the Women loved him for his great limbs, whoe bodies mut be at his devotion when ever he
uncontroulably, o the Men had him in particular eteem, in that he was more a Rogue than any, and could when he ate as Preident of their Courel, in great extremity, direct them bet how to ecure themelves from Jutices, Contables, and other Officers; and find out, and contrive notorious plots how they might ab â€¢ e the Country by filching and tealing, to the further continuance of their loathome Betiality; This fellow carries a hor â€¢ Truncheon in his hand, which he calls his Filchman; whatoever is gotten by the whole Society he hares in it.

This Upright man hall ometimes have in company with him, young and old, males and females, to the number of forty and upwards, and for the eae of ome of the women and children, hall have an As or two, or ome poor Jade which hall carry a pair of Panniers for the women as they grow weary by travail to put their children in them, which mell more rank then tale fih in Summer time coming from Yarmouth to Norwich in a pair of Doers.

Some of the Gang are very â€¢ dly clad with bells, and long ticks with ribbonds hanging at the end â€¢ angling, with many other mad contrived toyes, meerly to draw the Country people about them wherever they came, and by pretending to tell For
â€¢ unes get ome mony of the foolih, by way of gift, and ome by pic â€¢ ing of pockets.

To be ure wherever they came, the poultry and ucking pigs went to wrack, neither did Lambs, Sheep, and Calves ecape their hands, if they had any convenience to effect their purpoe; all which they handle more everely than a Malefactor having broke Prion and retaken by the Keeper of Newgate.

If a Gooe come among hem, they have a trick to make him o wife, as never to be taken for a Gooe again. Having eized the Prey, they leave the bloody part to be acted by their Morts or Women; who are o accutomed to natines, that when they have dret their Geee and Hens as well as poibly they can, you may then wear thoe Birds are foul. The end of ome large Heath or Fir-buh, Common under ome Covert, as an Hedge or o forth is their Rendezvouz, where having upt after their fahion, a conultation is had how to lie that night, if in the height in the fields or in Hay time under an Hay-cock ditributing themelves every one with his Mort as he thinks mot convenient; if it be at the latter end of ummer, to avoid cold dews and now and then rain, they then apply themelves to ome outlying Barn, and if the owner hould dicover them he is fearful of moleting them, let they do him a greater michief, by making his traw-thatcht Manion too hot to hold him: and now by the way give me leave to tell you a Notable tory, very pertinent to this purpoe.

A Crew of Gypies continuing for ome time about one Town in Gloceterhire, but divided in the day, though united in the night, all congregated to one appointed place, which was a convenient Barn for their purpoe, about an half mile from this Town: Hither they reorted night after night, and in the morning till early got up and eparated themelves, looking the Barnes door by the ame art they unlock'd it.

This Gentlemans Threhers wonder'd till when they came to ee the heafs of Corn o diorder'd and flung here and there, and in the tranget confuion imaginable; at firt they upected this diorder
hapned by their own negligence or forgetfulnes, but finding it o for a continued time; they reolved to acquaint their Mater with what they had oberved. The Mater being informed of what had hapned, would not believe his ervants till he had experimented the truth thereof himelf; and thereupon goes to his Barn with his two ervants, and there caued them to place before his eyes every heaf in good order, and o locking the door went home; the next morning he calls up his Threhers and away he went to the Barn, and there found the heafs tumbled and catter'd up and down, as his men had told him; he very much wonder'd how this hould be done, and his Barn door locked; however, he was reolved to try once more, and o caued the heafs to be placed in order as formerly, and as formerly he found them the fecond time o diorder'd, any, the third and fourth time; this omwhat tartled him, and coming home, concluded ome evil pirit owed him a pight, in thus diordering and poiling his Corn: The Threhers hearing their Maters judgment of this accident, on the morrow following, intead of going to threh, their Mater coming down from his chamber, finds his men gazing one upon the other in his Hall, whereas he thought they were at the Barn, and demanding the reaon hereof; they freely told him, that ince they undertood from his own Mouth that he believed the Devil haunted the Barn, the Devil hould take the Barn ere they would be o mad to bear him Company; The Gentleman miled at their ridiculous fears; and to depoe them utterly of any uch belief, produced everal good arguments, that it could not be, and o prevalent they were, as to perwade them to go to the Barn, with this provio, he would go with
them and tay there an hour, agreed it was and away they went, where as before they found all things in the like diorder, this made the poor fellows cratch the head, not knowing what was bet to be done; at length the Mater incouraging them, to work they went the Mater tanding by his full hour and o went home; he was carce got within the doors but his men at his heels, and o out of breath that they gaped for air to keep them alive, like a fih out of his proper Element.

The Gentleman eeing them in this trange poture began to be in as much amazement as they were; the good Gentlewoman his Wife coming out accidentally, and eeing the Husband and his two men in this gaping taring poture, knew not what to think, but concluded them mad or poet by ome foul fiend, till he asked one of them what he made there; Why forooth (quoth he) you would not believe our Barn was haunted, but now I will wear it, for if ever any body aw the Devil I am ure we did, I was never cared o in my life with a broad face, a crooked noe and a pair of Goggle eyes. It eems as oon as their Mater was gone, a very large dark gray Owle that ate upon a Beam jut over againt them, was upon the merry pin, or had a mind to be mer â€¢ ily dipoed, ell a hooting and hollowing after a very extravagant rate, ometimes hiing; ometimes napping, and (I know not what joyful crochet got into his noddle) then fell to a loud hooping; the men that before threht in fear, were now cared out of their wits, 'twas enough for them they aw a blackih thing with a broad glouting Countenance, itting on a Beam, hooting at them, which made them thus betake themelves to their heels, each of them bidding the Devil take the hindmot.

The report of thee fellows alarm'd the Town, poeing many with a belief that this might be a truth as to the haunting the Barn. A bold fellow in the Town, and one that had been a Trumpeter, makes his addres to the owner of the Barn, deiring his leave to lie in the Barn one night; it was granted by the Gentleman with thanks; and the Trumpeter went that very night to the Barn with his Trumpet, and locking the Barn to him, placed himelf in a corner thereof convenient for his obervation.

About the uual time of thee Gypies repairing to the Barn, which was omewhat late, they came and enter'd the Barn, every one endeavouring to ettle himelf as well as he could; the Trumpeter eeing this, reolv'd to try whether they were Devils or no by their dilike to Muick, and thereupon ounded his Trumpet, at the ound whereof, out ran the Gypies as the Devil had drove them, and the Trumpeter after ounding, the people there about ran out to know what was the matter that a Trumpet hould be ounded at that time of night; the Trumpeter informed them that he had conjured the Devils out of the Barn they had o haunted, and that they might now dipoe of them as they pleaed, whereupon they eized as many as they could and ecuring them till next morning, by a Jutice they were order'd to be whipt out of Town: thus with my tory I have ended my dicoure concerning an prightman; the next we are to take cognizance of, is

div.head: A Ruffler.
div.p: A Ruffler ever goes under the pretence of a maimed Soldier, if he troles the Country, he lets not a Gentlemans houe ecape, having a Catalogue of them all along as he goeth for his more convenient calling upon them, he carrieth in his pocket (for the help of his memory) a Lit of the old Commanders in the late Civil Wars which were noted Royalits, neither is he ignorant of ome of their brave actions; he ingles out the Heirs of uch deceaed Commanders, and then tells them a formal tory, that they had the honor to erve under the Command of their worthy Father in uch a Regiment, at uch a fight, as Naeby, Edghill, Newberry, Marton-Moor, &c. that in that ervice he was lamed, that he hath ince uffered all the misfortunes of an old Cavalier, and that being unable to work, he is now forced to beg becaue he corns to teal; and thus he goeth from one to another, having a good tongue in his head, and his tale at his fingers ends: but by the way, if he meets Country people coming late from Market, or any other feaable booty, he will not tick to eie it, though he be hanged for his pains; and thus the Ruffler is metamorphoed into a Low-Pad.

If his reidence be in the City, then his uual tands are in Lincolns-Inn-Fields or Covent Garden, where he corns to beg of any under a peron of quality, and then nimbly hops or tumps to a Coach ide, beeeching their Honors to commierate the pittiful condition of a great ufferer for his
Majety, and hath the impudence in a commanding way to crave an Alms, if he is denied, he hakes the head and crys, 'Tis a ad thing that an old cripled Cavalier hould be uffer'd to beg for a Maintenance, and a young Cavalier that never heard the whitle of a bullet hould ride in his Coach.

If he eeth a Gentleman coming that is his contant cutomer, he very civilly vaileth his bonnet, without asking a Farthing, and this tops my Gentleman more forceably than all the important prayers of a wide mouthed clamorous mendicant; having received his boon, he pronounceth as many bleings as will tand between Temple-Bar and Wetminster; for the cunning Rogue knoweth this to be the way to incourage him the more to a contribution hereafter.

I have been credibly informed that thee Covent-Garden Rufflers have their Quarter Cutomers, and will never call on their Benefactors till their full time of payment be expired, and then wherever they meet them, they will not let them be quiet till they have dicharged that which by cutome they claim as a due debt: thee Rogues get a great deal of money, and ome of them pend it as freely, as for example, I knew a Gentleman a good Benefactor to one of thee Rufflers who had been at Speerings Ordinary, and having lot all his money, going home one Saturday in the Evening, was accoted by his Pentioner, a ubtle Ruffler, who perceiving his Maters countenance omwhat cloudy, ask'd him boldly what was the matter with him; the Gentleman lighting his quetion, bid him be gone for a aucy fellow; nay, be not angry, quoth the Ruffler, you have been at play I will lay my life on't and lot your Money that you are o pettih; what then, aid the Gentleman? What then, quoth the
Ruffler, why never trouble your elf, I will lend you fifty pieces, if you will come and dine with me to morrow.

This trangely urprized the Gentleman, who to try the truth of what he heard, promis'd him, he would dine with him: according to the time and place appointed by the Ruffler, the Gentleman came; the houe was very poor to outward view, but within very neat and handome, a cloath was pread, but could not perceive the leat park of fire whereby any meat could be dreed; whilt he was muing to himelf on the entertainment he was like to have, in came the Wife with a large Sir-Loyn of Beef, the Son with two Stubble Geee in a dih, the Daughter with a tately Turky, and a Servant Maid with a very large Tart; look you Sir, aid the Ruffler, this is all the cheat you are like to have, wherefore fall to; the Gentleman had much a doe, to perwade the Father, the Daughter hould it down, but with much importunity it was granted: I heard him ay, though his appetite was as keen as a Turkih Scymiter, yet he forgot to eat, his mind running on other fleh, uch as he proteted exceeded, in his opinion, all that he had ever een before, uch was this Maidens beauty, not et off with any artificial imbellihments, but naturally hining in its own Orb; and leat her peron hould be depied, by reaon of the baenes of her Fathers profeion, he was Gentilely clad, but better adorn'd within with the mot approved principles of a good education, befitting o good a Genius. Wine both French and Spanih was not wanting; and Dinner being ended, to be as good as his word or better, the Ruffler lent the Gentleman fifty Guynnyes, on this condition, he would not divulge the kindnes received.
There is a tory omwhat like this of the blind Beggar of Bednall-Green, but how true I cannot tell, but this relation carrieth o much of truth in it, that thereon I will pawn my reputation.

div.head: Of Anglers.
div.p: ANglers are o called, becaue they have a Rod or Stick with an Iron hook at the end of it, with which they Angle in the night at Windows or any other place in which they cannot convey their hand, where all is fih to them that comes to net; in the day time they beg from houe to houe to py bet where to plant their deigns, which at night they put in execution; I hall peak more of this Angler when I come to Dicoure of the Runner.

div.head: Of Rogues.
div.p: THe very name of Rogue denotes the nature; it is a general title, and appertains to all uch who are of diolute lives and converations; uch who corning both the Laws of God and man, care not what they act or perpetrate, o they may add to the increae of their enuality and beatly manner of living. Any criminal whoe actions are cognizable by the Law may come under the denomination of a Rogue, as Gilts, Shoplifts, Files, Bulkers, Runners, Padders, Booth-heavers, Vouchers and the like.

All thee have their particular Societies, and Confederacies, and they are o linked together that they eldome eperate till they hang together. If one be in Prion the ret relieve him, wherefore they eldome dicover one another, for they are worn, if one is taken not to betray the ret; and this Oath they keep inviolably, though all others they break. They have their everal Wenches, and everal places of meeting, where whatoever they unlawfully obtain they pend, and whatoever they pend is to atisfie their unatisfied lut; wallowing in all manner of debauchery, converting the night into day and the day into night, damning and inking being four parts in five their dicoure; and the ret of their patime, drinking and whoring. Their company is dangerous, their lives detetable, and their ends mierable.

div.head: VVild Rogues.
div.p: THis term or appellation is obolete, and now a days not in ue. Wild Rogues were formerly uch who were begotten by very Rogues, uch who had been burnt in the hand or houlder, or been whipt at the Carts are, whoe Mothers had been frequent in Bride-well, and oftner in Newgate: thee in their wadling clouts are marked for Villains; and are then taught all manner of Roguery as other children are taught to read.

Firt, To go into Churches or great Crowds and to nim golden buttons off mens Cloaks, and being very little are how'd how to creep into Cellar-Windows, or other mall entrances, and in the night to convey out thereat whatever they can find, to the thieyih Receivers, who wait without for that purpoe; and omtimes do open the door to let in uch who have deigned to rob the houe; if taken, the tendernes of their age makes an apology or an excue for their fault, and o are let alone to be hang'd at riper years.

div.head: Priggers of Prancers.
div.p: PRiggers of Prancers, are Hore-tealers; for Prig is to Steal, and Prancer is an Hore; thee Rogues eldome go without a light Briddle in their pockets, and a mall pad Saddle, which they can eaily carry in their breeches, and being inform'd by their Spies abroad where good hores run at Gras, in the dead of the night will take them up in a moment, and will as oon teal an Hore as another look over the Hedg. If they fear to be dicovered by the Field-keeper, then two or three of them will go together and boldly attack him, and having worted him, bind and gag him, and o effect their purpoe, and will be far enough off, by break of day, from being overtaken; the nearet Fair is then inquir'd after, where with all imaginable peed they ell their toln Hores.

I have heard of ome of thee Priggers of Prancers that have been uch notable Artits, as that they could change the colour of an Hores Cote, or make an artificial tar in an Hores forehead, which hould lat a coniderable while, by which means the eyes of the right Owner have been o blinded, that he knew not his own Hore when he aw him: Nay, when they have been confident that they have found their toln Hore, and by everal remarkable tokens are aured thereof; yet the artificial tar in the forehead hath immediately poiled that belief; and o have een their own Hores old before their own faces and toled, having always ome notorious Rogue as himelf to vouch for him. This puts me in mind of a notable Story of a Serving-man,
who was pickt up by a pack of Rogues in the tteets and drilled into a Tavern, where having drank very high, they all took an opportunity to leave the Serving man for the Reckoning; this poor man finding himelf pawn'd. and not having o much money to dicharge the reckoning, watcht his opportunity, and o gave the houe the lip alo; three days after his Mater appointed a dinner at this very Tavern, his man ued all the argument he could for to divert him from it, alledging there was bad Wine, ill Attendance, and the like; but all would not prevail, but that thither he went according to the appointed time; Dinner being on the Table, the Mater of the Houe was invited up for the ake of his good company, being a very jolly and facetious man, at whoe approach the Serving-man knew not what to do. and had but one lender hift to keep him from being dicovered, which he did by hutting one of his eyes as if he had been blind, and o continued keeping it hut whilt he erv'd at table; the Vintner tared him o much in the face that his Mater took notice thereof, and askt him why he gazed o much on his man; your pardon Sir, aid the Vintner, if I ay that your man is as like a fellow that cheated me of an eighteen hilling reckoning as ever I aw in my life, and I would wear that he is the ame but that this wants an eye, and the other had his ight perfect. At this the Mater askt his man how he came to be thus uddenly blind, having lot an eye in les than an hours time; at which the man replied, being a notable crafty fellow, that if his Mater would be pleaed to forgive him, he would tell him the whole truth; his Mater granted it, and hereupon the Serving-man inform'd him, how he had been deluded by a pack of Knaves, and how to ecure himelf,
was forced to make his ecape; that to conceal himelf from the Vintners knowledg he had found out that tratagem of winking with one eye; the Mater was o well pleaed with the tory, that he pay'd the Vintner what was left to pay, and the Vintner was o well pleaed to have reocived a debt o deperate, that he gave the Serving-man a crown, to help to open his eye again.

But our Priggers Metamorphoing of beats is much more undicoverable, by which means they frequently teal and afely ell other mens Hores; but let them have a care; the pitcher goes not o often to the well, but that it comes home broken at lat.

div.head: Of Palliards or Clapperdogeons.
div.p:
THee Palliards or Clapperdogeons are Beggars born, who have their Morts in the treets, with children, either of their own, or borrowed ones, lying about them on traw; and in this manner they beg, and with thee they beg, extracting thereby the greater pitty; thee jades know how to crew their faces into what pittiful poture they pleae, and have melting words at their fingers ends; as For Gods ake betow your Charity on thee poor Fatherles Children; My Husband was kill'd at Sea, and I being ick and unable to work, am ready to tarve, with thee poor Infants; by thee and the like expreions, with the cryes of the children, which he forceth them to, by pinching or otherwie, he picks up a great deal of money, whilt he:
Comrogue lies begging in the fields with Clymes â€¢ r artificial Sores. The way they commonly take to make them is by Spere-wort or Arnick, which will draw bliters; or they take unlaked Lime and Soap, mingled with the rut of old Iron, thee being well tempered together, and pread thick on two pieces of leather, they apply to the leg, binding it thereunto very hard, which in a very little time will fret the skin o, that the fleh will appear all raw, then they take blood and rub it over the leg, which being fully dried makes the leg appear black, letting the eeming ore peep out of ome holes out of the Matterih clouts that are wrapt about it.

I aw a fellow not long ince itting by the road ide, on a Mudwall in the way to Ilington (this was his contant tand on Sabbath days, there being at that time the greatet concoure of people if the Weather be fair) I ay this fellow had one hand tied up in a white cloath, and pinned to his breat, his cloaths were indifferent good, but had a better face by much, I mean an honet harmles look, and eemed o bahful and modet that he beg'd of none but with his pale face and pittiful looks: and this way of begging prov'd more prevalent then the bawling of two or thre fellows that lay a little above him on the ground, with grievious ore legs, eemingly not able to tand or go of them.

I oberv'd this fellow everal times in this very place, not imagining this ilent Counterfeit was of the Society of thoe clamorous Rogues who lay nigh him, till one day having an occaion to go o â€¢ ver to the bank-ide, in a Garden houe, there did I ee this lame handed fellow with the other confederate Cripples playing at Nine pins as nimble as a Squirrel in a Bell-Cage.

I took no notice of them at that time, no more then what my ears uffer'd by the hideous din of their execrable Oaths; not being longer able to be near them, I return'd home, reolving to take the firt opportunity to detect thee Rogues. Wherefore I went with two or three more to the place according to the uual time where thee Beggars took up their tand to beg, and approaching my modet ilent Mumper, I askt him what ailed his hand, or how he came by that lamenes? To tell you the truth Sir, aid he, I am a poor Tranlator, or Cobler commonly called, and one day it was my michance, (and then the tears tood in his eyes) as I was working, to run the Awl quite through my hand; neglecting it, it feter'd, o that now it is in a ad condition, and not being able to work, I am ready to tarve, having old all my little tock already, either to cure my hand, or maintain my elf, but now all is gone. Alas poor man, aid It let me ee your hand for I am a Chyrurgeon. O Sir, cry'd the fellow, I hall die intantly if you open ie. Hereupon I graped his pretended ore hand very hard, and told him I would ee it; at which he roar'd as if he had been on the Dutch Rack at Amboyna; which noie gathered abundance of people about us, and every one condemning my hardheartednes, till I told them what a cheat he was, and bid them if they would nor credit me, yet believe their own eyes, and o opened his hand, which was ound and not hurt in the leat. Now good people ecure this fellow, and you hall ee I will dicover more of the Gang yonder; the Cripples that lay a little way off hearing me ay o, got up, and prov'd uch excellent footmen, notwithtanding their pretended lamenes, that though everal followed them, yet none could come nigh them; which caued o great a laughter, with hooting,
that one would have thought the People half ditracted. This fellow whom I had caued to be ecured was carried before a Jutice, and from thence to Bridewell, where he received the evere lah for his abominable hypocriie.

A Story much like this I have heard of, done in Dorethire.
