Once a year at a place called Woodberry-hill, on the top thereof is kept a Fair, and becaue it is omewhat coniderable, thither reort the Beggars all round the Country, lying at the bottom of the hill begging in heaps. An arch Crack that had oberved what counterfeit Rogues the major part of thee were, went to the top of the hill, and unpinning a wheel took it off and brought it to the brow of the Hill, which was very high and indifferently teep, and crying out to the Beggars below, have at ye blind Harpers, lets the Wheel go, hereupon the Counterfeit cut the trings to their counterfeit lame legs, and ran for it, and thoe that had not the time for it, roled one over other, and by this confuion (which was the mot pleaant and comical ight could be een) their Knavery was dicovered loing the benefit of that preent Fair, and many more afterwards. More might be aid of the Clapperdogeon, but let this uffice.

div.head: Of Fraters.
div.p: FRaters are uch, who with a Counterfeit Patent, beg for ome Hopital or Spittle-houe, or they are uch who pretend to have Patents for Briefs, and have hereby within thee few years, mot intollerably cheated the Country, and in the concluion have brought their heads to the Pillory.

div.head: Of Quire Birds.
div.p: Qire Birds are uch who have ung in the With, the Naskin; that is, Newgate, Bridewell, or ome Country Goal, who having got looe fall to their old trade of Roguing and Thieving again, for indeed when once their hand is in, they eldome give out, till they overtake the Gallows.

div.head: Of Abram Men.
div.p: ABram Men are otherwie called Tom of Bedlams; they are very trangely and antickly garb'd with everal coloured Ritb â€¢ nds or Tape in their hat, it may be intead of a Feather, a Fox tail hanging down a long tick with ribbonds treaming and the like; yet for all their eeming madnes, they have wit enough to teal Poultry as they go, and will have his change of Wenches, oftner than people change their Linnen.

div.head: Of Whip Jacks.
div.p:
WHip-Jacks are Counterfeit Mariners, who talk of nothing but Fights at Sea, Pyracies, Drownings, and Shipwracks; they have alwaies a Counterfeit Pas or Licene which they call a Gybe, and the Seals thereunto Jarkes; under this pretence they trole the Country, begging as they go, poeing the People with trange beliefs of their great loes, and that they onely beg to upply their neceities in their way home; and for their own certain upply, they will not tick to heave a Booth; that is rob a Booth at a Fair, or in ome by road rob an houe, playing other very notorious prankes. Thee Rogues have learned their Sea terms by which they have cheated uch as have been very expert in Sea-affairs, The Whip-Jack
carrie â€¢ h his Mort or Wench with him too, which he pr â€¢ to be his Wife, whom he miraculouly aved in th â€¢ Ship-wrack, although all his children were drown'd plitting on a Rock near the Lands end coming from the Wet-Indies with uch like forgeries; but I have known thee dicovered too, to be cheats, and being brought to the Whipping pot have been everely laht for their pains.

div.head: Of Mumpers.
div.p: Mmpers are both Male and Female, a Gentiler ort of Beggars, for they corn to beg for food, but money or cloaths, the money they lay out to pamper the gut, and the cloaths they ell to reimbure the pocket.

The Male Mumper in the times of the late Uurpation, was cloathed in an old t â€¢ rn Caock begirt with a girdle, with a black cap, and a white one peeping out underneath; with a formal & <> countenance he teals up to a Gentleman and whipers him oftly in the ear, that he is a poor equetred Paron, that he hath four mall children with a iek wife, all ready to perih.
Sometimes he appaared in the habit of ome decayed Gentleman, and then he pretends what a great ufferer he hath been for his Majety, but lately come our of Gaol, and not a penny to help himelf.

Sometimes he appears with an apron before him, and a cap on his head, and begs in the rature of a Broken Trademan, who having been a â€¢ ong time
ick, hath pent all his remaining tock, and o weak he cannot work.

The Female Mumpers, with a torn black hood and carfe, will go confidently to an houe, and knock at the door, demanding to peak with the Mitres of the houe, where after an Apology made for her boldnes, he acquaints her how urgent her neceity is; having an husband very ick, with two mall children, ready to give up the Ghot; that he was born a Gentlewoman, but marrying againt her friends conent, he was by them thrown off and diowned, and o by her husbands iknes reduced to this mierable condition.

Sometimes he appears as if big with child, and o begs cloaths or linnen to make clouts: She is very buie in the Palace-Ya â€¢ d in Terme-time; but if he be young, tollerably handome, and he find Charity grow cold, he will endeavour to repair her pretended misfortune by night-walking.

There is yet one gentiler ort of Mumper than any yet named, of which qualification I never knew but two; thee had their hores, and agreed between themelves as to their particular tidings. Their buines was to inquire out among Book-ellers mall Treaties not long printed, yet unaleable, of which they would buy a quantity of a ort for wate paper or little more, and having drawn up or caus'd to be drawn, a general Epitle Dedicatory, they left pace at top to inert the name and dignities of the Peron they intended to dedicate the book unto, carrying Letters and Ink with them, which they peedily did print, and tollerably enough for that purpoe; the Epitle was printed before, o that they need add nothing but the name and dignities. I have heard them confes they had from the meanet Donor, thrice the value of what
the book was old for at firt, and mot commonly ix-fold. Their travelling time was in the Summer, wherein they got o much to keep them drunk all the Winter, but they being deceaed, I believe the Trade dyed with them.

div.head: Of Dommerars.
div.p: Dommerars or Dummerars, are uch who counterfeit themelves dumb, and have a notable art to rowl their tongues up into the roof of their mouths, that you would verily believe their tongues were cut out, and to make you have the tronger belief thereof, they will gape and how you where it was done, clapping in a harp tick, and touching the tongue make it bleed, and then the ignorant dipute it no farther.

div.head: Of Jack-men.
div.p: Jack-men are uch who can both write and read, who make counterfeit Licenes and Paes, for which he is well rewarded for his labour and pains.

div.head: Of Patrico's.
div.p: PAtrico's are the Strolers Priets, every Hedge is his Parih, and every wandring Rogue and Whore his Parihoners; the ervice he aith is the marrying of couples, without the Gopel, or Book of Common-prayer, the olemnity whereof is thus.

The parties to be married find out a dead hore, or any other Beat, and tanding one on the one ide and the other on the other, the Patrico bids tham live together till death them part, and o haking hands the wedding is ended.

div.head: Of Irih-Toyls, or Swig Men.
div.p: THee Irih Toyls, or Swig-men, being much alike, I joyn them together, who carry pins, points and laces, and uch like wares about; who under the pretence of elling uch commodities, commit many Rogueries; I know not what to think of Tour old Shooes, or old Boots, will you buy my Brooms? When the Brooms are old, that long taff they carried them on would erve to knock a man down, with very much eae; and Have you any old uits, hats or cloaks, may make that profeion a good cloak to hide and cover toln goods.

div.head: Of Kynchen Coes.
div.p: KYnchen Coes are little children whoe Parent are dead, having been Beggars or ele young Boys, uch as have ran away from their Mater, and intead of a Trade to live by, follow this hind of life to be lowie by. The firt thing thee Kynchens are taught is Canting, then Thieving, and at lat Hanging. But before they come to take the heighth oe Tyburn, where the Pole is elevated o many degrees, they ail many times along while in the troubled Ocean of ad diaters, wherein they meet with nothing but Sorms and Tempets, raied by the Hurricans of their own irregular actions; ometimes ready to fouader in the large and dangerous Sea of Paddington, and continually ready to plit againt the dreadful Rocks of Newgate, or Bridewell.
The Female and antient Profeors of the Art of Canting, were ranked under thee even heads;

div.head: Of Glymmerers.
div.p: THe Glymmerers are uch as â€¢â€¢ vel up and down with Licenes to beg, under the pretence that they have lot all by fire: they have their tears at command, which they pour out in abundance, at the ad relation of their great loes, telling a lamentable tory, how the fire conumed their Barns, Stabies, and Out-houes, and what excellent goods they had which were detroyed therein; thee Glymmerers are defended by Upright-men, who ue not to walk with them, but keep aloof.

div.head: Of Bawdy-Baskets.
div.p: BAwdy-Baskets are uch who walk about with Baskets on their arms, wherein are pins, needles, and laces; and in this number ome of your band-tring women may come in, who are alwaies taking great pains with their hands in the day, and with their breeches at night.

div.head: Of Autem Morts.
div.p: Atem-Morts are uch who are married, having always children with them, one in the arms, and another at the back, and ometimes leading a third in the hand. You are not to ask what Church he was married in, or by what Paron, as long as a To â€¢â€¢ demallion hall wear he will jutifie himelf the â€¢ husband, before any Jutice of Peace in England, talk to him of a Certificate, and you were a â€¢ good call him Son for a Whore.

div.head: Of Strowling-Morts.
div.p: STrowling-Morts are uch as pretend to be Widdows, travelling about from County to County, making laces upon â€¢ aves, as Beggars tape, or the like; they are ubtil Queans, hard-hearted, light-ingred, hypocritical and diembling, and very dangerous to meet, if any Ruffler or Rogue be in their company.

div.head: Of Doxies.
div.p: DOxies are neither Wives, Maids, nor Widdows; they will for good Victuals, or for a very mall piece of Money protitute their bodies, and then protet they never did any uch thing before, that it was pure neceity that now compell'd them to do what they have done, and the like, whereas the Jades will prove common: Hacknies upon every light occaion: they are dexterous in picking of pockets, which they mind mot when they find the mans thoughts mot imployed on omewhat ele; they are detructive Queans, and oftentimes ecret Murtherers of the Infants which are illegitemately begotten of their bodies.

div.head: Of Dells.
div.p: DElls are young buckome Wenches, ripe, and prone to Venery, but have not yet lot their Maiden-heads, which is commonly done firt by the prightman, and then they are free for any of the Brotherhood.

div.head: Of Kynchin-Morts.
div.p: KYnchin-Morts are Girles of an Year or two old, which the Morts their Mothers carry at their backs in lates or heets; if they have no children of their own, they will teal or borrow them from others.
Let this uffice of what I have poken of the old Profeors of the Art of Canting; I hall now proceed and give you a hort Character, with the names of uch as are the late Profeors hereof.

LEt me take them in Order, and firt for the High-Pad, or Knight of the Road; Before he <> this dangerous enterprize in hand, he firt â€¢ urni â€¢ heth himelf with a good Hore, Sword and Pitols, with upernumerary killing Intruments, if need require; And thus equipt, ometimes ingly, but mot commonly in company with others, he robs all he can meet with: his uual times for
couring the Roads, is when the Sun begins to decline, and the place of oure, yet advantagious for the propect of the eye, o that it may quickly dicern approaching booties; thus enriching their own condition by the ruine of others, each honet mans lo â€¢ being thee Rogues gain.

They have a Vizard-Mask and Perruke to diguie themelves therewith, and by that means obcure themelves from the knowledge of uch as are contrained to pay them an unwilling Tribute. Nay, they have a trick to alter their voice, o that as their habit, face and hair are helps to their nondicevery; o their peech (which one hould think) is undiguiable, adds very much to their concealment and ecurity.

When they meet with a prize upon the Road, they have a Watch-word among themelves, which is no ooner pronounced, but every one falls to his work. This is the general rule they have among them, the tronget and bet at grap eize firt; the weaker only bid tand at firt, and afterwards fall in according as occaion requires; the intructions given them, is to catch the bridle by the left hand, and to have the word in the right; if any oppoition be made to cut oundly, and if likely to be over-powred, to kill as fat as they can, and then either with booty or without, to fly with all expedition. If they are purued by an Hue and Cry, they were wont to obcure themelves in ome place or other, and let it pas by them. How much the Roads of late have been peter'd by them is unknown to few, notwithtanding o many of them have been taken and Executed at Tyburn; Now to the intent you may be wary of them, take thee following afe and wholome Intructions.

Firt, If you are about to take a Journy, conceal the time as near as you can, and the charge you intend to carry with you; it is a Cutome no les common then indicreet, for perons to blaze abroad among their reputed friends, the time of their intended departure, and out of meer vainglory, tell what um of money they carry with them; this hath been often times the caue of their being way-laid, for there is not o found a Flock of Sheep, but there may be one cabby, o in a Society one Judas, that for gain to hare a fourth of the prize, will betray a man to thee Bully-Ruffins of the Road.

Secondly, When you come into your Inn, have a care you dicover nothing of your concern to the Hotler, Chamber lain or Hot himelf; the two firt are commonly bribed, or are in Pention with the High-Pad, and the lat in expectation of a hare, or good tore of Money pent in his houe profuely, will either from your own mouth voluntarily, or by pumping, endeavour to dicover where the booty lieth, and how much, and information intantly given to the High-Pad.

Be not eaily perwaded to aociate your elf with Strangers on the Road, but rather endeavour to hun uch as are too forward to pres into your company; if you have a upition of uch company, lag a little behind; and if you ee them halt alo before, by alighting or otherwie, provide for your afety with what peed you can.

Supect all thoe that diguie themelves in any manner, by throwing a long Cloak over there houlders, wearing a Vizard Mask, fale be ard, Perruke, &c. Or if they have none of thee diguies, yet till appead upitious, look their full in the face, and if they turn their heads aide being
unwilling to be viewed by you; this is an infallible mark of an High-way man: there are many more marks to dicover thee Deperado's, by which I omit, becaue they will take up too much time in the Decription.

I hall therefore give you ome intructions for your afety in Travelling: If you ride with a coniderable Charge, chooe rather to Travel by night then by day; for this is held as an undeniable truth among thee Catter-pillars, that none will ride by night that are worth the robbing: beides, thee High-way men in prudence take up their Inn betimes, to avoid the upition of being accounted and apprehended for Rogues by being abroad o late.
Chooe when you travel, the By-Roads; for your High-way men generally elect the Roads which are mot common and beaten, that they may have their choie of booties, and not treightned in their prize.

If you are five or ix in Company, keep a coniderable ditance one from the other when you come to ome noted place for Robbery, and do not huddle all together; this will conduce much to your afety, for by this means the Pads will be affraid to aault you thus tragling, leat one or other ecape and o raie the Country: What ele hath been or may be aid of this Subject, I hall refer you to the firt part of the ENGLISH ROGE; wherein you may be more fully informed.
I hall conclude this dicoure of them, with this Padding-Song.

lg.l: I Keep my Hore, I keep my Whore,
I take no Rents, yet am not Poor,
I Travel all the Land about,
And yet was born to ne'r a foot.
With Partridg plump, and Wood-cock fine
I do at Midnight often dine,
And if my Whore be not in cae,
My Hotes Daughter has her place.
The Maids fit up and watch their turns,
If I tay long the Tapter mourns,
The Cook-maid ha's no mind to fin,
Though tempted by the Chamberlin.
But when I knock, O how they butle,
The Hotler yawns the Goldings jutle,
If th' Maid but leep, O how they cure her,
And all this comes of Deliver your pure Si â€¢ .

div.head: Of the Low Pad.
div.p: A Low-Pad is a bae Sheep-tealing half-penny Rogue; the lownes and meannes of whoe Spirit will toop for two hillings, though he hang for his pains.

He is not of ability to ride on Hore-back, and therefore skulks under hedges in the Road, and with a long Pole knock a man down as he rides along, or immediately and uddenly tarts out from his covert, and eizing the bridle another comes and dimounts him, and o rob him.

The Fields about the Suburbs of the City, in Winter-eaon, ue to be very much peter'd with thee Vermin, thee dangerous Villains: the mot noted places are between Annieed-Clear and Newington, between Hollow-way and Ilington, between the Pinner of Wakefield and Kentih-Town, between Red-Lyon Fields and Totnam-Court, and latly, Woods-Cloe hath been very remarkable for thee pilfering Rogues, skulking and lying up and down in ditches, and like Quails calling on one the other with a harp and loud return they will anwer each others hrill whitle; this they do to give notice to each other where they lie, o that they may commodiouly join with each other in the aaulting of any peron they intend to rob. They make choice of Winter Evenings, as mot convenient to obcure their dark purpoes.

div.head: Of the Gilt.
div.p: THe Gilt is one that going into a Tavern or Ale-houe, no room below tairs will erve his turn, and therefore is howed room above; he carrieth his friend with him, or more, as occaion hall require.

Being mounted aloft, he peeps into this room, and that, if he epies no body in the way, he will boldly adventure in, and with his Gilts (from whence he takes his name) he will readily find out (by frequent practice) one that hall fit any Lock, whither Trunk, Desk, Cabinet or Chet, and if he have time will (very civily) lock them with the ame intruments he opened them; having done their buines, away they rub to ome other place, till they are dicovered, and o ent to the Nubbing cheat for their art and ingenuity.

div.head: Of the Budge.
div.p: THe Budge by ome is termed a Runner: his employment is in the dark of the Evening, to go into any door that he eeth open, and boldly entring the houe, takes whatever next cometh to hand, and marcheth off therewith; if he meets any upon his entrance, they hall not need to ask him what buines he cometh about, for he will intantly ask whether uch a Gentleman be within, if an anwer be returned they know no uch peron; he will traightways crave their pardon, aying, he was mitaken in the houe, and will not tay to hear any reply; but if he meets with no oppoition, his confidence will carry him three pair of tairs, though he is ure for his labour to come down by the Rope.

div.head: The Ken-Miller.
div.p: HE is a fellow that waits any opportunity to commit Burglary, he never goes alone, unles now of late time, wherein thee Rogues have found out new ways to rob houes, that is by getting in to new built houes unfinihed, through which they get into the Gutters of other houes inhabited, and o conequently into the Windows thereof, and o convey what they get either out of the Garrets, and other Rooms lower down, as far as they durt venture: This coure thee Rogues take as oon as the day is hut in, and ometimes ooner; but the other Houe-breakers watch their opportunity in the dead of the night; who have an Intrument they call a Betty, with which in a moment they will force open any door, at which entring they instantly Gag and Bind all in the houe, and o march off with their booty; but let them act ever o warily, thee pranks help them to break their necks at lat.

div.head: The Huff.
div.p: THe Huff heretofore uually kept his Whore, which upon a plotted occaion mut acknowledg her elf his wife, who having drawn in ome young man to lie with her, gives intelligence thereof to the Hector, who watcheth the minute, catcheth them in the act; and with threats and God knows what, frightens the young man into a compliance of recompencing the injury, either by preent atisfaction or by a Bond or o forth; but this hath been o notoriouly and commonly ued, that this practice is obolete and quite out of fahion.

Ye â€¢ till he hath a being, though his way of living be omwhat different, for now he at firt ets up by taking a pure on the Road, which not only puts him in tock, but furniheth him with good apparel, that may qualifie him to keep Gentile Company, as occaion hall offer. He undertands a Dye very well, and well he may; for, for ome years that he was a Foot-boy, or o, there was not an hour in the day pat in which he did not exercie his hand with the Dice, either for naughty halfpence, or Coffee-pence when fortune mil'd, or ele by himelf, that he might the better cope with his livery Companions, Lace-coated Gameters; beides, three parts of every nights dream is pent in Come at even, what chance of the Dye is oonet thrown, in topping, lurring, palming, napping, with how to fix a Die for any purpoe.

Practiing thus, Sleeping and Waking, he becomes an excellent Proficient in all orts of Gameing by which he endeavours to bubble all he meets
with, but if unkind Fortune by meeting with his match hath rob'd him of his Money, he knows where to borrow or teale an Hore with which he may rob the Travailer to Re-intock himelf.
In hort his Cloyter is a Bawdy-Houe, where all his devotions are tendered.

He is a Protector to all ditreed Damels called in our Vulgar Tongue Common Whores, and that he may put a better Glos on the matter, calleth them Cozens, and wears he will Vindicate their (Stinking) reputations with the Hazard of his life, and that he may trike terror into the fearful; he will draw upon any light occaion not with an intent to hurt, but to wipe off the upition of being a Coward: for this he knows that the opinion of Valor is a good Protection to him that dares not ue it.
In company there is no man more Exceptions and Cholerick, but eldom lets his anger well into a quarrel; but hopes by his Huffing to blow over a ound Bating.

Yet if he dicovers a Coward, he will not ret tell he hath found out ome means to quarrel with him, and there mut not be expected a reconcilement, till the Gentleman hath given him atifaction with a Silver word.

No man more contantly imployeth his Brains then this Bully-Huff; For his life is a dayly invention, and each meal a Stratagem. When his Whores will not or cannot upply him, he borrows of any that will lend him money, which ometimes is lent him, not o much expecting a repayment, as that he will never trouble them more.

To conclude with him, his Prayers are in the
morning that his Cheats may take effect that day, if not, that he may be Drunk before night; he leeps with a Tobacco Pipe in his Mouth, and dreams of nothing but Villany; and when he dyes it is either on the Gallows, or like Hercules with <> in his Bones.

div.head: The File and Bulker.
div.p: THe File was formerly called a Bung-Nipper! or Cut-Pure becaue with a hort harp Knife, and an horn Thumb, he would cut a Pure with all eae imaginable; but ince Pures are much out of fahion, the File or Pick-Pocket is a la Mode.

It was wonderful with what Dexterity and Celerity they will pick a Watch, Money, or any thing ele out of a mans Pocket; and leat they hould be detected, and the goods found about them, they have one that attends the Operator who aoon as he hath done his work, immediately conveys what he hath got into the hands of his Comrogue, who trips off with it, o that if they be upected and earched, there is no uch thing with which he is taxed found about him. They have their appointed places to meet where they hare.
Their Markets are Fairs, Crowds, Churches and places where great tore of People reort, the Bulker jatles them up, and the File doth the work.

Before the great and dreaful Fire, I heard of a very Spruce File, who took up his tand commonly on Ludgate Hill, there being frequently a great top of Coaches, if he could not pick the Pockets of thoe that were on foot, he would pick out the pin of the wheel of that Choach in which he aw none but Gentlewomen, and by their habit thoe of the better ort; he would wait on this Coach particularly, for the top being over as oon as ever the Coach began to move one of the Wheels would drop off, then would he be as officious as might be to hand the Lady's out, who eldom refued him, he being always well garbed and as with one hand he lifted them, out with the other he drew out what was in their Pockets, ometimes taking away the Watch that hung by their ide.
I mut not forget one notable tory of late, which was this.

A Trademan of my acquaintance having ome buines in the Strand, which required not o much hat but that he made a top at the Pictures which uually hung out near the Middle Exchange, gazing thereon, a Motherly Woman in good habit came and tood by him, and askt him what uch a Picture ignifyed, Why (aid he) its the Story of Noah and his two Daughters; what is it I pray Sir (aid he, Iutling up cloer to him) I am very deaf pray peak Lowder; with that the Man to atisfy her curioity opened his throat to ome purpoe, Speaking aloud that it was the Repreentation of Noah being drunk and lying with his own Daughters: Marry is it o, (aid he) then fie upon them for a couple of Lecherous Queans, and He for an old doting Drunken Coxcomb; could he find out no body ele to do withall but his own
fleh and Blood, however Sir I thank you for your information, I have received a great deal of atisfaction from you, and o it eems he had having pickt his Pocket of what Money was therein contain'd.

div.head: The Moon Curer.
div.p: THe Moon Curer is generally taken for any Link-Boy; but particularly he is one that waits at ome Corner of Lincolns-Inn-Fields with a Link in his hand, who under the pretence of Lighting you over the Fields, being late and few tiring, hall Light you into a Pack of Rogues that wait for the comming of this Setter, and o they will all joyne in the Robbery.

Some of thee were found to be Labourers o called, uch who wrought all day in the Ruins of the City and were paid by their Mater Workmen, and at night found an eaier way to pay themelves by lying in the Ruins, and as they aw occaion would drag in People into Vaults and Cellars and there rob them.

div.head: The Bawd Pimp and Whore.
div.p: I Put thee together becaue it is pitty to part the Devills Houholdtuf: and indeed he is very much like him, her Envy running Paralel with his: For all that the Devil indeavours to do, is to bring Man-kind into the like tate and condition, and the nature of a Bawd is to make all fair Women as foul as her elf; now becaue their youth perhaps will not admit of it o oon; he hurries them on to it by degrees; by the exces of Drink and Smoke, and Venery, and that point by which he indeavors to et off her bad Commodity will in a little time totally ruine.

If you viit her houe he pretends to have no Drink, but will end for ome that he may be ure of your Money; if you touch her bedding it will infect you, for few comes near it but they are troubled with a fit of the falling Sicknes; but yet this I hall tell you, hall well teach you temperance, not uffering you to have too much Liquor for your Money: If he tays a year in a place he is befriended by the Jutices Clerk.

The Intruments in chief of a Bawds trade are an Hector or Huff, which eems intead of the Gyant to defend her inchanted Catle from being violated by Knights Errant: The Pimp which brings Grit to the Mill, that is Bawdy Cutomers to the houe, which he picks up under this pretence; goe along with me and I will how you the fairet Wench in Chritendom, or raie a dicoure of Bawdry, and then wear, there is not uch a
Curious fine Sinner in or about the City as there is at uch a place, &c.

But the Whore is the Main upport of the Houe. The firt will not wagger unles he be paid, the next wont procure unles he may Spunge, and have his Leachery for nothing, and the Whore will not ply unles he hath half hare of her own Gettings beides a little Snicking by the by.

The Market places to which Bawds reort to buy Tools for her Trade are Inns, where he enquires of the Carriers for Servant Maids, and according as they are handome he Entertains them, and trains them up in the Myteries of her Occupation, and having qualified them for the Profeion of a Protitute, the Bawd furniheth them with Butter fly Garments, and other gawdy accoutrements for which he hath three hares, or as much as they can agree about.

I am orry I have fouled my Fingers with uch dicoure, excue what is already Writ, if you will be better informed, have a care you do not Entertain the Pox for your Companion; let me End with this Song.

div.head: The Park Song.
div.l: OF late in the Park a fine fancy was een,
Betwixt an old Bawd and a buckome young Quean,
Their parting of money began this uproar,
I'le have half ays the Bawd, but you han't ays the Whore.
Why 'tis my own houe,
I care not a loue,
'Tis I ays the Whore that mut take all the pains,
And you hall be damn'd e're you get all the gains,
The Bawd being vexed traight to her did ay,
Come off with your Dud's and I pray pack away,
And likewie your Ribons, your Gloves, and your Hair,
For naked you came, and o out you go bare:
Then the Buttocks o bold,
Began for to cold,
Hurry-Dun was not able her clack for to hold,
Both Pell-mell fell to it, and made this uproar,
With thee complements, thou'rt a Bawd, thou'rt a Whore.
The Bawds and the Buttocks that lived there round,
Came all to this cae, the pockie and ound,
To ee what the reaon was of this ame fray,
That did o diturb them before it was day;
If I tell you amis,
Let me never pis;
This Buttock o bold, her name was call'd Sis,
By Quiffing with Cullies three pounds he hath
got,
And but one part of four, mut fall to her lot.
Then all the Bawds cry'd, let us turn her out bare,
Unles he will yeild to return you half hare,
If he will not we'l help to trip off her cloat
And turn her abroad with a lit on her Noe.
Who when he did ee,
There was no remedy,
For her from the tyrannous Bawds to get free;
The Whore from the money was forced to yield,
And in the concluion, the Bawds got the Field.

div.head: Of the Shop lift.
div.p: SHe is mot commonly well clad, and one that wants more Grace than Wit; She hath everal large pockets about her, but that which tands her principally intead, is her Gown or Petticoate o tuckt up before that it will contain any thing without falling out: Thus prepared he will boldly goe into a Mercers hop, and there pretend to lay out a great deal of Money, whereas her whole intent is to convey into her lap ame Peece of Silk or Sattin which will lie in a little Compas, and that he may the better Facilitate her purpoe, he will be very troubleome to the Shop keeper, by cauing him to hew her much variety of Commodity, to the intent that what he hath toln may not be eaily mit; and having ped in one Shop, he will attempt other Shops of a different Profeion; he hath variety of Cutomers for thee toln Commodities, as Taylors, Piece-Brokers, &c. Where he makes up her Merchandize.

div.head: Of the Night-Walker and Diver.
div.p: I Joyne them together as being but one and the ame thing; for he that is a Diver or Pick Pocket is an infallible troler or Night-Walker.
This occupation is contrary to all others, for he opens her Shop windows when all other Tiaders are about to hut them.

The night approaching he riggs her elf in the bet manner he can, with ome apparent outward Enign of her Profeion; having weighed Anchor and quitted her P â€¢ rt he teers her coure for ome one principal treet, as Cheap-ide or Corn-hill; with a gentle breee he firt ails lowly on the one ide, and if he meet nere a Man of War between Snow-Hill and the Poultry, he tacks and tands away for the other ide, but if he be a tolerable tight Frigat, he is laid aboard before, made fat with the Grapplings, and preently rummaged in the Whold; ometimes he heers off and leaves my Man of War on Fire.

You hall know her by her bruhing you, taring in your face, often haltings in the treet by gazing about her, or looking after ome or other he hath bruht; but the mot infallible Sign is asking of Quetions, as what is't a Clock, Or I am a tranger which is my way to uch a place.

If he is pickt up he will make an hard hift but he will give a man omething whereby he
hall remember her as long as he lives; beides it is ten Pound to a penny but he plays the Diver and picks his Pocket.

div.head: Of the Bawd and whore.
div.p: THe next ort of Cattell I intend to treat of is the Bawd and Whore, now becaue the Subject is o copious their being o much Roguery Subtlety and Villany contain'd in the profeion of either.

Give me leave to inlarge my elf hereon, promiing you in this dicoure not to offend the ears of any modet READERS, but hall indeavour to dicover the truth of their wicked and Lacivious practices, decribed in the enuing lives of a Crafty Bawd, and a mot Notorious Whore.
Whom for the better carrying on their Hitory, I hall call the firt Mother Craftsby and her Niece Mitres Wheedle.

div.head: The vicious and Remarkable Lives of Mother Craftsby, and Mitres wheedle.
div.p: THe World is full of Impotors, and indeed he her elf is nothing ele but a complicated Cheat: Yet he faine would appear more plendid and better than he is: Men and Women herein contained to imitate everal of Natures production, bad men would eem good though their Intentions and Actions tend not to that Center, and that they may palliate their Rogueries, play the Counterfeit with Vertue and Honety; Pebbles well cut, and Britol-Stones by their borrowed or feigned Luter prove the Rivalls to Real Diamonds, and often delude the ignorant, but when judiciouly compared they prove but foils to the others true Worth, and their glittering erves only to urprize the ignorant.

The contant Standards or Conveyers of light and Virtue are neglected, when hort liv'd Meteors (Spawns of Bogs, and Extracts of Dunghills) drawn by the Suns reitles power to a great er height then they themelves were capable of attaining, to become the wonder of a gazing Multitude, and o much pride therein that being poet with a trange Phrenzy of Ambition, regard not what they do or uffer, o that they make ome butle in the World.

The Perons of whom I do intend my Dicoure were olely bent upon this irregular Humour;
Craftsby being now grown Old, the heat of whoe youthful blood being by Age now near upon extinguiht, minded her profit only; and that her Niece Mitres Wheedle might not too violently proecute her pleaurable inclinations, he topt them in their career by a watchful Eye and Politick Intructions.

The Subtle Bawd was glad to ee her towring Spirit to oar above her mean and low born fortune, to the upplying of which defect, he dayly plum'd her head with Ingenious conceits, which in time might be wrought into uch deceits as he aim'd at, and o it prov'd for dazled with thee fale appearances, they both forook Vertue, the difficult yet the only direct road to Glory, puruing their atisfactions in the crooked and bypaths of Subtlety and Circumventing all which come with in the verge of their power o to effect their purpoe.

It matters not to tell you where they were born, neither do I think them half o wie as they hould be, who relating the life of a Malefactor contend about the place of his or her Nativity; ome placing it here, others, there, the truet writer in the Moon, although the opinion avors omewhat of Lunacy; let it uffice that my two female Whipper Snappers, were born in Terra Incognita and travelled to London for profit, carioity and pleaure.

It will be requiite I begin with the life of Mistris Craftsby, as an introduction to that of Mitres Wheedle, ince the former had but jut began to act her part on Loves Theater, when the other (her Niece) was then as a meer Novice in uch Affairs, being but a bloom in the Cyprian Garden.

Mitris Craftsby had a very good natural Genius, quick of apprehenion, and though he had a very nimble invention, yet contrary to General obervation he had likewie a capacious Memory, its faculties were o retentive he never heard any Ingenious expreion once which was not afterwards abolutely her own; her beauty was not much fam'd though her face was very well featur'd and fahion'd, her tature was middle iz'd, her body plump and flehy, her hair of a dark brown and an eye as black as a low, with eye brows o large and thick, that Nature eem'd prodigal in planting thereon o much, that if half could have been tranplanted 'twould have been more then ufficient to have adern'd the face of ome antient Citizen made barren by the coldnes of his o're frigid Nature.

She very much affected gaudy apparel, and was a great hater of labour and pains taking, the firt he could not purchae in the Country, by reaon of the poverty of her Relations, labour he was continually exercied in, which made her enter tain o great an averion to the Country, that nothing could oppoe her Reolution of eeing London, and that which hatned her departure, was the inufferable dilike he took to the converation of her Country Neighbours, there being no proportion between her and their Humours, nor finding any thing agreable in their Rural patimes. Suans intended departure (for that was her Chritian name) being generally pread abroad, a univeral grief poet the Inhabitants of that Parih wherein he liv'd, but more epecially two Young men, the one a Wheel-Right and the other a Serving-Man; the lat followed her to London, and not finding her lot his Wits,
and was put into Bedlam, where he trifled away his time in Straw and making Congies to a pot intead of his Mitres, till he dyed; the other was no les forward in the purchaing of his love than the former who went for London alo, and miing his Mitres wheel'd off to Sea, whoe flames were quencht in the bottom of the Ocean.

The time being come for her departure, he mounted on a pack, and ate as if he was riding on a Cammel, in her bet Countrey livery, that is to ay, he had a traw hat, a green Watcoat, and red Petticoat, with Hob-naild hoo's which would trike Fire at every tep, the Emblem of what Fire works he would make when he arriv'd at her journeys end.

Coming to London, the reputation of a harmles Country-Girle, and a good comely Face, oon introduced her into a ervice, where having learn'd omewhat more than he undertood in the Country, and by her ervice having gotten good Cloths on her Back, he imagined the place wherein he lived too low to advance her to that height to which her fancy dayly prompted her; neither were the Amorous pretences and ininvations of her Maters Apprentice able to detain, although the grand Obligation of a promied marriage was contained therein; I concieve the tay of three Years, was too long for one in her longing Condition.

The only place he inquired after was a Merchants Houe, as creditable in the firt place, and next, as there was more probability of advancing her fortunes by matching with ome deluded Caheer and he was encouraged to this confidence by the many matches he had heard of in this nature by
uch who were as full of hopes as he was, of thriving in this kind.
A Service he oon got in a Houe as he deired, which, for external plendor and internal accommodations, was little inferior to any Merchants in the whole City.

Here he behaved her elf o well, that he gain'd the love and favor of the whole Houe, and o craftily he counterfeited a becomming modety that her Maters Caheer entertain'd for her a love within his breat that is not common, the more his Reaon indeavored to uppres, it became more Violent, and giving it no vent it was ready to breake that wherein it was Contain'd.

She like a cunning Gypie percieved well the malady of his mind, but would not take the leat notice of it, and intead of quenching that over grown flame which he had blown up by her alluring ubtle practices, her winning carriage and eeming compliance to every thing he eem'd to deire, added new fewel thereunto dayly.

He could now no longer keep in that which would have its free coure in pight of all oppoitions whatoever, and now it violently broke out like Powder fir'd, making a report o much the greater by how much it is pent up in a narrow Circumference.

When other careles Souls are dead in leep, or uffer themelves to be led Captive in leaden Chains, by that heavy headed God Morpheus, the careful Lover is ever watchful, his eyes can find no ret, becaue of thoe continual Alarums the panting Heart doth beat on his troubled Amorous breat.

Thus tood the affair between our Lovers,
Suan being informed that he would relate omething of importance that night to her, thought every hour even till the family was gone to bed, and he every hour eventy till he might have ome aurance of his bedding with his Love.
The houe being now in a profound Silence, he teals out of his own Chamber, and oftly trips down the tairs into the Kitching where his Love attended his coming.

Low was their talk but high was the paion they had reciprocally for each other, that ighs and looks were forc't to upply the place of peech, dicovering what their tongues were incapable of uttering, and Kies upplyd the defects of all the ret.

His warm touches and frequent embraces did melt her into complacency o that on both ides never were their made o many Amorous promies as between thee two Lovers, he wore and damn'd himelf a thouand times if ever he broke his faith with her, and he vow'd and proteted he would never be unfaithful to him, upon this Obligation he condecended the next night he hould lie with her with this Provio, that if he be with Child he hould marry her incontinently, but if no uch thing hapned to defer it ome time longer, this agreement was Seal'd interchangeably by Kies on each ide, and o they went to their repective Chambers.

The Mater of the Houe (whom we hall call Mr. Tradewell) had a Partner and his Wife in the Houe with him, whom for the better carrying on the Story, we mut call by the name of Mr. Silware. this Merchant was gone into France about ome Affair that concerned the Partnerhip, and left his Wife behind him to the care of Mr. Tradewell,
who ever had a great repect for her, being a very lovely Woman, and one whoe beauty and every part exceeded his own Wives by many degrees, the conideration of which had o inflam'd his Heart, that he only wanted an opportunity to make known to her the Fervency of his Affection.

This abence of her Husband gave him all the advantages a Lover could require, neither was he backward in the ving of uch means that might accomplih his irregular defires; he had made everal attempts but till was repult, at length he reolv'd to ummon together all his force and give her one home Charge more, or one Vigorous aault before he would raie his Siege; the time deigned was the next day, after the night the Caheer and Suan had agreed to the aignation of each others Maiden-Heads the night following.
The day being come and when one half or more thereof was pent, Mr. Tradewell ingles out his game (fair to Admiration) and reolved to hit his mark.

You may therefore Swear he did not fright her Ear, with the dreadful tories of horred Dutch cruelties in Amboyna, nor what will become of that ungrateful Nation hereafter, but how he might make a Conquet over Chatity.

Mr. Selware heard his temptations with much eeing impatience and reluctancy, offring frequently to be gone, but eaily tayd by her aailant; he fretted and fumed at the walls as if they were acceory to her detention whereas the door tood wide open, or had it been lockt one Skreeke or two would have as nimbly opened it as the Key thereunto belonging; having flount
and flung up and down, She at length (recovering breath) thus capitulates with him: Where note that Fortres or Citadel that admits of a Parley with her Aailent is already half Surrendred.

p.q: O Mr. Tradewell I did not think you were a Man o looly given, how can you thus offer to injure four at once, your Wives Vertue, my Husbands friendhip, my Chatity, and mot of all your own Soul.

div.p: Tradewell had a tongue mot excellently well hung, with wit at will, by which he o handled the matter, that he cleared thee Scruples, making her believe that forreign Nations publickly permitted (Adjutores Tori;) helpers in the marriage bed; and that it was freely granted by the husband that he hould make choice of any one friend whom he pleaed, that here at home uch things were winked at, ele how comes it about it hould grow o Fahionable for Women to have a Gallant beides their Husbands, who hall not only participate of the pleaure of the Wife, but the profits alo of the Husband.

p.q: What harm then (aid he) can your conent to my propoals do to your Husbands friendhip or your Honety? as for my Wives Vertue if he thinks Chatity uch, let her live Cloyter'd up in my Arms only, if not, let her take the freedome I freely give my elf.

div.p: He added a thouand things more which his tranported paion dictated to him, and laid them o home that with a kind of willing unwillingnes he yeilded to what he requeted, but with many Cautions, as Contancy, Secrecy, &c.

Thee Amorous combatants had nothing now to conider of but to appoint the field where this
Battail mut be ought which was the bed of her abent Husband, the hour Eleven, and that he would take care the whole Family hould be in Bed by that time; in Order thereunto he gave Order that Supper hould be made ready betime, and that his intentions were to rie very early the next day, and therefore he would goe to Bed by time.

This news did not a little pleae Suan and the Caheer, as thinking they hould the ooner and longer injoy their eagerly expected pleaures; every finger that Suan had, upply'd the place of a hand to dipatch Supper, which being ready was diht up, and Mr. Tradewell and his Wie with Mitres Saleware eating themelves.

Suan, according to Cutom, waited on her Mistres and the Caheer on his Mater: Suan was then o bahful that leat ought in her looks hould betray what was all-ready complotted, look't down continually, not daring to look up leat her wanton glances (which he could not hinder) hould prove the Traytors to her expected blis.

The Caheer in the mean time tood like a Statue either taring in Suans face, or ele his Eyes wandring he knew not whether, with his Wits in the weet contemplation of thoe delights he hould be mater of e're long, his thoughts were o totally employd hereon, that he was no farther erviceably to the table then for laughter, for if his Mater cald for Beer, he brought him a clean plate, if his Mitres called for a Glas of Wine he preented it to the Maid, and then to mend the Mitake to Mitres Saleware, which caued a great deal of pleaant dicoure what hould be the occaion of this uddain diorder, none took
more notice of it than Mr. Tradewell, for her Husband was in the like ditraction, neither was Mitres Saleware in les confuion.

Mr. Tradewell partly by the trength of imagination and partly by thoe flames, the incomparable beauty and over kind promies his Partners Wife had kindled in him, made him even ready to diolve as Snow againt the Scorching rays of the Meridean Sun; Fancy made him think he was already incircled in her arms and clung as cloe as Jvies to the Elme; ometimes he thought he heard the Ravihing twang of her harmonical Lace againt her Bodice, making her elf unready to be the more ready to his devotion.

As Supper ended o did the dicoure, for Mr. Tradewell counterfiting a bad Sentinel fell fat a leep pretendedly; this made Mitres Saleware retire, to give opportunity to Mr. Tradewell to put her Husband to bed, who (understanding from himelf that his buines would call him up very Early next morning) awaked him out of his leep deiring him to take his ret in Bed: Mr. Tradewell tarting as one too uddainly diturbed out of his leep, anwer'd (raiing himelf and rubbing his Eyes) goe to Bed Sweet-heart, I will but goe down and give ome intructions to my man what is to be done to morrow, and Order them to goe to Bed, I will intantly return; having given what Orders he thought convenient below, coming up he renew'd the former dicoure with Mitres Saleware and confirmed the contract; he return'd to his own Chamber, where he found his Wife in Bed, and undreing himelf went to Bed alo and to prevent toying with his Wife fell immediately (but feignedly) into a profound leep.

His wife that was not accutomed to be o erv'd could not refrain hedding ome tears to be thus frutrated of th â€¢ e expectations natural heat had ingendred within her; but knowing how ill humour'd he ued to be when pret to any thing he did not voluntary propound and fearing to dipleae him he accomadated her contentment with hopes remitting the fruition of her deires to ome other time, upon thee agreable and elf pleaing thoughts leep cloed the portalls of her Eyes, o Captivating her enes that her leep was as profound as her Husbands was counterfeit.

Every one in the Houe were now paying the quiet Tribute due to Pains-taking, indulgent Nature excepting the aforementioned Lovers: Mistres Saleware lay (improperly) above Mr. Trade-well, Suan in a little room next him, the Caheer a good way ditant; Mistres Saleware and Suan placed their ears to the bet advantage that they might hear the firt tread of their expected Amorous viitants, you mut think they hearkned with as much attention, as a dying Patient would hear the Phyitians entence of Life or Death, privately whipered into the Ear of ome friend tanding by.

Nor did the weary Traveller indure more pain and inquietude in waiting that happy day which hall free him from thoe fears and dangers do on every ide environ him, then this our Tradewell did in having thoe doubts removed which encompaed by the comming of the appointed Hour, before it was fully arrived he left his loving Bed fellow, whoe Face though not tinctur'd with a Vermillion hue like a Morning Bluh, yet was there nothing wanting in her which appertain'd
to her ex, but in every thing was rather redundant.

You may imagine he was very careful of treading hard, yet though he went oftly, he could not hinder the creaking of the boards, which caued a double Alarum, the one to his Mistres of his approach, and the other of fear to himelf, leat thereby he might awake his Wife and o he find him abent, the conideration hereof made his heart to imitate a Drummer in the beating of a point of War.
Coming to her Chamber door, he cald to her in o low a voice he could not hear himelf; yet he could perfectly at a good ditance and intantly give him admiion.

What they peedily went about you may imagine, and therefore it is needles to give you an account of every Amorous folly thee two Lovers were guilty of that time, which lay in Action more than expreion, and no wonder ince kies barracaded up their peech.
Having tired each others lipps, they then encountred with their Leggs and Arms, but how, my modety will not give me leave to tell.

No doubt they ran their Pots or Stages with uncontrouled Eagernes; like an high mettled Hore which at firt mounting will Carvete and Caper, and without the leat touch of Switch or Spur will bounce and foam at mouth, nay fret it elf out of Breath; but let us leave thee Champions of Venus, and give an account of what hapned in this interval, as a jut reward and a remarkable caual revenge on Tradewells infidelity.

About half an hour after this diloyal Husband had left the warm Bed of his hitherto contant
Bed-fellow to go a catterwowling, his Cahier (who was about the age of twenty, a handome luty Lad) got out of his Bed, having lept againt his will, and not knowing how much of the night had lipt away, rubbing his eyes between leeping and waking, he gropes his way in the dark to find out Suans Chamber; but intead thereof, entred into that of his Mitrees: The firt thing he encountred with was the Bed, and finding it o quickly, doubted not but that he was right, concluding the narrownes of the room guided him to his intent and purpoe; whereupon lifting up the clothes oftly, he laid himelf down by her ide; he was not long there, e're he began to butle (not as if he was etling himelf in order to his repoe) which oon awaked his Mitres, who believing it was her Husband, embraced him with an ardent affection, aying, My dearet Joy, how cold you are? Come, put thy legs within mine, I'le warm them for thee; and then dicharg'd a whole volley of kies on him: thoe being over, he talk'd to him again. My dear Husband, I'le tell thee what I jut now dreamt: Methought I heard your man open your maids Chamber door, and talkt of things not fit to be poke; being throughly vext my Houe hould be made a Brothel by your Servants, I endeavoured to rie to prevent them in their Roguery, truggling to get up, and feeling for thee to tell thee what I was going about, I could not find thee in the Bed; this o trangely did urprize my mind, that through fear, vexation, and I know not what, I intantly awoke, and glad I am that it is but a Dream, and that I have thee in mine Arms.

Thee actions and expreions clearly convinc't him that he was in an errour, and that he which
expret o many indearments, and which had o tricktly hackled him within her arms, was his Mitres.

At firt he was almot dead with fear, but having recollected his cattered Spirits, and bethought himelf of this tratageme to preerve himelf from dicovery, all paages that ever he oberved between his Mater and Partners Wife came freh into his mind, and from all the circumtances concluded that they were now conummating their loves. and that if he could but refrain from peaking, he doubted not but that he would fall aleep again, and o have the opportunity of tealing a way, to be as good as his promie.

But jealouly in her dream had o kindled her fire, that abandoning for that time the becoming modety of her Sex, he grew o impatient of delays, that he found himelf incapable of reiting thoe emotions he had rais'd within him, but uffer'd himelf to be taught by her thoe Love-leons, were deigned him by another Love-School Mitres; he had o warm'd her Cahier, that had he been Marble, or a Myanthropos, a mortal enemy to Mankind, he mut have then laid aide his innate hate and emnity to be reconcil'd to uch a loving Enemy.

This Combat lated a long time without any coniderable advantage perceivable on either ide, but being equally tired, they both willingly ounded a retreat. And now it was time for her to conider that thee embraces were more vigorous and fierce than uch which are the attendants to a Marriage-bed, unuually accompanied with uch frequent Repetitions: Beides his continued ilence all this while did trangely tartle her, which with the former, gave her ufficient
grounds to upect he was mitaken in her Bedfellow.

The poor foundred Cahier was in a peck of troubles, not knowing how to get out of that Labyrinth he had caually wound himelf into; each minute he dreaded his Maters apprehending him in bed with his Mitres, and what punihment could he expect les than his Maters Dagger plung'd to the hilts in his traiterous breat; hereupon an univeral Palie eized upon every Limb, but this trepidation of his joynts, his Mitres favourably interpreted the product of his pat delights, or of deire of enjoying more, and not at all the effect of fear.

After a thouand ditracting cogitations, the Cahier having weigh'd each particular in the ballance of his green undertanding, conidered that it might be of a dangerous conequence to ask pardon of his Mitres for what had pat between them, and then again to rie when his Mitres was aleep without dicovering to her the mitake, would the next day undoubtedly betray the whole matter, by her petulancie, or ome little toying and wanton dicoure between her and his Mater; and who knows not but that he might too amply acknowledge his gratitude for his late uppoed works of Supererrogation, which might give him caue to conclude (as it was but jut) that his man had uppli'd his lat nights abence, for none other in the family could be upected. The apprehenion of danger from the dicovery of a ecret of this great importance, did put him in o great a confuion, that it was not to be judg'd which was greater, the pleaure he had obtain'd, or the trouble and fear he underwent in the purchae thereof. Whilet his thoughts were ingaged
in this perplexity a tratagem bolted into his head, which in all probability might remedy all; and thus it was, he reolved to take no notice of any thing he uttered aving the Dream, making her believe that he thought himelf in bed with Suan and none ele, and therefore (grumbling a little firt) he thus poke:

Prethee, my Dear, what didt thou mean by that Dream thou told't me, the matter I value not, but 'tis the manner of telling it troubles me; thy language therein was more like my Mitres than my Love; Why dot thou call me Servant whenas I intend to be thy Husband? But I will not chide, ince I did not think to have been o favourably received by thee; and ince I find thy love cordial (peaking to her with a Kis) were I interrupted from thy embracements, by the interpoition of an Arm of the Sea, wider and more dangerous than that loving Leander once too often crot wimming to ee his portive Hero, I would do it with as much alacrity and willingnes as for triding a Brook obtain a Lordhip. Dearet, aid he, what is the matter? Why o ilent? Fear nothing, our Mitres, poor Gentlewoman, is fat aleep, he like an harmles innocent little dreams of the ingratitude and treachery of her lacivious Husband, who is now at this very nick of time in the height of his enjoyments with Mrs. Saleware. At thee words he became more urpriz'd and amaz'd than ever Alcmene was of old, after Jupiter had enjoy'd her in the hape of Amphitreo.

But eeing there was no remedy for o trange an Accident which had made her break her Marriage-Vow, he comforted her elf in that the fault, if it was any, was not deign'd by her, but all the
guilt ought to lie on her diloyal Husband; and indeed I know not how that can properly be called a fault which was done unwittingiy; beides, he could not but applaud the Jutice of Heaven, punihing him in the ame manner he had abued others. Mrs. Tradewel was omewhat loath to part with the Company of her new Bed-fellow, but reaon perwaded her to it for the avoiding danger, wherefore lipping a Diamond-ring off her finger he convey'd it into the hands of her Servant, aying in a very low voice, if you are dicreet hug in ilence your good fortune, otherwie you hall find a reward utable to your babbling folly.

Hereupon without replying a word, he got out of the Bed, and paing by the Chamber of his poor cheated Suan, he entred into his own, and went to leep; how and in what manner he took and revenged this intollerable affront, I hall anon give you a farther account.

Mr. Tradewel had not been in bed with his beloved Saleware above two hours, but that Mr. Saleware being return'd from France, and landing at Graveend, took a pair of Oars and came traight away for London with an affectionate deire to have a peedy ight of his intirely beloved Wife, and about one a Clock landed at Billingsgate, and thence with all peed went to his Habitation; where coming he knock at the back-door for the convenience of peedy entrance, the Skulling-boy lying jut over the Gate, and o oon got in, making the boy to trike a light, and with it went directly to his Chamber, where thee two Lovers were more intangled with each other than Mars was by the craft of Vulcan with the Cyprian Goddes. He knockt at the door two or three
times, but his Wife being other wayes employed then to come out of a warm bed and indanger of catching of cold, was as mute as a fih, neither could he in Reaon peak till the buines he was about was conummated; but he without repeating his knocks, he was forced at length to ask, who was there, in words imperfect, as jut diturb'd out of a profound leep. It is I, aid her Huband. Who are you, he repli'd. 'Tis I, your Husband, aid Saleware, don't you know my voice? She thus capitulated with him that he might have time to abcond her Lover; the uddennes of the urprize would not permit her to conult long about it, neither was there any other place of ecurity, but underneath the Bed; which Tradewel was forc't to crawl under; that being done, eemingly in great hate he ran to the door, peaking as he went, My Soul, O my dearet Heart, art thou return'd? The mot welcome man to me in the world; whil't he thought in her heart what envious Devil brought thee hither at this juncture of time, thus to obtruct my early joys?

The door being opened, Mr. Saleware entred in, and as he was about to run and catch her in his arms, the ight of her in a manner naked, diplaying her delicate Breats, put him to a tand that he might pleae his eyes before he feated his other enes; this mall time of abence had given him new appetite, and o impatient he grew, that he thought undreing himelf to be the way about and too long for the renewing his delight, and therefore would have cut it horter; but he which already had had the atisfaction of a more vigorous and active ubject, knew how to defend her elf againt the weak aaults of an impotent
Husband: to qualifie him, for the preent the de ir'd him to have patience, if not, he might be intrumental in bringing her into ome dangerous Ditemper, by catching cold coming weating out of a warm bed. This perwaion made him the more haty to go to bed, his Wife in the mean time conidering with what difficulty her Gallant almot tarv'd with cold) mut creep from underneath the bed to acquit himelf of the Chamber, and the danger of taying longer in it, and withal knowing how impoible it would be to teal from her Husband, or if he did, the creaking of the door might betray her, he uddenly pumpt out of her invention, a pretty device to blind her Huband and ecure her friend: Womens wits are ever mot ready at a puh in the greatet traights.

As her Husband was making himelf unready, he caught him about the neck, aying, hold, hold, my dear Heart, prethee let's drink a glas of Wine for joy of thy return, I have half a dozen bottles which were lately ent me as a preent, the bet thou didt ever tate of in all thy life, prethee tep down into the Cellar, there is but one left, it tands in the farthet corner of the Cellar: with all my heart, aid her Husband; in order to his going down he reputs on his Doublet, and having button'd it by halves, he tands up to look for his hooes which he had carelely dropt off his feet, but could find but one, the other it eems tumbled under the bed where Tradewel lay, he began to grope with his hands underneath the Bed, which had like to have frighted our Inamorata and and his Mitres out of their wits; but eeing his earch was in vain, he went to the Table to fetch the Candle, the wife eeing this, lept nimbly out of Bed and pretending to be angry for his tanding
o long barefoot on the cold ground, natcht the Candle out of his hand, aying, is it poible, Husband, that you hould be thus long looking for your hooe and not find it? Come, you hall tand no longer on the bare bords, I'le rather uffer than you; and thereupon lookt for the hooe where he knew it was impoible to find it. The Husband eeing his wife thus walk up and down barefoot, in a great paion told her, that unles he was reolv'd to be acceary to her own death, he would not do as he did; therefore, aid he, let me command you to go to your bed, and do not expoe your tender body to thoe injuries which accompany a cold winter eaon.

Let any one judge whether Mr. Tradewel were not in a weet pickle at the hearing of thee words, and Mrs. Saleware was at her wits ends, thinking now there was no hope of uing any other fallacie, concluding the bet Inventions in this cae barren, and that it lay not in the power of the harpet and craftiet wit to find out a way that may deliver them from this imminent danger.

Now did Mr. Saleware in a eeming rage adadvance to natch the Candle from his Wife; he pretending to prevent him, with an over-officious care not to put him to the trouble, eemed to flumble (in her tarting back) at the foot of the Table, and thereby fell, and by her fall extinguiht nuff and and all; whil't her Husband was groping for the Candle, with all peed he got to the bed to advie Tradewel that this was the time, if ever, to make his ecape undicovered, he durt not peak, and therefore he did thrut her arm underneath the Bed and caught him by the foot; Tradewel thinking that the hand he felt was that
of him he had o injur'd, and therefore now did jutly fear, knew not what to do, thinking it was to little purpoe to endeavour his further concealment, and judged he had no means left but to crawl out upon all four, and in that poture confeing the whole matter, beg pardon of his injur'd friend; but perceiving that the peron that held him by the foot pull'd him but gently, without the utterance of one word, he alterr'd his reolution, knowing it mut be his Friend; after this he found the hooe and gave it her Husband, who by this time had found the Candle, which he fear'd he had given to the Devil to light, and now he entreats him afreh to go down into the Kitching, and light the Candle (there being always ome fire all night long) and thereby fulfil her requet; Saleware by the charming perwaions of his ubtle wife, condecended to every thing he deir'd; he was no ooner gone, but he hatned her Gal â€¢ lant with all peed imaginable out of the Chamber; who eeing himelf freed and at liberty was the joyfullet man living, notwithtanding he was o benumm'd with cold that he lookt like the third Son of Ice-icle Winter, his hirt (by removing himelf on this ide and that, for his better ecurity) was o black by rubbing the boards, that he lookt like a Small-Coal-man, and his Hair, which like Lime-twiggs had ennared the Feathers underneath the bed, made his head appear more like an Owls than a Common-Councelmans; and which was wore, he had o bepit himelf by the fright he was in, that he tunck like a Polecat. In hort, his looks were o ghatly, and his face o pall'd and wan, that the mot rational would have taken him for a Spectre or Phantam, o trange was his Metamorphois in time of this
hort though harp Purgatory; but all this was nothing to what he uffered by his Cahier; one nights repoe would reettle him and retore his former quietude and erene temper, but the injury he utain'd in the abue of his Wife was remediles: Beides had he been dicovered by his Partner, who knows the dangers that jealouie and revenge might procure to proecute an act o foul and o ingrateful: The michiefs are innumerarable they run themelves into, who lighting Heaven by contemning the good Laws of man, are led away by their brutih appetites and inordinate enuality.

Conider then again, how blind and irrational ome are who having wives whoe beauties may dipute for eminencie with the choicet of the Creation, whoe dicretion, modety and prudence was never call'd in Quetion by any foul micarriage, whoe honety and nuptial fidelity is as potles white as innocence her elf; yet I ay, thee very men regarding neither the Laws of of God nor Nature (More ferarum Quadrupedumque) by invading other mens rights, endeavor their atisfaction with uch whoe Perons, Wit, Beauty and Behaviour fall as hort of that which adorns their own faithful Companions, as the plendour of the erene Sun outhines the gloomines of an ecliped Moon. In hort, men hould forbear entertaining uch looe and unlawful deires, if not for the ake of Heaven, yet for the love they ought to bear to their health and honour: But to return where we left.

Tradewel, thus pickled in dut, feathers, and urine, durt not approach his own bed, but thought it very expedient to go to the Chamber of his Cahier, but before he could come at it he mut pas
by his Maid Suans Chamber-door, who had not clos'd her eyes in all that time by reaon of her longing deire of enjoying her Friend. Impatient of waiting longer he had got out of Bed, and having lipt on her Petticoat, he was going out with an intention of going to viit her faithles Friend, at the ame time her Mater came tripping down the tairs from Mr. Saleware; by a little glimmering light he perceived omewhat in white, at firt ight he was omewhat affrighted uggeting that this might be ome Spirit, had undoubtedly creekt out, had he not preently bethought her elf that in all probability this was her unfaithful Friend who had lighted her for a more excellent beauty above, and was now return'd from thoe petulant delliances which properly belong'd to her by Oaths, Vows, & Protetations, imboldned with the conideration hereof, he eiz'd uddenly on his hirt as he was paing by, and not regarding the propinquity of her Mitrees Chamber to hers, in thee terms he upbraided him, O Sir, have I caught you, are thee the fruits of your lat nights Promies, can the current of your love o oon run in another Channel? Bae perjur'd man, o quickly to relinquih that, for which I mut for ever languih.

Tradewel concluded himelf urprized by his Wife, and thought he had by her vigilancie dicovered this amorous complotment, and being concious of his own guilt, he endeavoured after this manner to appeae the jut anger of his injur'd Wife: Dearet, I have offended, let my penitent Confeion plead the remiion of a fault I ne're was guilty of before. To which he repli'd: The firt is a Crime of o high a nature, it can never be forgiven. What violate your Maiden-Obligation and
me who never yet knew man, nor never would know any but for your ake, to whom I'me bound by promies extorted by you from me? Why, did you promie only to delude? Could you not finde ome other way to abue me, but by this the mot inufferable?

Tradewel (finding his mitake) oon baniht his fear, and perceiving what had pat between his Maid and man, made the dicovery of their folly his own advantage; for preently, as if he had known her from the firt interview, thus pake: Well Suan, I never thought you a light Huzzie till now, I had ever too good an Opinion of your honety by your eeming modet deportment, but for the future I hall banih uch good thoughts, o undeerved by you. Get you to your Bed, I hall peedily find out ome way that hall prevent Night-Walkers in my houe from uch like enual meetings; you may now take your ret to night for you are not like to ret here much longer; but let this be your comfort, I will go intantly to mine and your faithles Servant, and enquire of him what was his reaon that he violated that (Sacred) Promie he made, and thus baely diappointed you in your firt fruitions. Having utter'd thee words he left her, but in a condition o ditracted, that he knew not what to nor what to think.

Tradewel eoming to the door where his Cahier lay, found it lockt, whereupon he oftly knockt; the Robber of his Honour (who could not leep for contemplating on what had caually part between his Mitres and himelf) askt who was there: By the anwer return'd, he knew his Mater was without: Intantly his guilty Concience flew into his face, accuing him of what he had o
lately done, and now verily believed that in oftentation his Mitres had told her Husband how luckily (though not wittingly) he was reveng'd of his bae diloyalty, and that his Mater not knowing how to wreak his revenge on her was come to dicharge it on him. As Vice is commonly the Original of fear, o he who is afraid ever upects the worst.

In hort, fear had o univerally poet him, that there was no room left for one rational conideration; all courage had foraken this accidental offending Smell-mock, and the expectation of his enuing punihment had tew'd him in a a cold weat, or rather was diolving him into one of the Elements of his firt compoition; you could not now call him Man, but the Decoction thereof (Neither was mans limbs o hak'd with the cold fits of a Quartan Ague, as this ame quaking jelly was by his panick fear; ometimes he thought to leap out of the Window, & adventure an arm or a leg rather than run the hazard of loing â€” he knew not what; altering that reolution, he thought it better to cat himelf on his knees at the feet of his Mater, confeing his (not purpoed) fault, and implore his pardon; with this reolution, he opened the door, and eeing by the light of the Moon (which was jut then rien) the pallid and bloodles hue of his hivering Maters face, looking more like that of a Conjurer than one tranported with a jealous paion, recollected himelf and took courage to peak to him. Tradewel eeing his man in o great a confuion, could not but mile to himelf, asking him what was the matter? O Sir, aid he, your low trembling voice from without, and your frightful appearance within hath o diordered
me with fear, that I am like one beides himelf.

Although Tradewel was in his hirt half tarv'd with cold could not forbear laughing, nor would he loe the pleaure of dicouring with his man at preent, although he was ure his body would uffer for it by ome ditemper hereafter. Come Sirrah, aid he, thee pretences hall not erve your turn, I know your diimulation, and your ubtle practices, I know what contract you made with my maid, how, and when you were to meet, though you diappointed her, but that was, becaue you were afraid of my detecting your Roguery, knowing this night I watcht your appointment to prevent further michief.

The Cahier was all wonder and amazement; he could not imagine who hould dicover his dark deigns, unles the Devil had don't by declaring himelf his profet Enemy: it was but a folly to upect one or the other, or to blame any; it was now only expedient to make confeion and ask forgivenes, which as oon as he had done, his Mater granted him his requet, with this Provio, he hould never attempt the like again. But hold, aid Tradewel, there is omething more to be aid and done, and that is help me to one of your clean hirts, and whatever you think, peak not a word, as you tender your own welfare; let it uffice, that I tell you thus much, that I have been upon other Dicoveries this night than barely your lacivious appointment, but what they are, they mut be ecret to you.

The Cahier got him preently a clean hirt, the ooner to be rid of his Company, which as oon as Tradewel had put on, he return'd to his own Chamber, lying down by his Wives ide, with
as little noie as the gliding of a Snake over a mooth Marble; he was in a profound leep, as one extremely tired, making it appear by her (unuual) noring, the pleaure he took in leeping, and that he had travell'd that night every whit as far as her Husband. Yet though Tradewel was as cautious as might be of awakening her, yet he could not avoid the tumbling of her legs to and fro, agitated by ome pleaant fancies in her dream, which falling on his (as cold, as if they had been pickled in now, and laid on the Alps a whole Winter) made her uddenly tart out of her leep, no les tormented with that extreme cold, than others with the contrary Element; Tradewel hrunk from her, and he purued him, laying her hands on his face, breat, and thighs, and diembling her knowledge of his abence: My Dear, aid he, what means this trange and unuual coldnes? Art well? Prethee trike a light, I am confident that omething is amis; to which he replied, that he was in good health, and that his coldnes proceeded from the bed-cloaths tumbling off. That cannot be, aid he, the Bedtaffs would hinder any uch thing; and then laying her hands all about him, aid he, is it poible you can be o univerally cold, and in a warm bed with a warmer Bed-fellow, come abcond the truth no longer, and what e're it be, dicover it, and I will not be offended. If then you'l know the truth, Sweet-heart, aid he, I have of of late upected ome irregular practices between my Cahier and my maid Suan, and this night I was reolved to try whether I could detect them; to which he uddenly and martly replied, I now mut detect you: Is it not ufficient that you have a wife not loaded with years, her face not deform'd, her body
fruitful, and her heart faithful, but that you mut intrench on other mens proprieties? Surely Mr. Saleware and you becoming Copartners, it was not intended you hould go Partner in his Wives Commodities: Could any man in the world prove o ungrateful to two at once, one that he hould love beyond the world, a wife, the other which he hould affect the next thereto, a Friend? Would you be erv'd o your elf?

Tradewel had not a word to ay in his own vindication, but pleaded guilty to all that was alledg'd againt him, earnetly beeeching his Wife he would pas all by, and he would never commit the like again; upon that condition he forgave him, and the ooner, as knowing he was no loer by his infidelity.

The morning approaching, Mr. Saleware came and careed his Partner, thanking him for the tender care he had of his Wife in his abence, and that they both were much obliged to him for his love; Complements pat on all ides, and a general eeming atisfaction did o'repread the faces of them all, and now every one betook himelf to his proper buines: Only Suan could do no buines at all, becaue her buines was not done; he could not ret atisfied till he had ingled out her fale Lover; and therefore quickly found an opportunity, he firt acquainted him with the greatnes of her love, and how it was abued by him; and to be hort, if he would not tell her the whole truth of the occaion of this breach of promie, he would never indure him more. The Cahier hearing this ad entence, if he were not real in his Relation, and being re-inflam'd again with thoe adored eyes of hers, and her ininuating pleaing language (forgetting his Mitrees
threats) he tels her the naked truth, informing her, that as he was coming with no other intent than to fulfil his promie to her, by a mitake entring the wrong Chamber, he paid her due Tribute to her Mitres, who was left alone by her ungrateful Husband, who was gone to enjoy Mrs. Saleware in the abence of her Husband, his Maters Partner.

Suan was ready to ink down to hear that in all probability he had utterly lot her Sweet-heart, knowing like a cunning Baggage, that now adays love is les prevalent than interet: but prethee aid he, How did he receive thee? At firt, he thought me to be her Husband, till he perceived how many Barrs I had out-thrown him, and finding her mitake, he eem'd like a woman ditracted, complaining that her hitherto untainted Chatity was ruin'd, that I was a Villain, for being the Murderer thereof, and that he wondred with what impudence I durt approach her bed; I was forc't at length to vindicate my elf from that bold attempt, to tell her what love I had for you, for the acccomplihment of which we had appointed that night to receive the pawn on each ide of each others fidelity. And you have then, aid he, dicovered me to be the wonton ubject of her cenure and reproach: no matter, aid he. When he undertood that what was committed was by mitake, he eem'd atisi'd, and was thankful to Heaven that this mitake had reveng'd her Husbands infidelity; then he charg'd me to be ecret and be gone, and as a reward gave me this Ring; before I took my leave I enjoyn'd her to the ame ecrecie of our Amour.
