In the aurance that this is a truth, I do forgive what's pat, conditionally you ne'r enjoy your Mitres more.

Mr. Tradewel carried himelf now very obligingly to his Wife, and indifferently to his female Friend, and more than uual friendly to her Huband, but continually quarrelling with his Maid Suan, to the intent that he might make her weary of his Service, and o be gone; he perceiving this, was reolv'd peedily to make Hay whilet the Sun hin'd, and knew no better way to bring about her ends, then to carry her elf mot charmingly affectionate to her Friend, the Cahier, and to grant him every thing he deir'd; when he pleas'd he had the Command of her Bed, and dalliances with her where he pleas'd, and as often as he lited, and being now olely Regent over his affections (although now and then he accompanied his Mitres (more to pleae her than himelf) he reolved by his overthrow to raie her elf; and thus he plotted it: Notwithtanding the frowardnes of he â€¢ Mater towards her for her own benefit, he pretended a more than common repect to him, proteting more reallity of ervice than invention can well hammer out; making this her Prologue to her cunning deign; he tells him, he knows that he was educed, and led away by the crafty allurements of his man, and that he could not but yield after o many thouand Oaths and Vows of righting her wronged Virginity, that intead thereof, all his performances were continual lightings; and now at lat inquiring trictly into the caue of this udden alteration of his love, he upected that it might be occaioned by the hopes he hath of his Mitrees love towards him, that he had omething more than bare upition to make manifet what he aid, and that in a little time, if he pleaed, he doubted not but to make it apparent
how inconiderately his Wives love is miplaced on her Servant.

Mr. Tradewel heard this with no mall perturbation of minde, however being willing to know the truth hereof, he promied her a reward if he would make him a peedy dicovery thereof. In the proecution whereof, one night when Suan had got the Cahier in bed with her, and having according to cutome after tiring been ued to leep with her an hour or two (he being all this while his waking Centinel to raie him when it was time to return to his own bed) I ay, he then took the opportunity of conveying two Keys out of his Pocket, the one of his Till, where his Maters Cah lay, the other of his Trunck, which contain'd his wearing Apparel, with other things properly belonging; She opens his Trunk firt, by the help of a Candle he had placed underneath her bed in a dark Lanthorn, and there finds the chiefet thing he lookt for, the Ring which his Mitres had given him as a pledge of her love, he found what he lookt for, and therefore lockt the Trunck again, without diminihing any thing therein contain'd, but the Ring. After this he trips down the tairs oftly into the hop, and opening the Till, took out one hundred Guinny's, which was in a mall bag by its elf, and one hundred pound bag of ilver, locking the Till again, which money he hid in the Cellar, and o went up again to her own Chamber, putting the Keys into his Pocket, he not miing her all this while, being fat aleep. All things being effected without the leat remaining upition, he awak't her Lover, telling him he had over-indulg'd his humour in letting him leep o long, however he was well content to have no ret (and enjoy his
Company) o that he might have it; and o with a hug and a bus they parted.

In the morning early he got up, and taking the money he had hid (with an excue of going but half a dozen doors off) he carried it off, and put it into the hands of a very truty Friend of hers, and making very little tay, returns home.

By this time her Mater was up, who found her as formerly, very diligent in the Kitching, and being alone, ask'd her, what further progres he had made in the dicovery; I will tell you, aid he, within an hour, if you will be ure to tep out and be in again; in the mean time I will hew you a Ring, which your Wife gave her man; which by his knowledge thereof, increat his jealouie. He conented thereto, and he in the mean time teps up to her Mitres to know what he would be pleas'd to have for dinner: Ask your Mater aid her Mitres, forooth, aid he, he is gone (he told me as far as Blackwal, and it is quetionable whether he can come to dinner. Blackwal, how can that be! end up the Cahier to me, he will give me better information where he is gone than you can; I will rie by and by, in the mean time I'le think what to have for Dinner.

Suan was over-joy'd her plot took o well, and indeed but according to her expectation; for he oberv'd her Mitres always inquire where her Husband was, if gone out, how far, and then according to the ditance of place he knew how to imploy her time and exercie her elf with her man. Coming down he did not go immediately to acquaint the Cahier with his Mitrees Command, but taid ome time ere he told him, extracting from him at the ame time Protetations of Contancie.

Up he goes to his Mitres, but he had not been there long, e're Tradewel came in, & being inform'd by Suan how affairs tood, he went oftly up the tairs, and thruting at his Chamber-door, he found it lockt; he knockt again and again, but no anwer; till at lat he poke aloud, Open the Door, and that quickly too, or I'le force it open: Whereupon he came to the Door in her Smock, and did let him in; he needed not to have confet what he had bad been doing, the diorder he was in, proclaim'd more than her tongue could utter.

Tradewel in a rage askt her where her Minion was; he was o amaz'd, he could not pronounce one illable; hurried on with impatience, he earcht the room round, but found no body, till he lookt underneath the bed (the Mother would never have lookt for her Daughter in the Oven, but that he had been there her elf) and there he epied his truty Squire, having not room enough to kneel for pardon; as he was about to drag him out, his wife that had recalled her wandring pirits, took heart-a-grace, and taying her Huband by the leeve, aid, I pray Sir, be not too rah, conider it was your own cae once, and were you not glad by the ubtlety of a woman to ecape that eminent danger which hung over your head, pray Sir, let this Patern or reemblance of your late Condition intercede for him; your Politie availed you little in that treight, neither will his in this exigencie; you were preerv'd by your Mitrees wit and ubtlety, he is undone by my indicretion and folly, if you applaud the former commierate the later.

Thee melting, yet biting expreions took Tradewel off from the height of fury, o that his Revenge
knew not how to terminate any otherwie than intantly to call his Cahier to an account about the Cah committed into his charge; and therefore charg'd him to be gone immediately to that intent and purpoe.

The Cahier who was never call'd to an account before, by reaon of the large ecurity his Parents gave his Mater for his fidelity, which gave the greater liberty to his credulity, in aiting his Brethren who had ran out of Cah, and being concious how far he had ran out himelf, it tartled him almot as much as this unexpected urprize; as he was going down the tairs a udden reolution krept into his head to clear his accounts and free himelf from the approaching danger, he could not but in reaon expect would uddenly fall upon him, by one ingle act, and that was forthwith to acquit his Maters houe, and throw himelf upon the guidance of Fortune, which accordingly he put in execution; for immediately he got himelf out of the doors with as much hat and fear, as one that had made his ecape from a common confinement or his Keeper; not carrying any thing more than what he had about him.

The News was oon brought to his Mater Mr. Tradewel, who was not a jot troubled thereat, but rather rejoyc't that he was rid of a harer in his Marriage-rights, knowing withal how to give himelf atisfaction for what his Servant had ran out.

This coming to the ears of Suan, made her tranported with joy, how fully her revenge was extended, and how well paid he was for the exeecution thereof, being confident her Cheat could never in all probability be found out; beides her Mater to reward her Treachery, vail'd with the
pretence of fidelity gave her fifty pieces, with a promie he might continue as long as he pleas'd in hi, houe, with an augmentation of her Wages; he thankt him, and gave him only the hearing intending to tay no longer than he might make ome coniderable purchae, and o march off.

In puruance whereof, he ingled out Mrs. Saleware at a convenient time, and dicovered to her the knowledge of all thoe amorous Intrigues which pat between her and her Mater, intancing every remarkable particular, and laying it o home, that Mrs. Saleware could not but acknowledge them all truths by her ilence; having wrought her Plot o far, he reolv'd to drive the nail home to the head for what it was deigned for, and therefore told her, that the ruine of her credit lay at her dipoal, but for her part he was o tender of the Reputation of her Sex, that he corn'd to be a Traytor to its infirmities.

Mrs. Saleware that was apprehenive enough, and knew very well by the method of her dicoure what he aim'd at; rold her, he lookt upon her more dicreet than to make o great a ditraction in a Family he belong'd to, by peaking of uch things, which if known, the differences that would thence arie would never be reconcil'd; however aid he, to eal your everlating ilence, accept thee Guinneys, and my everlating friendhip, if not murder'd by your falhood, and o leaves her.

Suan carries this parcel to her former hoard of money, and not atisfied yet, was reolved to cat her net for more before he left fihing in this Pool. She now goes to her Mitres, and with tears (which he had always at Command) makes a ad Complaint for the los of her Love, telling her, that he
was betroath't to her, and had it not been for her diloyalty to her Husband, he might have enjoy'd him till; but now he was pat recovery, and though he had undertood all thoe amorous Entertainments from his own mouth which were enjoy'd between them, yet he rather chooe to uffer in his love, than tain the credit of her loving Mitres; that all he required at preent only was, that he would be pleas'd to revenge her on that dihonet, faithles, and lacivious woman, Mrs. Saleware, who was the ource and original of all her troubles, for had he not (aid he) conented to the loe embraces of your Husband, my Mater, your Servant and my Husband that hould be by a mitake in his abence, could never have obtain'd the opportunity of enjoying you by breaking his faith with me.

Mrs. Tradewel heard thee Complaints with no mall confuion and trouble of mind, but however to gratifie her own as well as her Servants revenge, he conented to do herein what he would advie her to. All that I requet you to do, aid Suan, is to acquaint her Husband how baely your Husband hath abued his Bed, but make him wear he will not dicover one tittle you do relate to him; aggravate every circumtance in uch manner, that you may make his jealouie well beyond all ene and reaon. This will put him upon trange extravagant abues at firt, each of which will be a tickling pleaure to ee them executed, and this in a little time alo will be the means to rid your elf of a Rival lodg'd within the bowels of all your concerns.

This advice was o well liked of by Mrs. Tradewel, that he could not ret till he had acquainted Mr. Saleware with this ecret, which in effect was
none at all, being known to more than two. Mr. Saleware when he heard it was ready to run ditracted, and could hardly be perwaded but that he would either lay violently hands on himelf or Wife immediately; but being qualified by his own reaon, and uch as Mrs. Tradewel produced, he deferr'd his revenge till another time Suan thinking he had done as mueh michief as he could, reolv'd to be packing, and therein followed the example of the Rats (according to Report) which will fly from a falling houe: She took her opportunity, and getting together ome of her Mitrees choice implements of gawdry, as a gold Watch, Pendents, Rings, a Neck-lace of Pearl, with other things of value, he tript off unupected, & abconded her elf for a while. Not long after Mr. Saleware confet a Judgment, or Warrant of Attorney to a pecial friend of his, for more by much than his own tock or Partners Mr. Tradewels would amount to; which was his firt revenge on his diloyal Friend, what revenging injuries he inflicted on his Wife, I cannot relate, only you may imagine what an abued Husband will do in uch a cae, when prompted thereto by jealouie and Revenge.

Mr. Tradewel looking on kis Wife as the occaion of this deperate and irregular coure, left her to the wide world, and went for Virginia, where he died, his wie in his abence being expoed to a great deal of miery, what through want and grief, died not long after.

Thus you ee how uddenly two flourihing families were brought to ruine by exorbitant lut and the ubtilty of a revengeful woman; but this was but the beginning or infancie of her early Projects, thouands whereof in the progres of her
life he nommitted far more cotorious than any hitherto related, I have not room to decribe them all, wherefore I hall briefly recount to you as many as I may.

After her running away from her Mater, he apparall'd her elf as richly and as modihly as mot of the female Gallants about the Town, and went by the name of Mrs. Craftsby, he took her lodging near to thoe places where the Gentry mot reorted, where he not only learn'd the counterfeit deportment of a Gentlewoman, but likewie by her Habit skrew'd her elf into the acquaintance of uch of her Sex, as were placed in the Spheres of Honety and Honour.

She pretended her elf the Relict of a Knight in Yorkhire, by which Lye he obtain'd the Honour of being called Madam, and the advantage of being Courted by men of good Etates, o many and o importunate, that her Lodgings from morning to night were eldom clear'd from one or more amorous viitants; and although by the mot fiery he was hotly beet, yet he would not urrender; till fearing he might withtand her better fortunes, he yielded to the importunities of a Gentleman well tricken in years, but one that had the bet etate of all her Suiters. They were not long married, before the old Gentleman found her out what he was, not only a Cheat, but an inatiate Whore to boot, having now a Cloak for her unbridled Lechery; the knowledge whereof made a eparation between them; however he ued for Alimony, and forc't from him a competent maintenance; he now no longer hid her elf under the vail of eeming Chatity, but walkt with Vice barefoot every where; and now for profit as much as pleaure, he protituted her
elf to any thing that had money; nay, a Dog, if he had but a hilling in his mouth: By thee lacivious excees he was o often clapt, that he became a meer Hopital of Dieaes, and was now no longer in a Condition to maintain the reputution of a handome Whore, being metamorphoed into the likenes of a loathome and deformed Bawd.

Yet till he had her Wits about her; and conidering he could do nothing of her elf, unles he procured ome aitance of other; he trotted all the Town over to find out one fit for her purpoe; Pat as he would have it, going into a inning-houe near Whetstones-Park, he found a young Plyer there, whoe Countenance promied every thing he deired, and having dicourt her, found her what he eem'd to be, and her own Niece: whereupon promiing her greater advantages than he could reap there, he allur'd her to her Houe, where as Partners they liv'd together.

Her Name was Mitres Wheedle, a plump ucculent Girl, with a face no way contemptible, he had a quaint Wit, a charming Tongue, and an humour o brisk a â€¢ d gay, as if no other Elements but fire and Air had club'd to her compoition; thee attractions, and her petulant Deportment, drew on a number of Smell-mocks, which courted her for that Trifflle which men o much covet to enjoy and women to be rid of; but he like a â€¢â€¢ nning Market-woman plotting to ell her Ware <> the bet advantage, received them all with pro
â€¢â€¢â€¢ ing Smiles, & dipened the ame indeared Ca
â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢ es to every one. This brought her in a large Harvet of preents, and the better to draw them in, he would for uch a Ring, Bracelet, or Necklace,
&c. promie ome Cully the great kindnes; if they were loath to purchae in at o dear a rate, he woul fall in her price, choing rather to play at mall game than it out.

In a little time he was o generally known that he was compell'd to tudy new Artifices to allure in Cutomers, and thoe which he refus'd at firt, he was now glad to acept of, o that the houe became the receptable of all forts of Cullies; not only the Bleeding-Cully, but the Ruff-Cully, the Dark-Cully, the Flogging-Cully, and the Fencing-Cully; in hort, no perons how wicked oever (Whores, Rogues, Pads, Gilts, Files) but were her daily Companions.

This houe at length grew o notoriouly infamous, that it was known and pointed at almot by every Boy which pat that way. Hereupon the Jutice takes Mrs. Craftsby the Bawd, to a evere account, and upon examination found her o guilty (not only for Bawdry, but all manner of Roguery, frequently entertaining uch in her houe, who being detected there, were afterwards hang'd) I ay, for thee coniderations, the Jutice made her Mittimus and ent her to Prion; Mrs. Wheedle having had timely notice hereof, made her ecape, and oon after the commitment of her Partner, old all he had, and not contented with this, he turn'd Night-Walker, whilet in the daytime he exercied other Profeions belonging to the ancient Society of Tyburn: Sometimes he plaid the part of a File, and did it with dexterity, even to admiration; he was a cleanly conveying Shop-lift, having a very large Pocket or Wallet underneath her under Petticoat, in which he would, cheapning Commodities in divers Shops convey inenibly omething of every
thing; but at lat endeavouring to play the Girl in a Tavern with one of her Bully-Huffs, they were both dicovered in the act, carried before a Jutice, and by him ent to Newgate; at the enuing Seions, Mrs. Craftsby the Bawd received the Sentence of Carting, Mrs. Wheedle and her Gallant, of being carted to Tyburn, where they ended their wretched lives, whilet the other lived more hated than the lat were pitied.

By this Story (which is a very truth) you may ee the evil Conequences which heavily wait on Lut and uch exorbitant actions; and therefore my advice is to all, that they imitate the Aegyptian Niceta, by ayling by the Scylla of carnal pleaure, and the Caribdis of incontinencie; and yet not endanger the Shipwrack of their Chatity; and I could with I knew how to teach you to drink out of Circes Cup, and not be converted into Swine; & how you may hear the Syrens weet & charming voices, and not yet be not inchanted by them. The bet Rules I can give you are contain'd in this Ditich:

l.hi: Otia, Mena, Libri, Vaga, lumina Verba, Sodales,
Hoec tolle, banc minue, hos muta, boec claude, hac fuge, vita hos.

lg.l: Sloath, Dainties, idle Fellows, wandring Looks,
Shun with all peed, and change your wanton Books.

div.p: To begin with Idlenes, Otia telle, be not unimploy'd, for that is the fittet eaon the Devil hath to perwade thee to any thing that is evil; and therefore that man qui nil agit (which doth nothing) may be truly aid, male agere, to do ill.

l.hi: Otia i toll as peri â€¢ re Cupidinis are us

lg.l: Shun Sloth, and Cupids Bow thou'lt break
And's Torch contemn'd will hine but weak.

div.p: Next Menam minue, that is, pamper not your elf by feeding too high. Adultery was never the Daughter of Temperance; Chatity ever lives more ecure in low Cottages, than in ublime Pallaces.

Beware of obcene Books, as Drollery, wanton Poems, lacivious Stories, &c. Ovid himelf, Loves-School-mater, gives good advice, when he faith, â€” Teneros ne tange Poet as. And yet his Art of Loving, or rather his Art of Bawdry, with wanton Martial, lacivious Catull us, Tibull us and Propertius are taught in Schools publickly; wherefore Ite mali verus animam qui perditis, ite.

Fourthly, Vaga lumina claude. Lut ometimes creeps into the Soul by a Kis, or through the Ears, but chiefly through the Eyes. Hence proceeded that Law of Zeleucus, that punihed Adultery by the los of the eyes, as firt promoter of that inful Act.

lg.l: â€” ruitque videndo.

div.p:
Latly, fuge Sodales, I mean hun only bad Companions. He that continually wallows with Swine in the mire, mut expect to be in the ame filthy condition. The Plague is not more preadingly
Infections than ill manners. Example is ever more prevalent than Precept, and one cabbed heep will infect the whole flock.

lg.l: â€” Sicut Grex totus in agris
nius cabie cadit â€”

div.p: Wherefore he that is ingaged in a vitious Society, let him forake it, and he that is inconcern'd therein, let him have a care how he falls into it.

l.hi: Hinc Niger est hunc, tu Romane c â€¢ veto.

div.p: Be of that mind that Apollonius Tyanaeus was of, when he deir'd the Gods, that they would give him uch a dicerning mind, as Nocere bonos, malos vitare, to know the good, and hun the bad.
To conclude, make other men your Example, let you be made an Example to others.
MISCELANIES, AND OTHER JOVIAL PARADOXES OR, THE Canters-Academy OF COMPLEMENTS.

div.head: MISCELANIES, and other JOVIAL PARADOXES: Or, the Canters-Academy OF COMPLEMENTS.
div.p: QUetion. What is an idle Jutice of Peace like?
Anwer. The Picture of St. George on the Sign-Pot with the Sword in his hand drawn to no purpoe.
Q. How may a Fool reemble a wie Man?

A. By concealing of his folly with ilence; for he cannot peak, that knows not wiely and eaonably how to hold his tongue: the common aying is, Vir apit qui pauca loquitur; which may be turned clean contrary, to, Vir loquitur; qui pauca apit.
Q. What's he that hath a fine wit in jest?
A. He that is a Fool in earnet.
Q. How comes it to pas that tall men for the mot part are not wie?
A. For that the length of their bodies proceeds from great moiture and heat: but drines engen dreth Widom in man; and your Garrets have for the mot part nothing but lumber in them.
Q. Whether doet thou profes thy elf a Knave or a Fool?

A. A Fool at a Womans ervice, and a Knave at a mans: thus I do ditinguih, I would cozen the man of his Wife, and do his drudgery, and I would preent his Wife my bet repects to do her ervice, o I might ubcribe my elf both Knave and Fool. Well, well, God give them Widom that have it; & thoe that are Fools, let them ue their Talent.
Q. What ditinction do you make betwixt a Friend and a Foe?

A. Marry thus Sir, he that would eem a Friend and Praies me when I do not deerve it, makes an As of me; now my Foe tells me plainly I am an As; o that I am the wore for my Friend and the better for my Foe; for Plain-dealing, till of late was ever counted a Jewel.
Q. How hould a man behave himelf to his Friends?
A. As if in time they might become his Enemies.
Q. What may a ample fellow in good Cloaths be compared to?
A. At Cinnamon-Tree, the Bark is more worth than the whole Body.
Q. How are great Eaters aid to be the mot valiant men?
A. Becaue they never fight but with a good Stomach.
Q. Why are thoe that wear long hair in the readiet way to make Fryars?
A. Becaue they promie to themelves bald Crowns without the help of a Barber.
Q. What men are dangerous in a Commonwealth?
A. Thoe that affect Novelties.
Q. What was the Opinion of Pythagoras concerning wild Fowl?
A. That the Soul of our Grandam might happily inhabit in a Bird; yet am not I afraid to kill a Woodcock, for fear I hould dipoes the Soul of my Grandam.
Q. But what think you of his Opinion?
A. I think nobly of the Soul, and no way approve of his Opinion.
Q. Why is it aid to be no Charity to give a blind man an Almes?
A. Becaue he would be glad to ee him hanged that relieves him.
Q. On whom ought not benefits to be betowed?

A. Not to young Children, nor to old men, nor to dihonet perons: becaue young Children have not the wit to apprehend a Courteie done them before they come to the Age of Knowledge; and Old men do quickly forget them; nor upon dihonet perons, for they are too ubtle to requite them.
Q. Why do the Women in Newgate beg inging?
A. Becaue Newgate is a Cage of Canary-birds.
Q. Why is Prion a good Instrument of Reformation?
A. Becaue it makes many Rogues and lewd Fellows tay'd men.

Q. Do you not wonder that there hould be o many
Pick-Pockets about t â€¢ e t â€¢ eets, notwithtanding that there is a Watch in every corner?
A. That's all one, for a Pick-Pocket would as willing â€¢ y meet with a Watch as any thing ele.
Q. Why is a Midwife o commendable a Trade?
A. Becaue they live not by the hurts of others as Chyrurgions do; nor by the falling out of Friends as Lawyers do: but by the agreement betwixt party and party.
Q. What's the best remedy for a woman that's troubled with the falling icknes?
A. It may be cured by a pell of the only croing her Legs. Probatum et.
Q. Why did the Ancients paint Fortune with a double fore-head, the one ide bald, and the other hairy; and why alo blind?

A. The backide bald ignified adverity, when we do not take opportunity by the fore-head top; the hairy part Properity, which we enjoy when he pleaes. She is pictured blind, becaue many times he betows her favours upon unworthy perons, and for that he blindeth her puruers.
Q. Why do Foot-boys for the mot part wear linnen tockings?
A. Becaue they are troubled with running Legs.
Q. What do everal orts of Colours ignifie?

A. White ignifieth Truth or Innocencie, it reembleth the Light; Green, Hope, or Youth, Yellow, Gladnes, or Jealouie; Straw Colour, Plenty; Orange, Cuckold, or Covenant-Colour ignifies diminution of Honour, or Spiteful; Blew, the Scotch-bonnet-Colour, Treachery: Carnation, Sorrow; Violet, Incontancie; the Azure is mot pleaant to the eyes of any colour, becaue Nature in the Azure eemed as if he had
meant all the ret; Red, betokeneth the noblenes of Courage; Purpure, or Purple, was a Colour in Ancient times only worn by Kings and Princes; Tawny is a Colour of Worhip, mot commonly born amongt the French-Gentry; Murrey in Blazon-Sanguine, is a Colour in ancient times appertaining to the Prince of Wales; All mixt or midling Colours, are reckoned more Noble or Ignoble by participation either of the Nobility of White which is Light, or of black which is a deprivation of Light.
Q. Why is a Cholerick man aid to be no wier than an Hore?
A. Becaue he cannot bridle his Paion.
Q. Why is a Miller aid to be the fittet Husband for a Scold?
A. Becaue when the Mill goes, though her tongue be never o loud, it cannot be heard.
Q. Why are Scriveners aid to be hard-hearted Fellows?
A. Becaue they never rejoyce o much as when they put others into Bonds.
Q. Why is it better to fall into the Claws of Crows and Ravens than of Flatterers?
A. Becaue Crows and Ravens do but eat us when we are dead, but flatterers devour us alive.
Q. Why had a Barber more reaon to be honet and trusty than another Trade?
A. Becaue whooever employs him, though but for a Hairs matter, puts his life into his hands.
Q. Why is a Barber aid to be uch an active man?
A. Becaue if once he take out his wooden Comb, he will o box a man about his Ears, yet he hall take no exceptions, for he hall carce feel it.
Q. Why do many hold that there is a World in the Moon?
A. Becaue they are Lunaticks.
Q. How may a man ue Tobacco that it may do him good?
A. He mut keep a Tobacco-hop and ell it.
Q. Why may Tobacco hops be aid for to be uch dangerous places for to come into?
A. Becaue there's no man that ever frequented them, but that he moakt for it.
Q. Why is a Hypocrite aid to be odious to God, to man, and to the Devil.
A. God hates him becaue he is not what he eems; Man hates him becaue he eems what he is not; and the Devil hates him becaue he eems not what he is, a very Raskal.
Q. Why are Smiths of all other Trades aid to be the mot irregular and wicked?
A. For that they never think themelves better employ'd than when they addict themelves to their Vices, according to the old Vere.
I heard that Smug the Smith for Ale and Spice Sold all his Tools, and yet he kept his Vice.
Q. What's the firt Commodity a young Shopkeeper puts off?
A. His Honety.
Q. Why do Souldiers love Beef o well.
A. Becaue 'tis powder'd.
Q. Why are Muquetiers of all other Souldiers aid to be the mot lazy?
A. Becaue they are always at their Ret.
Q. Why do Lawyers-Clerks write uch wide Lines?

A. 'Tis done to keep the Peace, for if the Plaintiff
and the Defendant hould be in the next, the lines being too cloe, they might perhaps fall together by the Ears.
Lay John there, lay Lilburn there about,

p.hi: For if they both hould meet they would fall out.

div.p: Q. What may a good Client be compared to?
A. A tudy Gown, that fits in the cold himelf to keep his Lawyers warm.
Q. Why did Nature allow of Mercury?
A. To make Alchymits Fools, and covetous men poorer.
Q. Why do we uually ay that the Philoophersstone and need to turn all Metals into Gold?
A. Becaue the tudy of it turns all a mans Gold into Metal
Q. What is a Prodigal like?
A. A Bruh which pends it elf to make others go handome.
Q. Why is a Hangman aid to be one of a contemplative life?
A. Becaue he never goes to work, but he is put in mind of his own end.
Q. Which of the two is more ufferable a Tyrant, or a Hangman?

A. You might as well have aid Oliver or Dun; I hall give it clearly for Dun; the Hangman, he executed thoe that were condemned by Law; but Oliver that High Court of Jutice-Devil caued them to be put to death that were innocent without any Law.
Q. How are Painters call'd cunning Fellows?
A. Becaue they have a Colour for whatoever they do.
Q. How are Trumpeters aid to be ubject to ickly Distempers?
A. Becaue commonly when they are mot in health they will fall a ounding.
Q. Of all things that you know which do you eteem most precious?

A. As for the word precious, I look upon it as an Epithite belonging to Stones. I confes I love a Diamond, a Ruby, an Emerald, &c. But above all precious tones, there are none like thoe which make a perfect man, and a Maid a Mother.
Q. Why do fat men love their eae o much?
A. Becaue the Soul in a fat body lies oft, and is therefore loath to rie.
Q. Why have many men no Beards?
A. Becaue they have their pores o great, that the Nutriment wherewith their Hair hould be nourihed and entertained is conumed of adut and burnt vapours: To the Tune of, Let Simons Beard alone:
div.l: Let Simons Beard alone,

l.hi: For Beard he never had one.

div.p: Q. Wherefore is it that we are for the mot part ill conceited of them that have their Hair of one colour and their Beard of another?

p.U: hall anwer for me in his Epigram againt Zoilus, Englihed thus:

div.l: Zoilus red headed and black bearded too;

l.hi: What quint-eyed and tump-footed in thy hooe?
Thus mark'd, thou art a Knave, or ele there's none;
Thou art not good, ten thouand 'tis to one.

div.p: Q. Why are Citizens Wives o affected with Hats?
A. Becaue they love to be covered.
Q. What is the Diet o much eteemed of by Citizens wives?

A. Though they love fleh better than fih, yet for their better varieties they o diet themelves, that at Noon they feed upon Carps, at Night upon Cods-head, and when they go abroad, they are very well pleaed with Place.
Q. Why have Hots uually uch red Noes?
A. They are given them by Nature, to hew to the world an experiment of the virtue of what they ell.
Q. Why is a Tooth-drawers aid to be an unconcionable Trade?
A. Becaue he takes away thoe things whereby every man is aid to get his living.
Q. Why are Saylors o eldom rich?
A. Becaue they are never o well pleaed as when they go down the Wind fatet.
Q. Why are Glaiers aid to be good Arbitrators?
A. Becaue they are continually compoing of Quarrels; and unfit to be Contables, becaue they are contant Quarrellers.
Q. Why are Fidlers compared to Camelions?
A. Becaue they live by the Air.
Q. Why are they called unfortunate men?
A. Becaue they do all againt the Hair.
Q. How are Players aid to be Philoophical?

A. Becaue they are better contented in their Rags, when they get Money by the Beggars-Buh, or the Jovial Crew, then when they act in their bet Cloathes a Courtiers Play, though of an Emperour, and it doth not take, to get them o much Money.
Q. How may Coblers be aid to be good men?
A. Becaue they et men upright, and are ever mending of Soles.
Q. Why are Carpenters aid to be civil, well informed, and governed men as any in a Commonwealth?
A. Becaue they never do their buines without Rule.
Q. Why are Tapters aid to be well eteemed?
A. Becaue they are not only of High Calling, but alo of great Reckoning.
Q. Why are Printers aid to be the mot lawles men in a Kingdom?
A. Becaue they commit Faults cum Privilegio.
Q. Why are Carriers aid to be wie men?
A. Becaue they will not meddle with any thing but they will know of what moment or waight it is.
Q. How is a Cook aid to be a man of the wort digestion?
A. Becaue as oon as he hath eaten his meat, he will be ure to pit it up again.
Q. What Spice doth a City-Sergeant love bet?
A. Mace.
Q. Why is he that draws Beer not called a Drawer, as well as he that draws wine?
A. Becaue the Beer makes a man but pis, but 'tis the Wine that makes him draw.
Q. What may a Taylor be chiefly commend â€¢ for?
A. For one of the mot anctified Members of a Common-wealth; for how many crooked and untoward bodies doth he make treight, that they may be the uprighter in their Lives and Converations.
Q. Why are Taylors like Woodcocks?

A. Becaue of their long Bills; and the long time before they are paid, he that pays them is
a Woodcock that doth not make them horter by the one half, and then they will be long enough in all Concience.
Q. What is a Drunkard like?

A. A Fool, a Mad man, and a Drowned Man: one Draught too much makes him a Fool, the econd makes him a mad man, and a third full Flagon Drowns him; the Crowner is the only man at that time fit to fit upon him.
Q. Why do the eyes of a <> for the mot part water?

A. It proceeds from the humors that the Drink hath engendred in the Brain, wherewith feeling it elf loaden, it endeth the ame again to the eyes, which are full of pores, as if they wept he hould be uch a Beat.
Q. Why do thoe that are drunk in beholding of one thing think that they ee many?

A. This ari â€¢ th from the continual and udden motion of the eyes, proceeding from exhalations and vapours; o the jealouie of the Cuckold makes him imagine that there is one a bed with his Wife, when there is only one hid under the Bed; and to imagine there is ome body in the room, when he can find none there forooth, but is good wife and himelf.
Q. How doth a Drunka â€¢ d make himelf known to the ober men of this life?

A. By the Pimples of his face, the rich Rubies on his Noe, the rednes of his Eyes, the trembling of his Body, the tink of his Breath, and latly, by his expatiating and taggering, by which he eems to claim a right to the Kings whole high way to tumble, fall, or lie in the Kennel, or any other dirty place where his heavy head weighs him down.
Q. What aid the Drunkard to thoe that pe â€¢ waded him to pay his money, and not to put himelf to o publike digrace as to it in the Stocks?
A. Good ober People, quoth â€¢ he, I thank you kindly, but I hall not do o, few <> are bet, ret you contented, that money I hould pay not to it here, will make me drunk three or four times more.
Q. What difference is there betwixt a Drunkard and a Brewers-hore drawing of a Dray laden with full barrels of Beer?
A. No other, but that the Drunkard hath all the load of drink in his belly, and the Hore all on back.
Q. Why are bitter Almonds eaten in the time of tipling, aid to preerve for a good pace of time from Drunkennes?

A. Becaue they dry the body, hinder the filling of the veins, and reit the trength of the Wine; but uch as receipts do for the mot part obtruct the tender and more friendly operations of Nature are dangerous; the bet remedy againt Drunkennes is Sobriety. Probatum et.
Q. Why are not Women o oon Drunk; but old folks uddenly oovercome with Wine?

A. Becaue the Wine remains longer in the tomachs of old People, they being dry by nature; even as the water doth in a trough of wood, dry and half putrifi'd: but women are cold and moit, by means whereof, they do the better reit the force of the wine, and withal they have whisking water-works for evacuation.
Q. What are the Companiens of Bacchus?
A. I hall anwer with the Poet for his Drunkards:
Panthers, Tygers, Satyrs, follow Bacchus; (us. <> Lust, fury, thee and the Devil to boot will thwack
Q. Can there be no remedy for this Vice?

A. Plautus was of the mind, that it was eaier to dye Ivory to perfect black with Ink, which cannot be; Horace (though he was a Drunkard himelf) was of Opinion that a man may ooner part two Bulls in ight, than prevail to tint two Drunkards of their Liquor; they have a Song which ignifies no les:

lg.l: I will, I will be mad, &c.

div.p: Q. Who are thoe that draw death out of which others preerve life?
A. The Drunkard and the Glutton.
Q. What is the pleaure of Drunkennes?
A. Small Beer in the morning.
Q. Whether is a fault committed in Drunkennes to be punihed or remitted?

A. He that in Drunkennes committeth any offence is worthy of a double punihment: firt, for being drunk, next, for the injury committed; according to the common aying, He that kills a man when he is Drunk, mut be hanged when he is ober.
Q. What may come into thy mind by recording of the Muical Vowels, Ut, Re, Me, Fa, Sol, La, M â€¢ .

A, The Cutome of Drunkards when they d â€¢â€¢ nk, they begin to quaff at t, avingly; and Re, regularly; at Me, marvellouly; they hold on to
drink in Fa, familiarity; in Sol, olemnly; but always conclude in La, Mi becaue the end of Drunkennes is lamentable and mierable.
Q. Why do Drunkards begin from halves te whole ones, and from Pints to Gallons, as if they were at the Dicipline of the Old Bayly, from Calves to Bulls and from Bulls to Calves.

A. Not without Reaon (till without Reaon) for leer Draughts cannot o oon intoxicate as the great ones: Nature would be diturbed by the greater quantitins of Draughts, but by the leer (as it were by ue) he will bear â€¢ he greater; as Milo carried his Calf, and by continual Cutome carried him till he was an Oxe; and Drunkards are o often from home, that oftentimes before they can reel thither, their foreheads are o branched, that they can carcely get their Horns in at their own doors.
Q. What Employments, or Places of Command have any of this Society of Drunkards at Sea-ervice? Who is Admiral amongt them of the narrow Seas?
A. He that utters his Stomach in his next follows Boots.
Q. Who is the Vice-Admiral?
A. He that pieth under the Table on their Shooes and Stockings.
Q. Who is Mater of a Ship?
A. He that is flawed in the Company before the ret.
Q. Who is Maters Mate?
A. He that is the econd who is drunk at the Table.
Q. Who is Swabber?
A. He that like a loven pils his Liquor upon the Table.
Q. Who is Pyrat of the Narrow Seas?
A. He that privately and cloely tealeth his Liquor.
Q. Who is Mater-Gunner?
A. He that is troubled with the Hickup.
Q. Who is the Cook?
A. He that is till moaking with a Pipe at his Noe.
Q. Who is Trumpetter?
A. He that belcheth either backward or forword.
Q. What other Officers, have they in Repect and Dignity, Civil or Martial?
A. Every Office is filled and thronged.
Q. What are their Civil Officers, who is their Mayor-Domo or Grand Steward?
A. He that is unruly in his Cups, waggers, flings Pots and Drawers down tairs, breaks Glaes, and beats the Fidlers about the room.
Q. Who is Mr. Comptroler?
A. He that cuts down igns and buhes.
Q. Who is Principal Secretary?
A. He that wins the favour of his Hotees-Daughter to lie with her.
Q. Who is Mr. of the Ceremonies?
A. He that tands upon his trength and begins new Healths.
Q. Who is Oliver, or Mater of the Novelties?
A. He that begins new frolicks.
Q. Who is a Mr. of Mirule?
A. He that flings Cuhions, Napkins, Trenchers, Pint-Pots, Quart-Pots, Tobacco-Pipe, &c. about room.
Q. Who is Mr. of the Wardrobe.
A. He that wanting Money, pawns his Cloak.
Q. Who is Clerk of the Kitching?
A. He that calls for Rahers, pickled Oyters, Anchovies, &c.
Q. Who is Proctor?
A. He that talks much and peaks Nonene.
Q. Who is Regiter?
A. He that tells tedious and long Tales.
Q. Who is publlick Notary?
A. He that takes the Tale out of anothers mouth.
Q. What are their Martial Preferments; who amongt them is Colonel of a Regiment?
A. He that drinks in his Boots and gingling Spurs.
Q. Who is Captain of a foot Company?
A. He that drinks in ilk Stockings and ilk Garters.
Q. Who is Marhal of the Field?
A. He that flings Pottle and Quart-pots down the tairs.
Q. Who is Mr. of the Ordnance?
A. He that begins three Healths together round the Table.
Q. Who is Camp Mater?
A. He that calls firt for a Looking-glas.
Q. Who is Corporal of the Field?
A. He that waheth the Faggots with piing in the Chimney.
Q. Who is Drum Major?
A. He that thunders in the room and beats the Drawer.
Q. Who is the Enign-Bearer?
A. He that looks red and Colours in his drink.
Q. Who is Gentleman of a Company?
A. He that thruts himelf into a Company, and hangs upon others.
Q. Who is Lanpreado?
A. He that keeps Company, and hath but two pence to pend.
Q. Who is Sutler?
A. He that pockets up Gloves, Knives and Handkercheifs.
Q. Who is an old Souldier?
A. He that drinks three days and nights together. Exempli gratia. H.
Q. Who is an Intelligencer?
A. He that wears, and lyes in his drink.
Q. What Orders have they amongt them for their better Government? Who is Tenant amongt them in Fee-imple?
A. He that makes himelf a laughing-tock to the whole Company.
Q. Who are Tenants in Dower?
A. When two or three Women meet twice or thrice a week to take a Goips Cup.
Q. Who is a Free-holder?
A. He whoe Wife goes with him to the Alehoue.
Q. Who is Tenant at Will?
A. He whoe Wife ues to fetch him home.
Q. Who is Foreman of the Jury?
A. He that ingroeth all the talk to himelf.
Q. What are their Penal Statutes, Forfeitures and W â€¢ its?

A. No man ought to call a good Fellow a Drunkard; but at any time he ees a defect in his Neighbour'ow; he may without a forfeit ay, he is foxt, he is flaw'd, fluter'd, cup hot, cut in the leg or back, he hath een the French King, or, His Mother, he hath wallowed a Hare, or White-foot tumbled him backwards, he hath bit his Grannam, he is bit by a barn Weeel, &c.
Q. What is their Writ of, By what Right?
A. If a Drunkard its long in the Tavern and hall be fetch'd home by his Wife.
Q. What are the Books that they chiefly tudy.

A. Some of them are of the old Tranlation as Tankard, the Black-Jack, the Quart-pot rib'd, &c. Thoe of the New Tranlation, are, the Tug, Mug, Bottle, Beaker, Single-Can â€¢ e, or Black-pot, Bran.+dy-bottle, with Pipes ready fill'd with Tobacco
Q. Who is he that tudies the Metaphyicks?
A. He that builds Catles in the Air.
Q. Who is he that hudies Comography?
A. He that brags of his Travels. Ir. B.
Q. Who is an expert Geometrician?
A. He that reels from one ide of the kennel (being led) and falls into the High-way.
Q. Who is a good Navigator?
A. He that going homewards falls in the dirt, or Ditch with a Gown.
Q. What are the Cutomes of this Learned Society of Drunkards, which they have ordained like the Laws of the Medes and Perians, to be unalterable?

A. Not to drink to any man, if a Woman be in preence. Not to drink to the Tapter, or Drawer, upon pain of drinking twice. To keep the firt man, and to know to whom you drink. To have a care to ee your elf pledg'd. That you ee the health go round.
I hall break up School with Anacreon, the Poets drunken Veres.

l.hi: The parched Earth drinks the Rain,
Trees drink off that ag ain:
Rivers the Se as do quaff,
And when the Health is done;

div.head: SONGS In Fahion, Since the publihing the lat New Academy of Complements.

lg.head: Captain Digby's Farewel.
lg.l: FArewel fair Amida. my Joy & my Grief;
In vain I have lov'd you, and hop'd no relief:
Undone by your Virtue, too trickt and evere;
Your Eyes gave me Love, and you gave me Depair.
Now call'd by my Honour, I eek with content,
The Fate which in pity you would not prevent.
To languih in Love, were to find by delay
A Death, that's more welcome the peediet way.
On Seas, and in Battles, in Bullets, and Fire,
The danger is les, than in hopeles deire.
My deaths-wound you gave me, though far off I were;
My fall from your ight, not to cat you a Tear,
But if a kind Flood or a Wave hould convey,
And under your Window my body would lay;
The Wound on my Breat when you happen to ee,
You will ay with a figh 'twas given by me.

lg.head: A Lover dying with delight.
lg.l: WHilt Alexis lay pret, in her arms he lov'd bet;
With his hands round her neck, and his head on her breat,
He found the firt pleaures too tay,
And his Soul in the Tempet was flying away.
When Celia aw this, with a igh and a kis
She cri'd, Oh, my Dear! am I rob'd of my blis,
'Twas unkind to your love, and unfaithfully done,
To leave me behind you, and die all alone.
The Youth though in hat, and breathing his lat,
In pity di'd lowly, whil't he di'd more fat,
Till at length he cri'd, now my Love, now let us go,
Now die my Alexis, and I will die too.
Thus intranc'd they did lie, till Alexis did try,
To recover more breath, that again he might die,
Thus often they di'd, oh! the more they did o,
The Nymph di'd more quick, and the Shepheard more â€¢ low.

lg.head: The Lover in a Quandary.
lg.l: ALl day do I it inventing,
While I live o ingle alone,
Which way to wed to my contenting,
And yet can reolve upon none.
There's a Wench whoe Wealth would inrich me.
But he not delights me:
There's a Wench whoe wealth doth inrich me.
There's anothers Eyes do bewitch me;
But her fahion frights me.
He that herein
Ha's a Traveller been,
And at length in his longing ped,
What hall I do,
Tell me whom, I hall wooe,
For I long to be lutily Wed.
Shall I with a Widow marry?
No, no, he uch watch will bear,
To py how my elf I do carry.
I hall always live in fear:
Shall I to a Maid be a Wooer:
Maydens are lov'd of many:
Knowing not whom to be ure,
Are very unure to any.
Marry to Youth,
There is love without Truth;
For the Young cannot long be jut.
And Age if I prove,
There's Truth without Love,
For the Old are too cold to lut.

lg.head: An Item for Marriage.
lg.l: TO Friend and to Foe,
And to all that I know,
That to Marriage etate do prepare;
Remember your days,
In everal ways
Are troubled with orrow and care.
For he that doth look
In the marri'd mans Book
And read but his Items all over,
Shall find them to come
At length to a Sum,
Shall empty Pure, Pocket and Coffer.
In patimes of Love
When their labours do prove,
And the fruit beginneth to kick;
For this and for that,
And I know not for what,
The Woman mut have or be ick.
There's Item et down
For a looe bodi'd Gown;
In her longing you mut not deceive her:
For a Bodkin, a Ring,
Or the other fine things,
For a Whisk, a Scarf, or a Beaver.
Deliver'd and well,
Who is't cannot tell;
Thus whil't the Child lies at the Nipple,
There's Item for Wine
'Mongt Goips o fine,
And Sugar to weeten their Tipple.
There's Item, I hope
For Water and Soap,
There's Item for Fire and Candle:
For better and wore,
There's Item for Nure
The Babe to dres and to dandle.
When waddled in lap,
There's Item for Pap,
And Item for Pot, Pan, and Ladle;
A Corral with Bells,
Which cutome compels,
And Item ten Groats for a Cradle.
With twenty odd Knacks,
Which the little One lacks;
And thus doth t â€¢ y pleaure bewray thee:
But this is the port
In Country and Court;
Then let not thee Patimes betray thee.

lg.head: A Sigh for She knows not what.
lg.l: TO little or no purpoe I pent many days
In ranging the Park, the Exchange, and the Plays;
Yet ne'r in my rambles till now did I prove
So lucky, to meet with the man I could love.
Now oh! how I'm pleas'd to think of the man
That I find I mut love, let me do what I can.
How long I hall love him, I can no more tell
Than had I a Feaver, when I hould be well;
My paion hall kill me before I will hew it;
And yet I would give all the World he did know it.
Then oh! how I igh! when I think he hould wooe me;
I cannot deny, what I know, would undo me.

lg.head: The pleaant Dream.
lg.l: LAt night I dreamed of my Love,
When leep did overtake her,
It was a ptetty drowie Rogue,
She lept, I durt not wake her.
Her Lips were like to Corral, red,
A thouand times I kit'em;
And a thouand mere I might have toll'n,
She never could have mit'em.
Her criped Locks like threds of Gold
Hung dangling or'r the Pillow;
Great pity was that one fair,
Should ever wear th'Green-willow.
I folded down the Holland-heet,
A little below her Belly;
But what I did you ne'r hall know,
Nor is it meet to tell yee.
Her Belly's like to yonder Hill,
Some call it Mount of Pleaure;
And underneath there prings a Well,
Which no mans depth can meaure.

lg.head: Not a Word of the Pudding.
lg.l: Y'Are undone, ye Women in Town,
If with peed you prevent not your ruine:
The pride of your Fleh mut come down,
Here are Plots and evere ones a brewing.
Whil't like Cats you play with your Tails,
To be thought to care little for ours:
Youmind not how drinking prevails,
And much leens the value of yours.
Inflam'd with our Wine, we didain
To remember the Chains we have worn,
And till you dou do prize them again,
Your repentance hall equal your corn.
You may think, Dear Hearts, what you pleae,
We're reolv'd to dipute your Commands.
Until we bring â€” on her Knees,
Not a â€” hall be kind, though it tands.

lg.head: The Womens Anwer.
lg.l: Y'Are deceiv'd in your Plots and your Tricks,
To think to rob us of our pleaure:
Since we rais'd up the pride of your â€”
Upon Hector and Huff without meaure.
You Pimps, you can ooner be damn'd,
Than to live a whole Lent upon Fih.
Drink on Bully-Fops, and be drunk,
Be mad, and profue of your Coin;
That leads you the way to your Punk;
'Tis the only effects of good Wine.
But then if your pirits hould move,
You'd be glad to make us amends;
And rather than loe what you love,
You'd be glad to kis â€” and be friends.

lg.head: A Catch.
lg.l: THe Pot and the Pipe, the cup and the Can,
Have quite undone, quite undone many a man.
The Hawk & the Hound, the Dice, & the Whore,
Have quite undone, quite undone as many more.

lg.head: The flames of Deire.
lg.l: DO not ask me charming Phillis,
Why I lead you here alone,
By this bank of Pinks and Lillies,
And of Roes newly blown.
'Tis not to behold the beauty
Of thoe Flowers which crown the Spring:
'Tis to â€” but I know my duty,
And dare never name the thing.
'Tis at wort but her denying,
Why hould I thus fearful be;
Every minute gently flying,
Smiles, and ays, make ue of me.
What the Sun do's to thoe Roes
Whilt the Beams play weetly in;
I wu'd â€” but my fear oppoes,
And I dare not name the thing.
Yer I die, if I conceal it,
Ask mine eyes, or ask your own;
And if neither dare reveal it,
Think what Lovers think alone.
On this bank of Pinks and Lillies,
Might I peak what I wu'd do
I wu'd with my lovely Phillis,
I wu'd, I wud, ah, wu'd you.

lg.head: The Art of loving.
lg.l: COme hither young Sinner,
Thou raw young beginner;
I'le hew thee if thou cant undertand me,
All the ways of a Wench,
Be he Englih or French,
More than Ovid, de Anti Amandi:
I'le reach thee to know
Borh the who, and the how,
And the when, and the where to delight;
If he imper or Saint it,
Or patch it or paint it,

l.hi: I'le warrant thee, Boy, he is right.

lg.l: If he jigg with her Thighs,
Or twinkle with her Eyes,
She bids you come on, if you like her;
If without joys or fears,
She can laugh and hed tears;
'Tis the only true trick of a Striker:
If he ighs when he peaks,
Or doth ue many freaks,
She is deeply in love, by this light;
If you tread on her Toe,
And he anwer thee o,
She'l mile, and he'l frown,
She'l laugh and lie down,
At every turn you mut tend her:
She'l peep in her Glas,
And dipraie her own Face,
On purpoe that you may commend her:
With Love-tales and Fancies
Pickt out of Romances,
She'l angle to try if you'l bite.
If he peak in a paion,
Or make application.
If he tand at a ditance,
There is no reitance;
Her very retreat is a Call:
She'l tare in your Eyes,
Like a Pyrate for a Prize;
As if he would ay, have at all.
She'l hew you her brew,
To gues at the ret,
The Fountain of Love and delight:
If he it in thy lap,
Beware of a trap.
She'l hit and he'l mis,
She'l be coy, and he'l kis,
To try and find out what you are:
One action hall ay,
And another, Come on, if you dare:
She'l give you a glance,
Like Heav'n in a trance,
No Diamond nor Saphir o bright.
If he drink Wine and Burrage.
And kis with a courage.
She'l et you more nares,
Than her tire hath hairs;
She's ubtle and wift in invention:
If you jet and mean looly,
Though ne'r o recluely,
She'l hew you her quick apprehenion:
Her Plots are abounding,
She fits hath of ounding;
If he call on your name in the f â€¢ ight,
Blind Cupid hath hit her,
And you too may fit her.
When Nol tole the Scepter,
She canted in Scripture,
And went to St. Antholines Lecture:
But now he doth trade,
Like a right Reformade,
And is a Decoy for the Hectors.
She'l wear he is free
From all men but thee,
And bluh like a Bride the firt night.
If he quint through her hood,
'Tis to heighten thy blood.
Her turne and her windings,
Are pat your out-findings.
She hath o many changeable tempers:
She'l give you a look,
Like a Virgin forook,
With another Command like an Empres:
This ign never mies,
If he queak when he kies,
And glimmers like Stars in the night:
If he give thee a trip
With her loe lower-lip,
She'l kis and cry Quarter,
Unloen her Garter,
That you may take't up as a favour;
When you ty't on again,
She'l cry, What d'ye mean:
Y'are a man of a looe behaviour:
Yet thus will he play,
To direct you the way
To the Center and eat of delight:
If he's troubled with qualms,
And weat in the palms,
She'l bid you forbear,
Y'are uncivil, my Dear,
She tempts in her very denial s
When tongue cries, Be gone;
Her looks cry, Come on,
The ticklings are only for trials:
When Rams do retreat;
More courage they get;
And tilt wit with redoubled might:
No ight can o move,
As the Landskip of Love.
She'l give you to wear
A bracelet of Hair,
And that as a fetter he'l lock on:
But let me perwade ye,
One hair of a Lady,
Will draw more than ten Team of Oxen.
Thus have I in brief,
Told the marks of the Thief,
That filches affection by light:
But if he prevail,
Thou'rt a lave in a Goal,
And Honour will bid thee good night.

lg.head: The Rapture.
lg.l: CAlm was the Evening, and clear was the Sky,
And new budding Flowers did pring,
When all alone went Amintas and I
To hear the weet Nightingal ing.
I ate, and he laid him down by me,
And carcely his breath he could draw;
But when with a fear,
He began to come near,
He was daht with an ah ah, ah.
He bluht to himelf, and lay till for a while,
And his modety curb'd his deire,
But treight I convinc'd all his fears with a mile,
Which added new flames to his fire.
Ah, Sylvia! aid he, you are cruel,
To keep your poor Lover in awe;
Then once more he pret,
With his hands to my bret,
But was daht with on ah, ah, ah.
I knew 'twas his paion caus'd all his fear,
And therefore I pitied his cae;
I whiper'd him oftly, there's no body near,
And laid my cheek cloe to his face:
But as he grew bolder,
A Shepherd came by us, and aw;
And jut as our blis
Began with a kis,
He burt out with ha, ha, ha, ha,
I bad him be quiet for fear of the Swain,
And follow me down to the Grove,
Where we crope in a Cave, and chatter'd again,
The dangers that proecute Love,
He plaid with my pretty white hooe-trings;
My legs he did tickle and claw;
But do what I cou'd,
Yet he forced my blood,
And I queek't with an ha, ha, ha.
The mall of my leg he did prettily praie,
And my calf that o roundly did rie;
I wink'd and I frown'd at his foolih delays,
Which made him skip up to my thighs:
He plaid with my oft panting Belly;
I bad to his fingers no law:
But when he did touch
What he loved o much,
He burt out with an ha, ha, ha.

lg.head: A Song of Nothing.
lg.l: I'Le Sing you a Sonnet that ne're was in Print,
'Tis truly and newly come out of the Mint,
I'l tell you before-hand, you'l find nothing in't.
On nothing I think, and on nothing I write,
'tis nothing I court, yet nothing I light,
Nor care I pin, if I get nothing by't.
Fire, Air, Earth, and water, beats, birds, fih and men,
Did tart out of nothing, a Chaos, a Den;
And all things hall turn into nothing again.
'Tis nothing ometimes makes many things hit
As when fools among wie men do ilently it,
A fool that ays nothing, may pas for a Wit.
What one man loves is another mans loathing,
This Blade loves a quick thing, that loves a low thing,
And both do in the concluion love nothing,
Your Lad that makes love to a delicate mooth thing,
And thinking with ighs to gain her and oothing,
Frequently makes much ado about nothing.
At lat when his patience and pure is betra'id,
He may to the bed of a Whore be betray'd;
But he that hath nothing, mut need be a Maid.
Your lahing, and clahing, and lahing of wit,
Doth tart out of nothing, but Fancie and fit;
'Tis little or nothing to what hath been writ.
When firt by the ears we together did fall,
Then omething got nothing, and nothing got all;
From nothing it came, and to nothing it hall.
That party that eal'd to a Cov'nant in hate,
Who our 3 Kingdoms, and Churches lie wate;
Their project, and all came to nothing at lat.
They raied an Army of Hore and Foot,
To tumble down Monarchy, Branches and Root;
They thunder'd and plunder'd, but nothing would do 't.
The organ, the altar, and Miniters clothing
In Presbyter Jack begot uch a loathing,
That he mut needs raie a petty New nothing.
And when he had rob'd us in anctifi'd clothing
Perjur'd the people by faithing and trothing;
At lat he was catch't, and all came to nothing.
In everal Factions we quarrel and brawl,
Dipute, and contend; and to fighting we fall;
I'le lay all to nothing, that nothing wins all.
When war and rebellion, and plundering grows,
The Mendicant man is freet from foe s,
For he is mot happy hath nothing to loe.
Brave Caear and Pompey, and Great Alexander,
Whom Armies follow'd as Gooe follows Gander,
Nothing can ay 'tis an action of lander.
The wiet great Prince, were he never oftout,
Though conquer the world, & give mankind a rout,
Did bring nothing in, nor hall bring nothing out.
Old Nol that aroe from Low-thing to High-thing,
By brewing Rebellion, Micking, & Frothing,
In ev'n years ditance was all things and nothing.
Dick. (Olivers Heir) that pitiful low-thing,
Who was once inveted with purple-cloathing,
Stands for a Cypher, and that tands for nothing.
If King killers bold are excluded from blis,
Old Bradhaw (that feels the reward on't by this)
Had better been nohing, than what now he is.
Blind Collonel Hewon, that lately did crawl
Te lofty degree, from a low Coblers tall,
Did bring Aul to nothing, when Aul came to all.
Your Gallant that Rants in delicate clothing,
Though lately he was but a pitiful low-thing,
Pays Landlord, Draper and Taylor with nothing.
The nimble-tongu'd Lawyer that pleads for his pay
When death doth arret him & bear him away,
At the Gen'ral Bar will have nothing to ay.
Whores that in ilk were by Galants embrac't,
By a rabble of Prentices lately were chac't,
Thus courting, and porting comes to nothing at lat.
If any man tax me with weaknes of wit,
And ay that on nothing, I nothing have writ;
I hall anwer, ex nihilo nihil fit.
Yet let his dicreetion be never o tall,
This very word nothing hall give it a fall;
For writing of nothing, I comprehend all.
Let every man give the Poet his due,
'Caue then it was with him as now it's with you;
He tudi'd it when he had nothing to do.
This very word nothing, if took the right way,
May prove advantageous, for what would you ay,
If the Vintner hould cry, there is nothing to pay.

lg.head: A Catch, of Something,
lg.l: WIll it pleae you to hear a fine Ditty,
In praie of a ix footed Creature,
That lives both in Countrey and City:
She is wonderous loving by nature,
She profereth her ervice to any,
She'le tick fat but that he'le prevail:
She is entertained by many,
Till death, no mater will fail.
She'l venter as far in the Battle,
As any Commander that goes:
She commonly plays Jack-a-both ides,
For he is ure to be hot free,
To kill her no Sword will prevail;
But if he be taken pris'ner,
She's cruhed to death with a nail.
She perfectly hates a neat Laundres,
And all thoe that et her on work;
For all her delights in foul linnen,
In the eams he doth privately lurk:
For he's for him that's non-uited,
Or any good Fellow that lacks.
She will be as good Friend to him,
As his hirt that ticks to his back.
More plainly I cannot decribe her,
For he had her beginning at firt;
She Sprung from the Loyns of great Pharoah,
And that by his Queen he was nurt:
But if you hould be dipleaed,
It is but in vain for to fight her;
I have no more now to ay of her,
But that he is a back-biter.

lg.head: A Song.
lg.l: WHen Aurelia firt I courted,
She had youth and beauty too,
Killing pleaures when he ported,
And her Charms were ever new;
Conquering Time doth now deceive her
Which her glories did uphold,
All her Arts can ne're retrieve her,
Poor Aurelia's growing old.
The airy Spirits which invited,
Are retir'd, and move no more;
And thoe Eyes are now benighted,
Which were Comets heretofore.
Want of thee abate her merits,
Yet I've paion for her name,
Only kind and am'rous Spirits
Kindle and maintain a flame.

lg.head: A New Song.
lg.l: ALl the flatt'ries of Fate,
And the pleaures of tate,
Are nothing o weet, as what Love does create.
If this you deny,
'Tis time I hould die,
Kind Death's a Reprive if you threaten to hate:
In ome cloe hady Grove,
Will I wander and rove
With the Nightingal, and Diconolate Dove,
With down-hanging Wing,
I will mournfully ing,
The tragick Events of unfortunate Love.
With our plaints wel'l conpire,
To heighten Loves fire.
Still vanquihing life, till at length we'll expire.
And when I am dead,
In a cold leaie Bed,
Be interr'd with the Dirge of a deolate Quire.

lg.head: Another.
lg.l: I'Le go to my Love where he lies in the deep,
And in my embraces my dearet hall heep,
When we wake, the kind Dolphins together hall throng,
And in Chariot of Shells hall draw us along.
The Orient hath Pearls, whith the Ocean betows,
And mixed with Coral a Crown to compoe
Though the Sea-nymphs do pite us, and even our blis,
We will teach them to love, & the Cockles to kis.
For my Love lies now in watry Grave,
And hath nothing to hew for his Tomb but a Wave,
I'le kis his dear Lips than the Coral more red,
Thar grows where he lies in his watry Bed.

l.hi: Ah, Ah, Ah, my Love's dead;

lg.l: But a Triton's Shell,

l.hi: To ring, to ring out his Knell.

lg.head: A Song.
lg.l: I Pas all the Night in a hady old Grove,
But I live not the day that I ee not my Love;
I urvey ev'ry walk now my Phillis is gone,
And igh when I think we were there all alone:

l.hi: O then 'tis, O then 'tis, I think there's no Hell,
Like loving, like loving too well.

lg.l: But each Grove, and each concious Bank when I find,
Where I once happy, and he hath been kind,
And py where her print in the green doth remain,
And imagine the pleaures may yet come again;

l.hi: O then 'tis, O then 'tis, I think no joys above,
Like the pleaures, the pleaures of Love.

lg.l: But while I repeat to my elf all her charms,
She I love may be lock'd in another mans arms,
She may laugh at my cares, and o fale may he be,
To ay all the kind things, he before aid to me,

l.hi: O then, 'tis, O then, 'tis I think there's no Hell,
Like loving, like loving too well.

lg.l: But when I conider the truth of her heart,
Such innocent paion o kind without Art,
I fear I have wrong'd her, and hope he may be,
So full of true love, to be jealous of me.

l.hi: O then 'tis, O then 'tis, I think it no Joys above,
Like the pleaures, the pleaures of Love.

lg.head: The Thief-Ketchers Song.
lg.l: Good People give ear whil't a Story I tell,
Of twenty black Trademen were brought up in hell,
On purpoe poor people to rob of their due
There's none hall noozed, if you find but one true;
The firt was a Coyner that tampt in a Mould,
The econd a Voucher to put off his Gold:
The the third was a Padder, that fell to decay;
And vvhen he was living, took to the High way.
The fourth is a Mill-ken, to crack up a Door;
He'll venture to rob both the Rich and the Poor,
The fifth is a Glaier, who when he creeps in:
To pinch all the Lurry, he thinks it no in.
Tour you well, &c.
The ixth is a Foyl-cloy, that not one Hick pare.
The eventh is a Budge, to track up the tairs:
The eighth is a Bulk, that can bulk any hick;
If the Mater be napt, then bulk he is ick.
The ninth is a Ginny, to lift up a Grate;
If he ees but the Lurry, with his hooks he will bate.
Tour you well, &c.
Th tenth is a Shoplit that carries a Bob,
When he ranges the City the Shops for to rob.
The eleventh is a Bubber, much ued of late,
He goes to the Alehoue, & teals there the Plate.
The twelfth a Trapan, if a Cull he doth meet,
He nips all his Cole, and turns him i'th' treet.
Tour you well, &c.
The thirteenth a Famble, fale Rings for to ell,
When a Mob he has bit, his Cole he will tell.
The fourteenth a Gameter, if he ees the Hic weet,
He preentry drops down a Cog in the treet.
The fifteenth a Prancer, vvhoe courage is mall;
If they catch him hore-couring he's noozed for al.
Tour you well, &c.
The ixteenth a She-napper, vvhoe Trade's o deep,
If he's caught in the Corn, he's mark'd for a heep.
The eventeenth a Dun-aker, that vvill make vows,
To go in the Countrey, and teal all the Cows.
The eighteenth a Kid-napper, Spirits young men,
Though he tip them the piks, they nap him agen.
Tour you well, &c.
The nineteenth is a Prigger of the Cacklers,
Goe. into the Countrey to viit the Farmers,
He teals their Poultry, and thinks it no in,
When into the Hen-root i'th' night he gets in.
The twentieth a Thief-catcher, o we him call,
If he nap a poor Trademan, he pays for all.
Tour you well, &c.
There's many more Craftmen which I could name,
That do ue uch like trades, yet think it no hame:
Thee may a young Convert confes to his grief,
Are all the black Trades of a Gentleman Thief:
Who though a good Workman, is eldom made free,
Till he rides on a Cart to be nooz'd on a Tree.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE: OR, Vices SAD CATASTROPHE.
Of Covetounes.

p.hi: THe better hap a man hath to attain to Riches, the more he is accured, in being more tormented with the feavers of the mind and unquietnes. This Vice is held to be the root of all evil, lacking as well thoe things which it enjoyeth, as which it wanteth.

div.p: THe Scithians only make no ue of Gold and Silver, for ever deteting and condemning the montrous in of covetounes. Solinus.

Caligula, was o covetous, that there was no kind of lucre, or mean to get money by, how unlawful oever it were, which he ought not out, inomuch as he laid a tribute upon Urine, and old his Siters Gowns, whom he had ent into banihment. Vale â€¢ ius.

Calipha, King of Peria, having filled a Tower with Gold, Jewels, and precious Stores, and being in war with Allan King of Tar â€¢ ary, was o ill â€¢ uccoured of his own people, becaue he would not give them their pay, that he was taken of Allan, and famihed in that Tower where all his Treaure lay.

Dionyius the Elder, advertied of one that had hid great tore of money, commanded him upon pain of death to bring it to him, which he did, although not all; but with the remainder dwelt in another place, & betowed it upon an Inheritance, when Dionyius heard thereof, he ent him that which he took from him, aying, Now thou knowet how to ue riches, take that I had from thee.
Hermocrates, ready to die, bequeathed his goods to himelf.
One at the hour of his death, wallowed many pieces of God, and ewed the ret in his Coat, commanding that it hould be buried with him Atheneus.

One beieged in the Tower of Cailino by Hannibal, choe rather to ell a Rat which he had â€¢ aken for 200 Roman pence, than to atisfie hi â€¢ hunger, whereof he died â€¢ raight after, but the other aved his life by that dear meat. Valerius.
The Popes Camera, or Echequer, is like unto the Sea, wherein to all Rivers do run, and yet it overfl â€¢ weth not. P. Martyr.
The old Clergy being asked why they cannot live by <â€¦> lines but by covetounes, anwered, Nunc aliud tempus, alii pro tempore mores. Polychr.
Demonica betrayed Epheus to Brennus of Senona for Gold, who demanded her reward of him, who brought her to a great heap of gold, and loaded her o heavy therewith, that he died under the burden.
Euclio, had hidden uch treaure under the ground, that he durt go out of his houe for fear of robbing, nor tarry in it for fear of killing. Plautus.

p.U: irnamed Sophita, when a neighbour of his had ent him a few dainty fihes, for a preent in a ilver dih; he took both the ilver dih and the fihes, aying to the Meenger, Thank thy Mater, and tell him, I take his fihes for Novelties, and his ilver dih for a preent.

div.p: Simonides, when he was requeted to do any thing gratis, id et, for nothing, aid, That he had two Chets, the one hut up for thanks, the other open for money. Plut.

Vepaian, when he heard that a ilver Image of great ubtance hould be made for a Monument of his worthines, he traight held out his hand, aying, Behold, here is a place ready to et an Image, a ure foundation from falling.

Vepaian, of pure miery, niggardhip, and covetounes, commanded in Rome to be made publike places to receive Urine, not to keep the City more weet, but to the end they hould give him more rent. Suetouius.

Simonides, being demanded why he hoo â€¢ ded up
money towards the end of his old age, Becaue
â€¢ quoth he) I had rather leave my goods to mine enemies, than to have need of the relief of my friends while I am alive.

Virgil, in his ixth book of Aeneiads, putteth thoe perons in Hell, which have done no good to their friends, kinsfolk, and neighbours, but have been wholly wedded to their riches, without imparting them to others. Virgil.

Ochus, King of Peria, would never go into the Countrey of Pereland, becaue that by the Law of the Realm, he was bound to give to every woman that had born children, one French crown, and to every woman with child two.
Plato, thought it almot impoible, for a man very rich to be honet, yet Solon as wie as he, deired to have riches, but not to get them by wrong. Plut.

Anacreon, having received of Polycrates five talents for a gift, was o much troubled for the pace of two nights with care, how he might keep them, and how to imploy them bet, that he carried them back again, aying, That they were not worth the p â€¢ ins he had already taken for them.
Socrates, being ent for by K. Archelaus, to come and receive tore of Gold, ent him word that a meaure was old in Athens for a penny double; and that water cot him nothing.
Lyc â€¢ rgus, abrogated the ue of Gold and Silver coyn, and appointed Iron money to be currant, by this means he banihed from them the deire of Riches.
Caligula, took of every Curtezan, as much of her gain as he could get of any man at once.

Pertinax, being advanced to the degree of Emperor, did not forget his niggardlines, but parted
Lettice and Ar â€¢ ichooks in two, that the one half might be for his dinner, and the other for his Supper. Eutropius.
The Parimony of Fabritius, is not to be condemned, for the age wherein he lived, ought to excue him, in the which all magnificence was unknown to the Romans.
Jutinian the Emperor, for himelf procured Riches, and for the Devil he cheapned Souls, he was covetous, and maintained the hereie of the Pelagians.
Epimenides, cure of Riches was, that all the Treaures hoarded up by the covetous, hould be wated by the prodigal.
The Romans, and the Carthaginians, were friends a long time, but after they knew there was in Spain great mines of Gold and Silver, immediately aroe between them Civil Wars. P. Diaconus.

Darius, being very rich and covetous, ent to Alexander in corn, to know where he had treaure to maintain uch an Army, who anwered, Tell thy Mater that he keepth in his Coffe â€¢ s his Treaures of Metals. and I have no other Treaure than the hearts of my friends. Plutarch.

Angelot, a Cardinal, was o covetous. that by a fale door he decended into the Stable, and every night tole away the Oates which his Hore-keepers had given his Hores, and continued it o long, till one of the Hore-keepers hiding himelf in the table, did o belabour him with a Pikefork, that he had much adoe to crawl away. J. Pontanus.

div.head: Of Sloth.

p.hi: In this Vice, Wit, ndertanding, Widom, and all honet endeavours are buried, as it were in a grave, from which arieth the loathome tench of corrupt maners and diordered life, making of men women, of women beats, of beats monters.

div.p: ALexander, an Emperor of the Eat, given to to great idlenes, demanded if he had long to live, they anwered him, Yea, If he could take away the teeth of a brazen Boar that tood in the Market-place; meaning thereby, that he hould horten his days, except he gave over his idlenes. Zonarus.
A Senator of Rome, who was falured by an other, riding in his Chariot, anwered, I will not ay God ave you, ince in going thus at your eae, you hew you have no deire to live long.
Epaminondas, dicharged all his Souldiers that grew fat, aying, That as a woman too fat doth not eaily conceave, o doth fat hinder a man from doing his charge, as Arms which are too heavy.
Scipio, being arrived at his Camp, banihed all Souldiers laves, and Pages, and all unprofitable people, and made each one to carry his own Armour.
The Sabies, having abundance of all kind of Riches, pent their times lothfully.
The Nabathies, having nothing but what they get by their virtue and labour, are good husbands, and abandon all idlenes,

Metellus, when he was arrived in Africa, he took away whatoever might eem to no â€¢ ri â€¢ h lothfulnes, and caued Proclamation to be made, that
none hould preume to ell either bread or any other food dreed; that the Carriers of water hould not follow the Camp, that the Souldiers hould have no Pages, no Beats of Carriage, that each one hould keep his rank, cat his Trench, and carry his Victuals together with his Furniture. Salust.

In the Ilands named Bal â€¢ ares in Spain the Children might not eat, untill they with their lings they had trucken down their meat, which their Parents ued â€¢ o et for them upon an high beam or pool. Pliny.
Epaminondas killed one of his Souldiers being aleep, that was et to watch, aying, that he left him in the ame etate that he found him.
The Kings of Peria and Macedonia, were every morning awaked, to put them in mind to take care of that which God had committed to their charge. Herodo â€¢ .

At certain Games of Olympus, there came a Philoopher of Thebes, which had made all the apparel he wore himelf; the Aembly marvelling that one could do all this; he anwered, The loth of man is the caue that one Art is divided into divers; for â€¢ e that knoweth all Arts together, mut needs know one alone. He was reputed a valn glorious Phil â€¢ opher.

More hurtful was the City of Carthage to Rome after her detruction, than during the whole coure and eaon of Wars which the Romans had with her; for that whilet they had enemies in Africk, they knew not what vices meant in Rome. Guevara.

The great Numantia in Spain could never be won (notwithtanding fourteen years iege of the Romans) till Scipio purged his Camp of loyterers,
perfumers, and Harlots.
Darius plunged the Babylonis in all manner of idlenes, that they might not have the heart afterward to rebel.
The ame policie ued Cimon to diminih the force of his Allies, by granting them whatoever they required.

The carelenes and negligence of Dionyius the Younger, getting the upper-hand of him, carried him to women and lechery, and at length did break in under his Adamant chains; that is, the greatnumber of his warlike Souldiers, and his tore of Gallies, of whom his Father had boated that he left his Kingdom fat chained to his Son.
Sardanapalus through his lothfulnes was overcome by Artabactus, and lot the Monarchy of Ayria.

The Pheacons counted it the greatet felicity that might be, to do nothing,
<> .
The Romans ued to punih idlenes o harply, that the husbandman whoe ground was found barren, and his patures unoccupied, was preently put from the place, and his ground given to another man.
Macarius and Diogenes, for that they would not be accounted idle perons, the one would remove heaps of and from place to place, and the other would tumble his tub up and down.
Augutus did win the Souldiers unto him with rewards, the common ort with plenty of Victuals, and all generally with the pleaure of eae. Tacitus.

When Augutus reproached a certain Player becaye through his occaion there was a tumult among the people, he anwered, It is good for thee, O Caar, that the people be with held by our idle exercies, from buying their brains about other matters.

div.head: Of Gluttony.

p.hi: This deadly enemy to health, repleniheth the body with Humors, Wind, Inflammations, Ditillations and Operations; and change of Meats draweth pleaure out of the bounds of ufficiencie; Pleaure, in all things which pleaeth, where as in imple and uniform things, delight never exceedeth the appetite and natural neceity.

div.p: THe Arigentines builded as though they hould always live, and did eed as though they hould always die. Plato.
The Emperor Septimus Severus and Jovinianus died with eating and drinking too much.
Valentinianus a famous Emperor, died uddenly of a uret.
Lucullus being asked one day by his Servant, whom he had invited to his feat, eeing o much meat prepared? anwered, Lucullus hall dine with Lucallus. Plut.
Vitellius Spinter, was o much given to gluttony and exces, that at one upper, he was erved with two thouand everal kind of fihes, and with 7000 flying Fowl.

Muleaes King of Tennis, after he was deprived of his Kingdom, in his return out of Almaign, being without hope that the Emperor Charles the fifth would help him at all, he pent one hundred Crowus upon a Peacock dreed for him.
Maximilian the Emperor devoured in one day forty pounds of fleh, and drunk an hoghead of Wine.

Geta the Emperor, for three days together continued his Fetival, and his delicates were brought
in by order of the Alphabet.
Atydamas being invited by Ariobarzanes to a Banquet, eat up all that alone, which was provided for divers Guets.

There was a Contention between Hercules and Lepreas which of them both hould-firt devour an Oxe, in which attempt Lepreas was overcome; afterwards he challenged him for drinking, but Hercules was his Mater.
Aglais, whoe practie was to ound the Trumpet, devoured at every meal twelve pounds of fleh, with as much bread, as two buhels of wheat would make, and three gallons of Wine.
Philoxenes, a notorious glutton, wihed he had a neck like a Crane, that the weet meat which he eat might be long in going down. Raviius.
Lucullus at a olemn and cotly feat he made to certain Embaadors of Aia, among other things, he did eat a Griph boiled, and a Gooe in pate.

Lucullus took great pains himelf in furnihing of a Feat, and when he was asked why he was o curious in etting out a banquet, he anwered That there was as great dircetion to be ued in marh â€¢ lling of a Feat, as in the ordering of a Battle, that the one might be terrible to his enemies, and the other acceptable to his friends. Plut.
In Rhodes, they that love fih, are accounted right courteous, and free-hearted men, but he that delighteth more in fleh, is ill thought of, and to his great hame is reputed a bondlave to his belly.
Sergius Galba was a devouring and gluttonous Emperor, for he caued at one banquet even thouand birds to be killed.
