Xerxes having tated of the figs of Athens, ware by his Gods that he would eat no other all his life after, and went forthwith to prepare an Army to
conquer Grecia, for no other caue but to fill his belly full of the figs of that Countrey.
The Sicilians dedicated a Temple to Gluttony, and erected Images to Bacchus and Ceres, the God and Goddes of Wine and Corn.

M. Manlius, in times pat made a Book of divers ways how to dres meat, and another of the tates, auces and divers means of ervices, which were no ooner publihed, but by the decree of the Senate, they were burned, and if he had not fled peedily into Aia, he had been burned with them.
There was a Law in Rome called Fahia, by which it was prohibited, that no man hould dipend in the greatet Feat he made, above an hundred Sextexterces.
Nioeus a Tirant of Syracue, when he undertood by his Soothayers that he had not long to live, what he had left, he pent in belly-chear and drunkennes, and o died.

p.U: et forth a book of his drunkennes, in which he proved thoe pranks when he was overcome with wine, to be good and lawful.

div.p: Darius had written upon his grave this incr â€¢ iption; I could drink tore of Wine, and bear it well.
Ptolomey, who in a mockery was called Philopater, becaue he put to death his Father and Mother, through wine and women died like a beat.
Aruntius a Roman, being drunken, deflowred his own Daughter Medullina, whom he forthwith killed.
Tiberius Caear was preferred to a Pretorhip, becaue of his excellencie in drinking.

Diotimus, was irnamed Funnel, or Tunnel, be caue he gulped down wine through the channel of his Throat, which was poured into a Funnel, the end whereof was put into his mouth, with out interpoition between gulps.
In the Feat of Bacchus a Crown of Gold was appointed for him that could drink mot.
Cleio a woman, was o practied in drinking, that he durt challenge all men and women whatoever, to try materies who could drink mot, and overcome all.
Cleomenes King of Lacedemonia, being dipoed to caroue after the manner of the Scythians, drank o much, that he became and continued e ver after enceles.
Cyrillus Son, in his drunkennes, wickedly lew that holy man his Father, and his mother great with Child, he hurt his two iters, and deflowred one of them.

Androcides a Gentleman of Greece, hearing of Alexanders exces in Drunkennes, wrote a Letter to him, wherein was a Tablet of Gold, with thee words thereon engraven, Remember Alexander when thou drinket wine, that thou doest drink the blood of the earth.

Thoe of Gallia Tranalpina, undertanding that the Italians had planted Vines in Italy, came to conquer their Countrey; o that if they had never planted Vines, the French-men had not demanded the Countrey.

Four old Lombards being at Banquet together, the one drank an health round to the others years, in the end they challenged two to two, and after each man had declared how many years old he was, the one drank as many times as he had years, and likewie his companion pledged him, the one was 58. the econd 63. the third 87. the lat 92. o that a man knoweth not what they did eat or drink; but he that drank leat, drank 5 â€¢ . cups of Wine.

div.head: Of Lechery.

p.hi: T is bewitching evil, being an unbridled appetite, in whomoever it reigneth, killeth all good motions of the mind, alteretr, drieth, and weakneth the body, hortning life, diminihing Memory, and ndertanding.

div.p: CYrena, a notorius trumpet, was irnamed Dode camechana, for that he found out and invented and found out twelve everal ways of beatly pleaure.
Proculeius the Emperour, of an hundred Sarmatian Virgins he took captive, he deflowred ten the firt night, and all the ret within fifteen dayes after.
Hercules in one night deflowred fifty.
Johannes Ã Caa, Archbihop of Benevento, and Legate in Venice, writ a Book in praie of the abominable vice of Sodomitry.

p.U: trived to have carnal knowledge of his Son Rohert, who thrutint his dagger into his Fathers boom, revenged his wickednes.

div.p: Cleopatra, had the ue of her brother Ptolomeus company, as of her husbands.

p.U: tayd a whole winter in Chalcidea, for one maid which he there fancied.

div.p: Lut was the caue of the Wars between the Romans and the Sabines.
Thalestris Queen of the Amazons came 25 days journey to lie with Alexander.
Adultery in Germany is never pardoned.

Mealina and Popilia were o incontinent, that they contended with mot hameful harlots, protituting
themelves without repect of time place, or company, to any, though never o bae.
Claudius deflowred his own iters, and Semiramis burned in beatly lut towards her on Ninus.
Nero caued Atticus a Roman Conul to be lain, that he might the more conveniently enjoy the company of his wife
Commodus, not contented with his three hundred Crncubines, committed incet with his own iters.
Caligula did the like, but the one was lain by his wife, the other by his Concubine.
Adultery was the caue of the firt alteration of the City of Rome.
Sempronia a woman, well learned in the Greek, and Sappho, no les famous, defended luxury and lat by their writings.
Cleopatra invited Anthony to a Banquet in the Province of Bithinia in the wood Sethem, where, at one intant, of threecore young Virgins, fifty and five were made Mothers.

Cleophis a Queen of Tridia, aved her Kingdom and Subjects from detruction, by a nights l â€¢ dging with Alexander, by whom he had a Son called Alexander, who was afterward King of India; he was ever after called Scortum Reginum.
Helogabalus, not only deflowred, but alo married a Virgin Vetal, aying it was reaon that Priets hould marry Nuns, becaue that in times pat he had been Priet of the Sun.
Jane Quen of Naples was hanged up for her advoutry, in the very ame place where he had had hanged her husband Andreas afore, becaue he was not (as he aid) able to atisfie her beatly deire.

Feron King of Egypt had been blind ten years,
and in the eleventh the Oracle told him that he hould recover his ight, if he wahed his eyes in the water of a woman which never had to do â€¢ t any but her husband; whereupon, he firt made â€¢ l of his â€¢ w â€¢ wif, <>
â€¢ ha â€¢ did him no good; after, <> ininite o â€¢ h â€¢ which did him all as little, five only one, by <> he recovered his ight, and then he put <â€¦> death.

Julia he Daug â€¢ r â€¢
<â€¦> o immodet, hameles, and â€¢ ch â€¢
<â€¦>
â€¢ mperour was never able to reclaim her; <â€¦> adm â€¢ nihed to forake her ba â€¢
<â€¦> , and to f â€¢ llow chatity as her Father did, <> anwered, That her â€¢ ather forgot he was Caar, but as for her elf, he knew well enough that he was Caars Daughter.
Cornelius Gallus, and Q. Elerius two Roman Knights, died in the very action of their filthy lut.
Arichbertus, eldet Son unto Letharius King of France, died even as he was embracing his whores.
Alcibiades was burned in his bed with his Curtezan Timandra.
The Egyptians punihments againt adultery, was, to cut off the noe of the woman, and the privy parts of the man.

Alexander when a woman was brought to him one evening, demanded of her why he came o late? he anwered, that he tayed until her husband was gone to bed. Which he no ooner heard, but ent her away, being angry with them that had almot made him commit adultery.
He was angry with Caander, becaue he would by force kis a Mintrels maid.
Roduldus King of Lombardy being taken in adultery, was lain by the womans Husband whom he abued.
Roderigo King of Spain was deprived of his Kingdom and life by the Sarazens, who were called in by an Earl called Julian, that he might be avenged of his King for forcing his daughter.
Calius Rhodoginus in his 11 Book of Antiquiquities, telleth of a certain man, that the more he was beaten, the more he fervently deired women.

The widow of the Emperor Sigimund intending to marry again, one perwaded her to pend the remainder of her life after the manner of the Turtle Dove, who hath but one mate; If you counel me (quoth he) to follow the example of Birds, who do you not tell me of Pidgeons and Sparrows, which after the death of their mates, do ordinarily couple with the next they meet
Hiero King of Syracua banihed the Poet Epicharmus for peaking wantonly before hir wife, and that very jutly, for his wife was a true mirrour of chatity.
Sulpitius Gallus, put away his Wife by divorce, becaue he went abroad unmasked.

Pompey caued one of his Souldiers eyes to be put out in Spain, for thruting his hand under a womans garment that was a Spaniard; and for the like offence, did Sertorius command a footman of his band to be cut in pieces.
If Caracalla had not een his Mothers thigh, he had not married her.
Speuippus the Philoopher, one of Platoes folowers, was lain for his adultery.
Tigellinus died among his Concubines.
